PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Leo McLeay) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Prime Minister aware that within the last hour Mr Connell has told the Royal Commission into corruption-the Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters-in Perth that on 15 June 1987 Mr Connell had a private meeting with the Prime Minister and Premier Burke prior to the lunch? What was the purpose of this private meeting; what subjects were discussed; what commitments were given; and why did the Prime Minister not tell the House last week about this private meeting with Mr Connell?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, I am not aware of the evidence that has been given by Mr Connell this morning. At the outset, in answering that question, I would like to take the opportunity to go to issues that the Leader of the Opposition has raised and with respect to which he has said that there are questions that need answering.

—I would hope that those opposite would expect that I would take this first opportunity, within the framework of this question, to answer those questions. I would like, at the outset, to go to the circumstances of this lunch, to what happened at that time and to all of the relevant circumstances leading up to it in relation to all the questions which, last Friday, the Leader of the Opposition said publicly needed to be answered.

ANSWER.PARA: A program had been prepared in advance for the 1987 election campaign, including visits to Perth. A private lunch was organised for 15 June by Mr Burke, who had told me that he intended to seek financial support for the Australian Labor Party. Of course, it is perfectly normal and proper for a political leader to attend and speak at such a function. At the luncheon, as I have said, I spoke informally, but in some detail, on the record and achievements of my Government to that time. I spoke not only about the positive reasons why this Government should be supported and re-elected, but also, as I have said, about the hopeless inadequacy of the Opposition in terms of forming an alternative government. Also, at that lunch, I spoke of the Government's plans for the future.

It is entirely possible that at the luncheon the issue of a gold tax was discussed. It was, as will be recollected, a major issue in Western Australia at that time and it would have been surprising if it had not been raised. If it was, I would have talked in terms of the Government's policy. That policy should have been well known, but it was continually being queried by the Australian Gold Mining Industry Council and the Opposition. I do not think anyone will be surprised when I say that I cannot be dogmatic about every detail of that luncheon; but I assert this fundamental point, which I have from the beginning-I do now, and I will at all times: I gave no private commitment on this matter and could not have given any such private commitment. I would not have said anything beyond what I had already said publicly only a few hours earlier: no gold tax if re-elected.

Let me refer to the details of what I had said so there can be no doubt in anyone's mind on that point. I refer to the reference to the interview on 6WF with Diana Warnock. I was asked, `If you are re-elected will there be a gold tax?' I replied, `No'. This was on the morning of 15 June. The observation-not a question-by Warnock was:
The Australian Financial Review of the following day, 16 June, had no doubt at all as to what I had said. It reported that statement of the morning of 15 June in these terms:
The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, gave an unequivocal guarantee yesterday that his Government would not introduce either a gold tax or a broadly-based consumption tax if elected for a third term.

What I had said that morning was interpreted in that way, as it should have been-the only way it could have been interpreted. I have no recollection of being involved in any discussions about specific donations at the lunch, and nor is there any suggestion that I was. That is quite clear from the evidence. There was no suggestion that I was engaged in any discussions about specific donations at the lunch.

I can, however, say that there was no need for any donation to the Labor cause to establish this policy. It was already set in place and had been for some time. The record shows that the Treasurer had stated that there would be no gold tax at least twice between the election being called and 15 June. That policy was public knowledge.

I would like to refer to a sequence of matters which is relevant to that point. On 23 April 1987, in a speech in Sydney launching the Australian nugget bullion coin, I referred to the Government's decision not to remove the tax exempt status of the goldmining industry. It was a theme to which I returned a fortnight later on 7 May at the annual dinner of the Australian Mining Industry Council. There was no ambiguity about my words. I said:
Let me add that after a review of the taxation arrangements for the gold mining industry, we decided not to remove its current income tax exemption . . .

Less than three weeks later, on 27 May, I announced that a general election would be held on 11 June 1987. The Treasurer, Mr Keating, also made it plain on 30 May that the Government was not considering a gold tax. He was reported in the Canberra Times as saying that a gold tax had been considered, the decision had been made and that `it's off the agenda'. This was reiterated on 4 June in a media statement from the Treasurer's office which said that the Government had rejected outright the Gutman recommendation for the imposition of a gold tax. That statement from the Treasurer's office continued:
Having made that decision, the Government has before it no proposals to change the tax treatment of the goldmining industry, nor does it have any intention of considering any proposals.

From that chronology it should be plain that, with an election at most only months away, the Government's policy against the introduction of a gold tax was firmly established and it was widely publicised. It was inevitable in the circumstances that the `no tax' December decision of Cabinet would not only stand but also have to apply to Labor's next term of office. In political terms, it was meaningless otherwise. As 1987 wore on it became increasingly relevant to relate that decision to post-election matters, as the Treasurer did on 30 May, as I have said, in reference to our intentions, if re-elected, for Labor's 1987 Budget.

As I have said, in May 1987 I addressed the Australian Mining Industry Council's annual dinner. As I have said, at that speech I referred to the December Cabinet decision. On the eve of an election campaign the reference only made sense as applied to the next term of a re-elected Labor government. As I have said, the question was put to me explicitly when I was interviewed on radio in Perth on the morning of 15 June. I have referred to the unequivocal answer that I gave, the way it was immediately accepted by the interviewer and the proper interpretation that was made by the Australian Financial Review the following day. I also seek to repeat this: whether a policy is public or not, I do not trade off the policies of this Party for campaign donations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those opposite can laugh. I have not done it and I will not do it. Let me say-and I say it with full respect to the honourable member for Bennelong-that the Australian Financial Review of 22 June reported a meeting between the Leader of the Opposition, as he then was, Mr Howard, and Mr Bond. It is entirely possible that the issue of gold tax was raised at that meeting but, if it was, I am sure that the honourable member for Bennelong, as Leader of the Opposition, would have provided the same assurance as the one that I have publicly alluded to.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me say in regard to the questions that were raised and said by the Leader of the Opposition needed to be publicly answered: we came to the decision of 7 July to put our election commitment in writing to the Gold Mining Industry Council. As I have said, this was something we had resisted because we were keen to avoid being deluged with similar demands by other lobby groups. But, as the honourable member for Kalgoorlie has proudly proclaimed, the strategy of those in the goldmining industry was ultimately successful because they forced the Liberals to cave in. With the Liberal commitment in the bag, the gold lobby threatened--

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a matter of record. As a matter of record, the Leader of the Opposition gave that commitment in writing. I am indebted to the honourable member for Bennelong: he acknowledges that he did. With that commitment in the bag, the gold lobby threatened that, unless there was a written commitment from us, Labor would face a massive campaign in the last days of the election. ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer was consulted. While, for reasons that I have stated, neither the Treasurer nor I liked the idea of putting the matter in writing, we both recognised the inevitability of doing so. It was evidence of what could be achieved by an influential third party lobby group and it is relevant to our proposals on political advertising and public disclosure of donations.

It is a matter of record that it was this Government that bit the bullet in 1988, taking a decision to introduce a gold tax from January 1991, as it is equally a matter of record that in, I think, October of 1989 the Opposition, in its Economic Action Plan, also came out and said that, if it was elected at the next election, it would not change the decision that we had announced in May of 1988 for the tax to come into effect in January 1991.

I seek to make the point as strongly as I possibly can that, as far as I am concerned, at no stage either on 15 June or at any other point did I give any private commitment to Mr Connell or anyone else. The position that I had arrived at on this matter was that, in the electoral situation with which the Government was faced, the decision that we had taken in December in regard to a gold tax was one that had to apply for the whole period of the next Labor government. But clearly it would have made no political sense if we had had a position that we would not do it for one month or two months or three months; it was politically meaningless. I had come to the position-and clearly had made it abundantly publicly clear that morning-that that was the position that the Labor Party would have to adopt. I repeat: I have been in public life for 33 years now and I assert--

TALK.START.PARA: —Those opposite do not like it. I am entitled, in the context of the questions that are asked and the innuendo that is put, to make the point that in 33 years of public life in the industrial wing of the trade union movement and in the political wing of the Labor movement, my integrity has not been for sale; it is not there for someone to buy for any amount of money, and it was not on this occasion. What happened was clearly that I, on behalf of this Government, had arrived at a position where the Labor Party, if re-elected to government, would not impose a tax on gold in the next term of that government. I made that perfectly clear that morning.

ANSWER.PARA: I have not, on any occasion, in any circumstance, on 15 June or on any other occasion, given a private commitment on this matter. All I have done at all points is state what the position of the Party would be if re-elected. We adhere to that. I repeat: in the end we were the only side of politics which then had the guts to make the decision but while adhering to that commitment not to introduce the tax in the lifetime of that next government. I am pleased to say not only that we did it but also that the Opposition, finally in 1989, as distinct from the difficulties those opposite quoted beforehand, acknowledged the correctness of the decision we have taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Treasurer inform the House of the implication for Australia's economic development of the measures announced in and taken since the economic statement of May 1988?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That statement was very significant in the history of the Australian taxation system. I remind the House of some of the things that were done: the cutting of the company tax rate to 39 per cent; the introduction of the abolition of 5-year/3-year depreciation; the introduction of foreign source income legislation; research and development incentives; the abolition of private company dividends, dividends paid by tax exempt entities; the abolition of the exemption on goldmining income; pre-paid expenses; the prescribed payment system; expanded audit programs; and, of course, a radical change to the tax treatment of superannuation. It was one of a succession of landmark changes to the tax system, the first being in the tax statement of 1985.

ANSWER.PARA: But the tax statement of 1985, which dealt with the absolute haemorrhaging of the Australian taxation system through capital gains taxation, through fringe benefits taxation, through dealing with all of the loopholes which existed at that time, was of course under attack by the then Opposition. It remained under attack and was voted against by the then Opposition when all of the measures came to the Parliament. But we remember the desperate campaign of the then Opposition in 1987, which was referred to in the previous question in this House. We then heard the Leader of the Opposition, a questioner on this issue. `How goes vote buying', says the Australian Financial Review, `with $7.3 billion in tax cuts?'. Honourable members should listen to this:

Capital gains tax goes. Fringe benefits tax goes, deductions restored for entertainment expenses. The assets test goes. Changed treatment of lump sum superannuation pay outs, which underpins the whole reform of tax superannuation, goes.

That was the policy of credit. And here is the tax policy statement by the honourable member for Bennelong. It states that a Liberal Government would also abolish Labor's capital gains tax, assets test, fringe benefits tax, et cetera. In addition to that, in the course of that shabby campaign with those shabby policies, the Leader of the Opposition made a commitment that he would not introduce a gold tax over the three year term of the next Liberal Government. The Prime Minister does have to explain an apparent embellishment of the Government's public position seen as different to give a timeless nonspecific promise not to introduce something and then say you won't introduce it for the lifetime of the upcoming Parliament. All that the Prime Minister did was write in exactly the same terms as those used by the Leader of the Opposition, which were:

He did exactly the same as the Leader of the Opposition did.

With capital gains tax, we had a situation where the Opposition wanted to adhere to a position where billions of dollars more were being paid by ordinary pay as you earn taxpayers-more and more being paid by them because the Opposition was going to make sure that the most privileged people in the community were not going to pay the tax on capital gains that they should. As I have said, in the situation of 1987-and particularly in the period leading up to the election-I had the responsibility, as Prime Minister, of making the decision. The Cabinet is not operating in that period. It is the responsibility of the Prime Minister to make a decision in accordance with those in authority with whom he seeks to have any discussion and to make a decision which he believes is necessary in terms of the interests of the party and the government.

I did that with total authority according to the conventions, and in full discussion with the Treasurer, as he has acknowledged. This was a joint decision that we took. So there is the answer to the honourable member's question. TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories advise the House on the present state of the environment in the Persian Gulf following the massive oil spill?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: THE ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I know that a lot of members in this House are very interested in the state of the Gulf. When I answered a question in this House on another occasion I said that when I received further information I would report that to the House. Members of the House will be aware that the Australian Government has sent two marine biologists and two oil spill experts and supplied and transported oil spill equipment to Saudi Arabia. I have received recent information on the environmental aspects of the spill from one of the experts who was sent from Australia. I am informed that the oil spills commenced on 19 January this year and at least seven sources are known, including tankers, terminals and refineries. The total spill has not been fully determined but it is likely to be in the order of six million barrels.

ANSWER.PARA: The spills have resulted in two types of slicks-very thin slicks located in the centre of the Gulf, and very thick slicks which have impacted on the coast of Saudi Arabia. By far the majority of the spilt oil has moved south along the Saudi coast, eventually impacting all the shoreline to a coastline distance of 460 kilometres from the source.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Mitchell!

—The reality of it is that one cannot read this sort of thing in the newspaper; this comes from advisers that this Government has taken the trouble to send to the area; and they are making a very important contribution.

ANSWER.PARA: The reason I am giving this answer is so that I can provide more detailed information to the House. Along the sandy beaches the oil occurs in a band of between 10 and 100 metres wide. Surface coverage within the band is about 100 per cent. On the beach slope the oil has been worked into the sediment to a depth of two to 30 centimetres. At the base of the beach slope, the oil has often been pooled to depths of several centimetres. The intertidal zone in this area has been very heavily affected. Within the impacted area, most of the salt marsh and all of the mangroves have been oiled. It is likely then that all the mangroves and virtually all the salt marshes will die. The oil does not appear to have settled in subtidal areas and there have been no apparent short term lethal impacts on the seagrass beds or the reefs. The intertidal shores of some offshore coral islands have been heavily impacted, but the reefs appear to be unaffected.

The slick has killed an estimated 20,000 to 30,000 seabirds; marine mammals do not appear to be significantly affected. Small numbers of turtles and some sea snakes seem to have died from being smothered by the oil. Fish mortalities have been fairly localised to shrimps, crabs and molluscs that have died in very large numbers. The destruction of the intertidal habitats is expected to have a very major impact on populations of birds which migrate through the Gulf area.

This needs to be put in some perspective. The Exxon Valdez spill was 224,000 barrels of oil. So far, over 600,000 barrels of oil have been recovered from the Gulf war spills. This quantity is insignificant compared with what is still in the environment. Due to the magnitude of the spill, the types of habitats impacted and the extreme inaccessibility of some areas, it is unrealistic to expect that much of the coast will be cleaned. I am informed that the Saudi authorities are now identifying the most important sites which, upon recovery, may act as sources for recolonisation of some other sites. Clean-up of selected habitats is also about to begin. Oil is to be flushed from some mangrove areas and some salt marshes.

A final concern worthy of note is the oil fires in Kuwait. A huge volume of oil is not burning and is forming into huge lakes. It is feared that these may eventually flood into the Gulf, potentially creating a spill of even greater magnitude. I think it is important that we pay tribute to those Australians who are working there and to the others who are part of the international clean-up effort.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, despite his selective answers in the House today, so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the Prime Minister from giving forthwith to this House a full account of the processes involved in the Government's decision in the 1987 election campaign not to impose a gold tax during the term of the next government, including what undertakings were given by the Prime Minister to Mr Connell and others.

We have had several attempts by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in this Parliament to provide selective details of what actually transpired in the lead-up to the 1987 election. On each occasion he has tended, as he did again today, to raise more questions than he answers in respect of what actually transpired in the settling of the final commitment, a three-year commitment not to introduce a gold tax. Of course, the allegations continue to be made in the Western Australia corruption royal commission and each of those is going to continue to call for the Prime Minister to give a complete answer.

Today the Prime Minister has almost done a full circle in his argument. He started out by arguing that the Cabinet decision always related to three years. Indeed, he made a mockery of suggestions that it could have related to any period less than three years. Yet he simultaneously went on to argue that Labor members were intent on being the genuinely reforming government which was going to clean up totally the tax system. That does not imply to me that, at the time the decision was taken in December 1986, he had any intention of its being a three-year commitment.

If we look at those two arguments and go back over the history of this issue and some of the evidence that the Prime Minister cited today in defence of his position, we see the extent to which he has selectively represented the position. Let us begin with the first issue: what the December 1986 Cabinet decision actually meant when it was brought down. The most telling feature of that decision is that in the press release there is no reference at all to three years; it simply states:

The Treasurer, Mr Paul Keating, and the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, announced today that the Government had decided not to remove the income tax exemption available to the gold mining industry.

This decision was taken at a time when it was publicly known that Senator Gareth Evans, Senator Walsh and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) did not want to take that decision. After all, there had been an outside inquiry-the Gutman inquiry-that had recommended the abolition of the exemption on the goldmining industry. They had been led to believe that there were substantial revenue benefits from an early decision about this. So it is not surprising, against the background of the known views of those three gentlemen, that there was no explicit commitment about three years in that initial decision.

As we then go through some of the events that the Prime Minister drew attention to today we again find no evidence of a three-year commitment. For example, at the launch of the Australian nugget bullion coin on 23 April in Sydney, to which the Prime Minister referred, he simply referred to that December 1986 decision. He said:
My Government recently decided not to remove the tax exempt status of the gold mining industry.

There was nothing about a forward looking three-year commitment in relation to that exemption. Similarly, at the Australian Mining Industry Council annual dinner speech, to which he referred, there was no explicit recognition of a three year commitment; again the Prime Minister simply referred to the December 1986 decision. I quote:

Let me add that after a review of the taxation arrangements for the gold mining industry, we decided not to remove its current income tax exemption so as to encourage exploration and development and to maximise production and export income.

Again, there is no explicit commitment to three years. As we proceed through the other occasions on which Government Ministers and the Prime Minister made statements about this matter we see that the three-year commitment never emerged until 7 July 1987-some three weeks after this now infamous lunch that took place in Premier Burke's offices in Western Australia. That was the first time when that three-year commitment emerged. Indeed, there is a fair bit of evidence to suggest that the view was to the contrary.

In early June, when the Treasurer was making statements about the first post-election Budget, he said that there would be no new taxes in that Budget, including no gold tax. This was not a three-year commitment but a one-year commitment in the first post-election Budget. The Treasurer was still playing the game on behalf of Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Walsh to contain that decision. They still fully intended to implement that decision at the earliest opportunity.

I guess the Prime Minister has hung most of his case on what transpired in an interview on an Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio program in Perth on the morning of that infamous lunch. The interviewer asked the following question:

If you are re-elected and this is an issue that of course comes up in Western Australia, because, there have been ads in the paper, there has been concern expressed locally, if you are re-elected will there be a gold tax?
Mr Hawke answered:
No.
The interviewer asked:
Categoric assurance, no gold tax?

It is crucial how we read that. The Prime Minister's statement today was that that was an observation. What if it were a rhetorical question? The interviewer asks, `Categoric assurance, no gold tax?'. The Prime Minister does not say, `No, categorically there won't be a gold tax', he repeats the same sort of argument that was used on earlier occasions by himself and the Treasurer in explaining the December 1986 decision. He did not give a categorical no when he was asked that question by the interviewer at that time.

People do not need to take our view as the basis for that judgment. The Australian Mining Industry Council certainly did not believe that there was a firm three-year commitment because it was imposing considerable pressure on the Government and others to explain their position, irrespective of the fact that the Prime Minister had made that statement on the morning of 15 June.

If we want further evidence that there was no decision at that time to make a three-year commitment in relation to the gold tax we can look at two speeches subsequent to the 15 June lunch made by the Treasurer and the former Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans. I think the Treasurer spoke in Perth on 19 June. He simply referred back to the statement made a few days earlier by the Prime Minister. But, again, there was no specific reference to a three-year commitment in relation to that gold tax decision. Senator Gareth Evans actually referred all the way back to December 1987 when, on 18 June in Kalgoorlie, he said:

The Government's decision not to remove the income tax exemption available to the gold mining industry, announced on 16 December 1986, has obviously also been an important contributor to the climate of confidence which the industry now enjoys.

All the way through, whether it was before or after the lunch, there is absolutely no evidence to suggest that the Government had a three-year commitment in mind. Indeed, the evidence given by Laurie Connell under oath in the corruption inquiry begs the question that he was given a commitment, whether the Prime Minister at that lunch on 15 June gave the commitment that was sought by Mr Connell and others at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —No way.
—The Prime Minister makes light of it.
—No, you are making a mess of it.

—He is yet to explain whether that commitment was made at that lunch. Today I asked the Prime Minister whether he had a prior meeting in the anteroom to the luncheon room with Mr Burke and Mr Connell. He failed to answer a very specific question of fact as to whether he attended that meeting, so the onus of proof is still with him, despite a couple of attempts on his part to explain the situation away.

SPEECH.PARA: I put it to the House that up until 7 May there was no specific intention declared publicly by the Government to restrict the application of its decision to the gold mining industry for a period of three years. That letter emerged, surprisingly, on 7 May, just a few days before the election campaign ended on 11 July, but three weeks after the decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —July the seventh.

—I said 7 July, some three weeks after this now notorious lunch at which the matter was clearly discussed, as revealed by the evidence of Laurie Connell under oath. There is a very clear-cut case for the Prime Minister to answer. He needs to give us full details of the meeting prior to the lunch with Laurie Connell and Brian Burke. He needs to give us full details of the meeting prior to the lunch, and whether in fact gold and the gold industry concession were discussed at that lunch. He is yet to answer Mr Connell's specific allegations that a commitment was given to him at that lunch in relation to the application of the gold tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The second part of the argument that the Prime Minister put today, which more likely confirms the view that the Government never had an intention to restrict the application of that decision to three years, was the time he and the Treasurer spent today putting the case for tax reform and the role that they have played in relation to tax reform.

I was left in no doubt, as I listened to the Treasurer speak today, that he had always intended to remove that gold tax exemption as a matter of urgency. If honourable members go back and read the text of his answers today, they will draw the same conclusion: he cannot have it both ways. If he has always wanted to introduce that decision and to remove the gold tax exemption, that is entirely consistent with the view that the Treasurer maintained all the way through to the July 1987 election when he did not refer at any time to the decision relating to three years. Only when the Prime Minister's letter was released on 7 July did anybody know that that sort of commitment had been made.

That raises a second question for the Prime Minister. The other day, when the Treasurer was asked what his recollections of that decision were and whether he had been consulted and so on, he said in this House that whether or not he was aware of the decision was insignificant. Insignificant! He only runs, after all, tax policy in this country. He said it was insignificant, but Senator Walsh left no doubt about it on Friday when he went public and said it was a complete surprise and, I think to quote him accurately, he said both he and the Treasurer were `bloody angry' that that decision had been taken by the Prime Minister. Obviously they had a suspicion as to who had got at Hawke in order to lead him to make that statement on the eve of the election campaign. So we need to have a complete explanation of the precise decision making processes that were entered into in order to arrive at that decision on 7 July. In particular, we need to know what transpired between the lunch on 15 June and that decision on 7 May, particularly when two of the senior relevant Ministers--

TALK.START.PARA: —July the seventh. You have trouble with it, don't you.

—July 7; sorry. There was a gap between 15 June and 7 July, a gap in which the two relevant senior Ministers-Senator Evans and the Treasurer-made speeches not alluding to a three-year commitment. So how was it that the Prime Minister in the end came to the decision that there would be a three-year commitment? When did he consult Senator Walsh? When did he consult the Treasurer? Precisely what other Cabinet processes were adhered to, if any, in order to make that decision? Or was it simply, as the allegations would lead one to believe, the outcome of a deal he had done at the lunch of 15 June or in the meeting prior to the lunch on 15 June, and he had just hung on and finally released the letter publicly, and it came as a complete surprise to his colleagues that that commitment had been made?

SPEECH.PARA: As long as those questions remain unanswered, as long as there is not a complete statement of the processes from December 1986 right through to 7 July and that final decision and, in particular, the decision making processes that took place after the lunch on 15 June, the suggestion that donations were given at that lunch in return for political commitments in relation to that gold tax exemption will continue.

Many Australians believe that those are very reasonable questions, given the record of this Government in deal-doing and its attempt to hang on to power by doing deals rather than governing in the best interests of the people of Australia. It has a sustained history-it is now nearly nine years-of doing deals in the best interests of some sectional or vested interest group and not doing deals in the best interests of the people of Australia. A lot of Australians would take some convincing that yet another of those deals was not done in the course of that 15 June lunch about which the Prime Minister's memory has been so mysteriously impeded.

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot remember the difference between May and July.

—It does not matter what I can remember. I am not on the block. The Prime Minister is on the block and he is the one who has to answer the questions. We are giving him every opportunity to answer the questions.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, the fact remains that the Prime Minister has to provide a complete explanation of exactly what transpired over the period from December 1986 to 7 July at which time he made that announcement, and he needs to tie up the various elements of his explanation to give a consistent story over that period, not the very selective quoting of events either in the House the other evening when he came in to admit that he had misled the House or again in Question Time today when he read selectively from those events of that period to try to make his case look as defensible as he could.

Even in the Parliament last week, for example-just to take one specific example of how he turned around his position-on 10 April he went out of his way to say that he had not decided until 7 July that that decision was to be taken. Then, of course, when confronted with the fact that there were statements on the record about the gold tax that went back to December 1986 and, in particular, when confronted with the fact that the allegation would stand unless he could find some evidence of a three-year commitment prior to that lunch, he came back into the House and manufactured a second explanation, at which time he tried to pin the whole lot on that Australian Broadcasting Corporation morning interview. He had every opportunity in that interview to state quite clearly that it was a three-year commitment.

If he had been keen to put the matter beyond doubt at that time-the questioner in fact gave him the opportunity-he had every opportunity to do so. But when Mr Hawke finally remembered the facts and gave them to the House, he completely--
This is Senator Walsh. The Leader of the Opposition is invoking Senate Walsh against me on this matter. Here is Senator Walsh's statement:

But when Mr Hawke finally remembered the facts and gave them to the House, he completely cleared himself of any suggestion that some sort of a deal was done on the question of gold-tax policy at that lunch unless you believe in the theory of retrospective causation.
If the Leader of the Opposition wishes to invoke Senator Walsh, okay invoke Senator Walsh. There is Senator Walsh's specific repudiation of what he is alleging.

I will come to the question of Cabinet processes in a moment, but before I do that let me again give a comprehensive response on this matter. I go to this snide observation by the Leader of the Opposition that this Government has been about deal-doing generally in its time in office. Those opposite keep referring to the deals that we do with the trade union movement in the accord. I have had cause to say before on a number of occasions in this House that not only are we not ashamed of the dealing that we do with the trade union movement under the accord, but we assert with great pride that, as a result of the fact that we have the capacity to negotiate with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, we have brought about enormous benefits for the people of this country. This is not something that has been done surreptitiously; it is something that we have trumpeted, and properly trumpeted, from the roof tops.

The fact that we have been able to shift the share of national income from wages to profit, the fact that we have been able to get a 1.4 million increase in jobs, the fact that we have a 10 per cent reduction in real non-farm unit labour costs-all of these have come out of what the Opposition is pleased to call dealing with the trade union movement, but they in fact represent the massive change from the contempt with which the Opposition held the organised working men and women of this country. Where the Opposition wanted confrontation, yes, we did want to deal with them, and we have done so in a way which has brought enduring benefits to this country.

In the time which remains I will again put in total context the issues that have been raised so inadequately by the Leader of the Opposition. I want in particular to provide the full context in which the Government made its decision not to remove the tax exemption from the goldmining industry. This detailed sequence will prove two points of fundamental importance: first, the decision to retain the exemption on gold was not made as a result of or to attract any political donation from Mr Connell or anyone else, as I have said. There is no evidence whatsoever to support any contention that it was so made. Any claim that Mr Connell influenced the decision with a political donation made at the luncheon I attended is wrong for the manifestly persuasive reason that the decision had been made and announced before that luncheon was held. As I have consistently stated, there was no private commitment by me or by the Government to Mr Connell or to anyone else on this issue.

The second fundamental fact to emerge from the detailed sequence of events is that it presents neither side of politics in a particularly flattering light. The truth is that both the Government and the Opposition decided, despite rational economic arguments to the contrary, to maintain the gold tax exemption. The Opposition today voicing its criticisms is the same Opposition that in 1986-87 was not only in the same policy boat as the Government but also had led the way there in a headlong rush. It was the then Opposition, led by its leading Western Australians, as my friend the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has pointed out-Senator Durack and Senator Chaney-who conducted a relentless campaign against the gold tax. It was the then Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who first succumbed to the pressure from the goldmining industry to provide a written guarantee that he would not introduce such a tax.

I have no doubt that significant gold interests were making financial contributions to the coalition. By his own testimony, Mr Connell had been an undisclosed donor to the Liberal Party of Australia. My point is to highlight the enormous capacity of a well-funded single issue group such as the goldmining industry to exert political pressure on politicians and parties. It gives me no great joy to reflect on the way in which the goldmining industry ruthlessly conducted a campaign of self-interest and on the way in which the Opposition, exploiting that campaign, adopted a no-tax policy purely in order to create for the Government a political problem that impelled us to match that policy. It is my fervent belief that the publicity now being given to these events strongly underlines the need for full public disclosure of public donations in the future and for an end to the crazy spiral of television advertising costs. This Parliament will shortly have the opportunity to consider those issues.

In June 1985 the draft White Paper on tax reform proposed that the income tax exemption on the goldmining industry be removed. On 19 September, the Treasurer announced the establishment of the independent inquiry to examine the issue and to be conducted by Mr Gutman. That independent inquiry, the Inquiry into the Taxation of Gold Mining, reported to the Government on 29 August 1986, recommending that the exemption be removed. On 16 December 1986 Cabinet decided not to accept this recommendation and the decision was announced by the Treasurer and the then Minister for Resources, Senator Gareth Evans, later that day. As I have said, on 23 April 1987, in a speech in Sydney at the launch of the Australian nugget bullion coin, I referred to the Government's decision not to remove the tax exempt status of the goldmining industry. It is a theme to which I returned a fortnight later on 7 May at the annual dinner of the Australian Mining Industry Council (AMIC). As I have said, there was no ambiguity about my words, which were:
Let me add that after a review of the taxation arrangements for the gold mining industry we decided not to remove its current income tax exemption.

Less than three weeks later, on 27 May, I announced that a general election would be held on 11 July 1987. The Treasurer, Mr Keating, also made it plain on 30 May that the Government was not considering a gold tax. He was reported in the Canberra Times as saying that a gold tax had been considered, that the decision had been made and that:
. . . it's off the agenda.

That was reiterated on 4 June in the media statement to which I earlier referred in my answers in this place, but in this context it should be put down again. He said that the Government had rejected outright the Gutman recommendation. The statement from his office continued:
Having made that decision, the Government has before it no proposals to change the tax treatment of the gold mining industry, nor does it have any intention of considering any proposals.

That was from the Treasurer's office on 4 June. As I said earlier, from that chronology it should be quite plain that-with an election at most only months away, I remind honourable members-the Government's policy against the introduction of a gold tax was firmly established and was widely publicised. The viewpoint of the Opposition was clear: right from the start the coalition was adamant that there would be no gold tax. Senator Durack, then the coalition spokesman, issued a press release on 15 June 1985, in which he called on the Government:
. . . to abandon the White Paper proposal to tax gold.

Between then and the 1987 election, Senator Durack issued no less than 12 press releases arguing various aspects of the anti-gold tax case. Senator Chaney, his colleague from Western Australia, also chimed in. On 10 October 1986 the Treasurer said that the Government would be lunatic to consider changing the tax exemption of gold, and he pledged in that statement the repeal of any Labor decision to impose a tax.

In political terms it was very much in the Opposition's interests to run this campaign. In so doing, the coalition parties were joined by the Western Australian State Government and other State governments. There was also a strident, energetic and tireless campaign by the goldmining industry itself. While the Government was considering the Gutman inquiry, for example, Mr Duncan Bell, the Executive Director of the Australian Mining Industry Council, made public an estimate of a $500m loss of investment throughout Australia and a further $100m reduction in exploration expenditure if a gold tax were introduced. In other words, it is quite clear that the issue of a gold tax was a highly political issue. Notwithstanding Cabinet's no-tax decision of December 1986 and the subsequent statement by me and other Government spokesmen, the crescendo of the anti-tax campaign continued to increase. For example, on 8 June 1987, four days after the release from the Treasurer's office, the Australian goldmining industry called for a written commitment from political parties not to introduce the gold tax during the next Federal Parliament.

Last Thursday I apologised-as I should have-to the House for the inaccuracy of my initial recollections as to the sequence of events surrounding this decision; but since that matter first came to my attention last week I have thoroughly examined the circumstances in the public record. It is clear that by the first part of 1987-certainly by May 1987-I had formulated in my mind the decision, if re-elected, not to impose a gold tax for the entirety of my next term of office. The reasons for this can be easily deduced. As the pressures normally associated with a pre-election period began to build, the decision had to be made on whether to let the Government's electoral position be eroded by the campaign of the Opposition and the goldmining industry or whether, by applying the December Cabinet decision to Labor's next term, we could neutralise that vociferous campaign.

As I said earlier, in those circumstances it was inevitable that the no-tax decision of the Cabinet in December would not only stand but would have to apply to Labor's next term in office. As I said before-and it only has to be said to be abundantly clear-in political terms it was meaningless unless it applied to the three years of our re-elected government period. As 1987 wore on, it became increasingly relevant to relate that decision to post-election matters, as the Treasurer did on 30 May in reference to our intentions if re-elected for Labor's 1987 Budget.

I referred to my address in May 1987 to the Mining Industry Council. In that speech, as I have said, I referred to the December Cabinet decision. On the eve of an election campaign, the reference only made sense as applied to the next term of a re-elected Labor government. What sense would it make if I were to say, `We won't do it in the first month, but you had better watch out in the second month or the third month because then we will do it'. (Extension of time granted)
Obviously, in that pre-election situation, the reference to not imposing the tax only made sense. It was politically irrelevant if it was not made for the period of the next Labor government.

As I said, the question was put to me explicitly when I was interviewed on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio in Perth on the morning of 15 June. The answer I gave then was an unequivocal statement that a re-elected Labor government would not introduce a gold tax. The answer was obviously intended to apply to the whole of Labor's term. As I have already said-I pointed this out in referring to the Australian Financial Review of 16 June-there is no doubt what the interpretation was. I will repeat it. Under the headline `No gold or consumption tax: Hawke', the article stated:
The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, gave an unequivocal guarantee yesterday . . .
He pledged that there would be no gold tax under a Hawke Government.

There you have it. I made it clear. The media understood exactly what was involved because they knew. I knew that one could not make such a statement with any political content or meaning unless it applied to the three years. It is against this background that the luncheon of 15 June 1987 must be seen. As I said, by the time the luncheon was held the decision not to introduce a gold tax had already been made and had already been announced.

The burden of my comments at the lunch dealt with the general record and achievements of my Government and, as I put it, the hopeless inadequacy of the alternative. As I told the Parliament last week, and as I have said again today, Mr Burke told me that he intended at the luncheon to seek financial support for the Federal ALP. But, as I have said, to the best of my recollection, there was no discussion of political donations while I was present-and, indeed, so the evidence confirms.

I have made the point that there is every possibility that the gold tax issue was discussed at the luncheon. It would have been surprising, given its prominence as an issue, had it not been discussed. As I have said, I cannot be dogmatic about every detail of that luncheon. I just make the point in regard to things going back some time that it is rather interesting to note that it was Malcolm Fraser who said in this House on 22 September 1981:

I do not believe that any honourable member of this House would want to be condemned . . . wholly and solely on the basis of one person's recollections of a conversation five years ago, especially when those recollections are unconfirmed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you calling him a liar?

—Not in that regard, I did not. The honourable member knows very well what that was about. I repeat, because it is appropriate that I should, and reassert fundamentally this important point: I gave no private commitment on this matter and I could not have given any such private commitment. I would not have said anything beyond what I had already said publicly. In his testimony to the Royal Commission, Mr Connell said at one point:

SPEECH.PARA: I would have felt that a contribution-
that is a donation to the ALP-
should have been made regardless of the gold tax issue.
At another point he said that his contribution was:
certainly influencing the decision that a gold tax wouldn't be introduced.
But, whatever he believed to be the case, the public record makes clear that no private commitment was made to him.

I put it this way: Mr Connell may have spent $250,000 in the belief that he would hear new policy commitments from the Government. But it cost listeners to the ABC radio that morning only their 8c a day to hear me articulate my Government's policy on this issue.

I now turn to the question of the written guarantee provided to the goldmining industry-first by the Opposition on 20 June and then by the Government on 7 July-outlining both parties' commitment not to introduce a gold tax in their next term of office. I note that the Opposition's letter followed by four days a report in the Australian Financial Review of a meeting between the then Leader of the Opposition and Mr Alan Bond. Whatever the upshot of that meeting, my office was in no doubt that, in the absence of a similar written commitment from the Government, a campaign would be waged against us in the last days of the election. We were left with little choice but to match the Opposition's written commitment. The Government had resisted putting the undertaking in writing for the very obvious reason, as I have said, that it would have encouraged every pressure group to seek similar written guarantees in the future.

The decision to write the letter was taken by me, in consultation with the Treasurer, on 7 July 1987, the day the written commitment was made. In my letter addressed to Mr Duncan Bell I said that there appeared `to be an element of uncertainty' among members of his Council concerning the tax exemption `despite my public statements on the matter'. That is what I wrote to him.

Last Saturday several newspapers suggested that that decision was made without regard to proper process. Let me make it clear that there was no question of Cabinet or senior Ministers as such being involved in the 7 July decision. The caretaker convention in this country is that no major decisions are taken by a Federal government between the dissolution of Parliament and the time the election result becomes clear. Of course, exceptions clearly apply in the case of a national disaster. But, during an election campaign, a Prime Minister normally speaks on behalf of his party as he is not in a position to commit the incoming government.

Hence my letter of 7 July gave an undertaking not to introduce a gold tax `during the next three year term of the Labor Government'; likewise, the Opposition Leader's letter of 26 June 1987 specifically related to `the next Liberal government'-such undertakings, under the Constitution, relating to three-year terms. Such undertakings are party commitments. During election campaigns they can be made by the leader alone or in consultation with whoever he considers appropriate. Cabinet as an organ of government simply does not enter the equation during an election campaign period.

The Government's decision on 16 May 1988 to introduce a gold tax from 1 January 1991 was taken in full knowledge that, had we left the issue until after the following election, we would have faced a rerun of 1987. As it was, this Government once again demonstrated its capacity to bite the bullet and to introduce a gold tax-something which no Australian government from 1924 had had the courage to do.

I have sought to outline in close detail today all the matters relevant to this issue. The information I have provided fully answers the allegations made in Perth and in this House regarding the Government's decision on the gold tax. Only this remains to be said: much of what has been insinuated by the Opposition has sought to question my personal integrity and reputation and to impugn my conduct as the Prime Minister of this nation. If the Opposition wishes to go further down that path and to suggest seriously that I corrupted myself to acquire party political donations, the onus is on it now to say so clearly. But it will not do so because it cannot. That is because nothing has emerged to erode or diminish the fundamental point that I have made throughout: the Government's policies are not for sale. No-one has bought Government policy through providing donations to the ALP. As I have stated to this House consistently throughout recent days, the fact is that no-one buys favours from this Government. The critically important standard that I have asserted for myself and for my Government-that our policies cannot be secured by the provision of financial support-remains inviolate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Prime Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We all know that we have a populist and scheming Prime Minister. The question is: how populist and how scheming? I support and second this motion. It is the Opposition's contention today that we have not had a clear and precise explanation from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as to his involvement in the change in the Australian Labor Party's gold tax policy in the 1987 election. Today in Question Time we had a mere four questions able to be put to the Government from the Opposition and, I must say, a failure on the Prime Minister's part to answer many of the propositions put to him. I simply say that there is a cloud hanging over this Prime Minister and he has a duty to come into this Parliament and to answer all of the questions, all of the issues, which have been raised by the Opposition about his conduct.

SPEECH.PARA: Even last weekend the Prime Minister acknowledged that he was prepared to answer questions on this issue in front of the Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters. Why is he not prepared to come in and answer the questions that the Opposition has put to him? The Prime Minister's principal argument, as it appears to have been put to us today, is that his Government's policy on the gold tax was consistent the whole way through. He started back in December 1986 with a press release by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the then Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans. It is instructive to go back to December 1986 to see the Government's policy position at that time. I say that because it is of the essence of our proposition that basically this position did not change until 7 July, which then itself raises the question as to why the change was made in the first place. But back on 16 December 1986 we had this short two-paragraph press statement:

The Treasurer, Mr Paul Keating, and the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, announced today that the Government had decided not to remove the income tax exemption available to the gold mining industry.

After considering the report of the ``Inquiry into the Taxation of Gold Mining'' conducted by Mr G O Gutman, and other relevant submissions, the Government had concluded that the importance of encouraging active exploration and development, and of maximising production and the consequent export income generated by the gold mining industry, outweighed the arguments in favour of removing the industry's long-standing tax exemption.

I read it all so that no-one can be in any doubt about a simple fact. Nowhere in that two-paragraph statement is there a commitment for the full three-year term of any preceding Labor government. To advance his argument the Prime Minister relies upon, firstly, his own statement in April 1987 at the launch of the Australian nugget bullion coin in Sydney. Very simply, he said:
My Government recently decided not to remove the tax exempt status of the gold mining industry.

That was the statement. Where was the claim that that would run for a three-year period under an incoming government? Secondly, he relies upon a statement he gave on 7 May to the Australian Mining Industry Council. Again, it is instructive to see what the Prime Minister actually said-not for the content of it, but for its omission on the critical point as to Labor's intentions to introduce a gold tax. He said:

Let me add that after a review of the taxation arrangements for the gold mining industry, we decided not to remove its current income tax exemption so as to encourage exploration and development and to maximise production and export income.
In a radio interview in June, the critical radio interview that the Prime Minister rests his case upon, he was asked:
. . . if you are re-elected will there be a gold tax?
His answer was no. The interviewer said:
Categoric assurance, no gold tax?

The Prime Minister then proceeded to debate the point. Very simply, there was no clear unequivocal statement from the Prime Minister as to the Government's longer term intentions. Finally, he relies on a speech from the Treasurer on 19 June and attempts to ascribe to that speech exactly the same interpretation, that is, that there was a consistent position not to introduce a gold tax for a period of three years. If we read the speech we see there was no mention again of any three-year blanket intention not to introduce a gold tax.

Essentially, the Prime Minister says that his policy was a status quo policy; in other words, that it was always open to an interpretation which he now seeks to place upon it, which is that Labor would not, during a three-year term, introduce a gold tax. I find that argument very unconvincing. In my remarks today I simply want to state why I believe those remarks are unconvincing. Essentially, my argument comes down to seven fairly simple points.

Why has the Prime Minister changed policy? Was it for the political pressure which he claims or was it for other reasons for which he has a responsibility to now dispel doubts which are raised by his conduct? First of all, I thought it was very revealing that the Government's organised defence for Question Time today was that it had fewer hands on the gold tax issue and the only reason it did not change its policy was that it was being terrorised by the Opposition. That reveals that the Government has always wanted to introduce a gold tax. It was publicly touted that this Government had taken a political decision before the election because it was worried about the votes, and that it would introduce such a tax after the election. The Treasurer's remarks today absolutely confirm that. Of course, as we all know now, eventually Labor did introduce a gold tax. This is further confirmation of its true position.

Secondly, we have the evidence of the then Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh. His evidence, I believe, is damning evidence about the Government's real intentions and motives on this issue. His essential allegation has not been refuted by his subsequent remarks. Let me read it to the Treasurer and hear his refutation when he stands. The Australian of 12 April stated:
Senator Walsh said he and Mr Keating had expected to introduce a tax in the following term . . .
That is what they were up to: `Tell them we're not going to introduce it; keep mum about the tax policy and we'll introduce it in the next term'. The article went on to say:
While Mr Keating said publicly in May 1987 he did not plan to introduce a gold tax in his next Budget, he made no commitments covering the full term, according to newspaper files.
Let me read what Senator Walsh actually said. He is quoted as having said:
The first thing I remember, which was a complete surprise to me, was when those advertisements were published.
It was a complete surprise to him. He was second after the Treasurer responsible for revenue for the Commonwealth and he knew nothing about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is not responsible for revenue.
—We will hear the Treasurer tip a bucket on him when I sit down. Senator Walsh said:

SPEECH.PARA: It was news to me-I certainly hadn't been consulted about it or even told and I believe the same was true of Paul Keating.
They had had a chat about it. The article continued:
We'd made no decision to do it (introduce a tax) so I guess you could argue Hawke wasn't obliged to get any Cabinet agreement.
That was the rationalisation for the subsequent position.
The article continued:
. . . there was certainly an intention to introduce it, certainly as far as I was concerned and I believe the same is true for Keating.
This is the final quote:
We (he and the Treasurer) were pretty bloody angry when that (the advertisements) appeared.

That is the second reason why I believe there was a change in government policy. It is another significant fact. Thirdly, let me refer to the Treasurer's remarks. Only a week before the relevant lunch, on 9 June, the Sydney Morning Herald contained a quote from a spokesman for the Treasurer. The article stated:

``We've already looked at gold tax and said there won't be one,'' he said. ``We'll wait until we receive the request and look at it, but if we made any written undertaking there would be 500 on our doorstep-it's an impractical request because they would never end.''

Just a week before the relevant lunch the Treasurer's office was simply dismissing out of hand any proposition that there might be a written guarantee given to the goldmining industry as a response to its requests.

As the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) said, when the Treasurer was asked last week what he knew about the 7 July statement, he said it was insignificant. Why did he say that? He said it because he was going on the attack, which is his best form of defence. I question whether he was ever consulted. If he was consulted, we have also been told that members of his staff at officer level were involved. That is another question yet to be answered.

As a fourth basis for my proposition, I go to the remarks of Mr Gutman, whose views on this matter were sought back in 1987, during the election, and which were probably significant in promoting the public debate about whether or not there would be a gold tax. He said a lot when he was quoted as follows in the Age of 29 May 1987:
``The reason that the Government turned down the recommendations of my report was presumably because they were not the sort of things that could be introduced before an election''.

In other words, this was a clear statement that Labor's real intent was to keep mum on this issue until after the election and then go for the gold tax. Furthermore, Gutman's point made over the weekend was also very damning about the processes involved in Labor's decision. In his original report to the Government, Gutman said, `If you go ahead with it the one thing you don't do is give people two or three years notice of the intention to change'. The figure he has quoted in the weekend press as to revenue forgone is something like $1 billion. If it were the case, as the Treasurer alleges, that he had a consistent position all along, why is it that Gutman was able to say that, and the Government acted so as to provide a windfall benefit to the goldmining industry?

My fifth point is one that Senator Walsh made when he said that there was no political pressure on the Government to give this undertaking-a point acknowledged by the Treasurer when he dismissed that request earlier in June. A few days before the 7 July undertaking by the Prime Minister-people forget history, but if they want to know whether or not the Government was under a lot of pressure in the July 1987 election they should look at the polls in the Australian of 4 July-we were behind in the Newspoll, the McNair poll, the Saulwick poll, the Morgan Gallup poll, another Newspoll and the Reark poll. Unfortunately, we were not ahead in one poll. Where was the political pressure if that political pressure is the explanation for Labor's change of mind on the gold tax policy?

My sixth point-and I challenge the Treasurer to answer this when he stands-is to ask where it is stated on the public record that anybody in his Government, either he or the Prime Minister, had given a commitment for the full three-year period of an incoming Labor government. He should tell us where it is. It is not in his speech of 19 June, it is not in the Prime Minister's interview on the radio in June, it is not in the Prime Minister's speech at the launch of the Australian nugget bullion coin on 23 April, and it is certainly not in the Prime Minister's speech of 7 May 1987.

Finally, I say that the Prime Minister's recollections of these matters are unsatisfactory because I find all his responses very selective. He says that he remembers that he gave no commitment as to Labor's gold tax policy-in fact, he is not even sure whether they discussed the gold tax policy, so he is very doubtful there-but when it comes to his actual position he is as clear as a bell. He cannot even remember whether he met Laurie Connell before lunch or not.

The truth of the matter is that we raised this matter because there are many questions still to be answered. What were the consultations with the Treasurer on 7 July? Who else was involved? Who else did the Prime Minister meet before lunch on 15 June? What were the discussions at that lunch in regard to politics? Did the Treasurer or the Prime Minister consult with the then Deputy Prime Minister, Bowen?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard two very weak speeches from members of the Opposition. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) was flat out making the 15 minutes and was repeating himself throughout. During the speech of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith), I started to take notes; I got down to about two points on the first page, and that was the end of the substance of his speech.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact of the matter is that the Opposition has gone nowhere on this matter. Today those opposite have completely run out of puff and have been shown for what they are. They are trying to besmirch the integrity of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on this issue when he has been prepared to tax the income from goldmining companies. The only problem the Prime Minister has had was his faulty recollection last week and the fact that he had to change a statement in Parliament. The allegations have been shown to have no substance at all.

Dr Hewson-`the Professor'-said today that the Prime Minister had selectively misrepresented the Cabinet decisions of 1986. He said that there was no reference to `three years' and that Keating and Evans did not want to take part in that position. In fact, Evans and I announced it. He went on to talk about the radio interview in Perth and said that there was no categoric reference. The question by Diana Warnock was:
If you are re-elected will there be a gold tax?

The answer from Hawke was no. The claim is that he should then have said, `Oh, not for the next three years'. What a lot of codswallop! At that stage the Howard letter had not appeared; the Howard letter appeared 11 days after that. The Prime Minister was not responding to any written commitment from the Opposition at that time. He was not responding to the specific three-year commitment by Mr Howard at that time. The notion that, because he did not refer to it, in some way he is being tricky is simply dishonesty. Then Dr Hewson said--

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Treasurer to refer to the Leader of the Opposition by his correct title.

—The Leader of the Opposition said that until 7 July there had been no public intention to restrict it to three years. Then he said, `Then it surprisingly emerged on 7 July'. In terms of any written commitments, the three-year issue has been a formula used by both parties on a number of occasions. We used it in 1983-and kept to it-in relation to the capital gains tax. After that, we could have been defeated at a poll. Honourable members should remember that there was a 1990 election. If the public did not like the 1988 gold taxing arrangements, they could have turfed us out in 1990-remember? But they did not. That was the point of three years, which those opposite dishonestly know. Then we have the other dishonest claim by the Leader of the Opposition that I said last week that the issue was insignificant. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: Whether . . . the letter was written or not is insignificant, because the point was made by the Prime Minister and by me that we would not be legislating in the course of that Parliament.
I said:
The letter would have given only written confirmation of things that the Prime Minister had said orally to the industry.
There was another attempt to take that word `insignificant' out of context.

But the real questions are: why did those opposite vote against the Bills in 1988? Why did Mr Howard write the letter in the first place? What did Mr Howard want from Mr Bond when he saw him? And what did Mr Bond want from Mr Howard in the course of that exchange? The Leader of the Opposition said, `I am not on the block'. He said to the Prime Minister, `You are on the block'. An article written by Peter Rees in the West Australian on 14 October 1989 makes interesting reading. It says:
When the Hawke Government announced its plan in May last year to tax gold from January 1, 1991, Mr Howard told his shadow cabinet there was no alternative but to go along with the policy.
That night Andrew Peacock, then shadow treasurer, took the same line on television.
But by October last year-
that is, in 1988-
new factors were at work and a process to reverse this commitment had begun with the WA Liberal Party leading the way.
In hindsight, it coincided with the emergence of the campaign against Mr Howard.
In a speech in New York in early October last year, Mr Howard made it clear he supported the tax.

A month later, as the internal pressure against the tax mounted, he became more equivocal, saying he did not have a closed mind on the matter. The strongly held views of the WA Liberals on the issue played a part in influencing Mr Peacock to reverse his position.
His submission opposing it was ultimately supported by shadow cabinet.
It left the coalition parties in the questionable position of opposing the Government's tax while not having a policy of their own.
It went on to say:
Among the shadow ministers backing Andrew Peacock were Fred Chaney, Wilson Tuckey and Peter Shack-all of whom were to play crucial roles in organising the coup against John Howard in May . . .

There are conflicting versions about the shadow cabinet debate on the gold tax which ensued but one Liberal who was present says Senator Chaney made the point that everyone around the table had a `distortion' which suited them politically and this was his.

Another Liberal said yesterday, `If Chaney and Peacock had taken the position last year that they have now ultimately taken, it would have made things a lot easier for Mr Howard'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The scatter-gun attack of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was a very weak form of defence. Today the Treasurer has come in here and said that the coalition has made Government members' lives a misery because of a number of reforms. The Treasurer is wrong.
