If the Opposition had wanted to be irresponsible on that issue, it could have had 5,000 pensioners outside this Parliament every sitting day of this week. We chose not to do that; we chose to take a very responsible action with regard to deeming. That is the complete opposite to what this Treasurer did many years ago when the then Senator Chaney drew up the original proposal on pensioner deeming. It ill becomes the Treasurer to come into this House and say that we have constantly been irresponsible when he has brought forward reforms. The Treasurer made a shabby speech here this afternoon. The fundamental mistake that he makes is to think that the acceptable standard of living and code of conduct on his side of the House are automatically the same as those on our side of the House. I have news for the Treasurer: that is not so. It ill becomes him to judge us by his criteria.

SPEECH.PARA: The motion before the House is simple enough; it is to call upon the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to come back into the Parliament and give a dispassionate, constructive, comprehensive and accurate account of all that happened in relation to the gold tax and the lifting of the gold tax exemption, in relation to all of the meetings and the evidence so far given in the Western Australian Royal Commission, and in relation to his credibility with the Australian people. It is now or never as far as the Prime Minister's credibility and integrity are concerned.

We have afforded the Prime Minister the opportunity to come back to the dispatch box, not in the context of an emotional debate-he tried to rip through his speech this afternoon as more evidence was coming out of Perth-but rather in a very direct way, in a more proper response to what we quite rightly put to him. It is in this context that I draw the attention of the House to evidence given later this day to the inquiry. Mr Connell was asked-and I quote in part:
I put it to you there was no mention at the lunch of the gold tax?
Mr Connell replied:
I would reject it completely.
The evidence continued:
You say it was discussed at the lunch?
Connell: Yes.
Who raised it?
Connell: I don't recall.
Did you speak about it at the lunch?
Connell: I am sure that I did, yes.
Did the Premier raise it?
Connell: I don't recall.
Did the Prime Minister?

Connell: Yes, I believe he did. He was able to confirm that the gold tax would not be introduced and that was of considerable interest to me, my company Paragon Resources, and the companies of Alan Bond.

There is more to come. Perhaps now we should draw back and look at the background to the Royal Commission. We should look at why it took the Western Australian State Government so many months even to decide on proceeding with the Royal Commission when that much was an open and shut case. It took the Premier's own brother to bring a lot of pressure to bear and a major campaign around the State of Western Australia and the city of Perth just to convince the West Australian Labor Government to have the Royal Commission so that this evidence could be brought out. Now we know why there was so much reluctance, hesitation and delay. I say again: there is more to come. What we want, what we need and what this Parliament and the nation are entitled to is a comprehensive response from the Prime Minister-not the response we had here this afternoon.

I now to turn to the National Times on Sunday newspaper. The Prime Minister is fond of quoting from it in his Question Time answers. I refer to an editorial of 12 October 1986 by Robert Haupt. Under the heading, `Tell us how many pieces of gold, Bob', the article states:

Today's industry, therefore, has been reborn, often on the sites of defunct mines. It is an industry of venture capital, a small work force, new technology and high returns-get-rich-quick in the best traditions of the Gold Rush.

as it did from 1986 to the 1st January 1991. No other Labor politician . . . better understands the needs of these operators than West Australian Premier Brian Burke. After all, what is the point in being in a get-rich-quick industry if you don't get rich? Rich people support Burke's John Curtin Foundation (a fund that bears more than a passing resemblance . . .
to other foundations-
Rich people supported Burke's re-election campaign this year, modestly estimated to have cost $4m.

None of this shows up on the replay. Nor will you find there an answer to the question first raised after Burke persuaded Hawke to back off on Aboriginal control over mining: just how much will Brian Burke contribute to Bob Hawke's re-election campaign? But it is worth asking now, and it will be asked often if gold mining remains tax free.

Goldmining remained tax free from 1986 to 1 January 1991. There is another dimension by way of background to this whole issue which, as shadow Minister for energy and resources, I focus on strongly; that is, the Gutman report. This report went to the Treasurer and gave him a warning many years ago, back in 1986-87, that if he were going to proceed down the track of removing the exemption from gold tax then he should do so with no phase-in and a relative degree of speed between the announcement and the cut-in to avoid the high grading mining operation being conducted by mining companies. This is not necessarily in the best interests of the longer term life of the mine or in the best national interest, but one that is difficult to assess and which had to be done on a mine by mine basis.

To date in this debate the Gutman report has not been mentioned. I inject a mention of that report into these proceedings because it was a very significant report. It pointed to the correct strategy should the Government be of a mind to introduce a gold tax or remove the exemption from tax on gold. It gave the Treasurer the correct blueprint by which to proceed. What happened? The Treasurer privately accepted the thrust of the Gutman report. The Treasurer and Senator Walsh-in his confirmed comments last week-said, `Yes, we have two agendas operating-the public agenda for the immediate election campaign, which, simply stated, is that there will be no gold tax, and the private agenda'. What was in the private agenda? To pick up the Gutman report and in the early phase of the next parliamentary term, after the 1987 elections, to remove the gold tax exemption in the first Budget by 1 January 1988 or 1 July 1989 in the middle of the bicentennial year, an early date-not on 1 January 1991.

The two agendas were there. Senator Walsh has confirmed that there were two agendas. The Government has failed to conclusively prove that there were not two agendas. What happened? To quote Senator Walsh, `Somebody was got at'. Suddenly, we had the upgrading of that simple statement, `No gold tax', to the following statement of the Prime Minister:
You have my undertaking we will not introduce a gold tax during the next three-year term of the Labor Government.

That represented a totally different dimension; a much more serious, significant and precise commitment in relation to the timing of the gold tax. It is this twist which has caused concern. This substantial upgrading of the commitment has meant millions of dollars to goldmining company after goldmining company. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer have not addressed this aspect in debate this afternoon. They should come back and do so in the context of this motion.

The sooner they come back and clear the air in a far more fundamental way and open up their files and diary notes to the Parliament-it is the Prime Minister's first responsibility to do that-the sooner the Parliament can focus on the other critical issues of hurt affecting the rural economy, youth unemployment, transitions in key industries and the overall economic recession as we approach an economic winter of absolute discontent.

It is time for the Prime Minister to come forward and give comprehensive answers before the stench envelopes him, the New South Wales parliamentary Labor Party, the New South Wales State division of the Labor Party, the South Australian division of the Labor Party, the Western Australian division of the Labor Party and, indeed, the Federal parliamentary Labor Party-in respect of information on where the money flowed across Australia from the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow in Perth.

It is in this context that I focus briefly on Brian Burke. He is a key player in the whole equation. He was the host at the famous luncheon. He was present, seemingly, at the special troika meeting between the Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, Laurie Connell and the Premier Brian Burke prior to the luncheon. In fact, there was only one reason why Brian Burke was sent off to Ireland. It was because the Labor Party knew that the material now coming out would surface. It wanted Brian Burke as far away as possible from Perth. The Labor Party hoped it would wriggle through without a royal commission and that, therefore, Burke would be bypassed by the media and all the others involved. The people who saw to it were his mates.

That might be fine for the Labor Party but for the Australian people it means that, even as I speak, our formal representative to Ireland and the Holy See cannot give those demanding positions his full attention. That seems okay with the relevant Minister and the Prime Minister. I say that it is not okay by me; it is not okay by the shadow Minister for foreign affairs; it is not okay by the Liberal-National Party Opposition; and it is not okay by the vast majority of Australians, that Brian Burke has not been stood aside.

Many senior diplomats representing Australia will feel acutely embarrassed by this decision. However, at the end of the day it comes back to the Prime Minister. It is the Prime Minister who, by his own conduct and the standards he sets within the Government, determines wider standards of conduct throughout the nation. The Labor Party has to come to grips with the fact that it is no longer just dealing with matters concerning its own Party, the factions within its own Party and all the other elements that might be involved.

Deals which constantly pass for informed debate within the Labor Party are totally inadequate in terms of the proper decision making of this Government and the decision to greatly upgrade the no gold tax promise to no gold tax within three specific years, which meant millions of dollars for so many gold companies. I remind the Government that it is here to govern the country; it is here to look after the national interest in a proper way. It needs to lift itself out of this backroom politicking which has too often been a feature of the parliamentary Labor Party way of government. It is for that reason that the Prime Minister should be back at the dispatch box, and that Senator Walsh and the Treasurer should sort out their alibis because there is still a massive conflict between what each of them is saying. The truth must out on that, and I serve a warning to the Government: the truth will out at the expense of one or the other, and hopefully sooner rather than later, as I said before, so that Parliament can get on with other business with which it must deal as a matter of priority.

This is an extraordinarily serious affair, made slightly lighter by the famous fishing trip to Geraldton and the fact that when a television crew lobbed up there-it is now a matter of record-so concerned were certain Ministers and others with the prime ministerial party that they went around to the operator of the only other charter boat in town. He was charging about $1,000 a day. An approach was made late at night to the family concerned, the only other boat operator, to stay off the water for the fee for a three-day charter-$3,000. They are the words of the journalist who took the trip up there to check on the fishing trip and to attend the Norcape Lodge and proceed with the business. He arrived at a time which was clearly very awkward for those involved.

The Prime Minister does have a case to answer. It is in the interests of the nation and in his own interests that he comprehensively clarify the situation, the saga, and all aspects relating to that saga. The sooner he does it-because he failed to do it this afternoon-the better for the Government and the nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has managed to reduce this debate to complete tedium. That was not to be unexpected, but it certainly was out of sorts with what it promised us over the weekend. We even had the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) going into a radio station earlier this morning and saying that he would be coming in here to tear the guts out of the Government; that the Opposition would be up here to tear the guts out of the Government. We had one question from the honourable member for O'Connor and all it did, as is usual with regard to the honourable member for O'Connor and as was amply pointed out by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), was simply peddle lies in this place, and the question was dealt with as containing peddled lies.

SPEECH.PARA: But the Opposition comes to one central point in this, and it has been amply answered by the Prime Minister. As far as policy making is concerned, the Opposition, to rest its case, has to sustain an absurd position. The position is this: when an election campaign is under way and the Opposition says something, what it is in fact saying goes for about the first two or three months after the election campaign or perhaps the first Budget, but has no meaning in the subsequent years. Does the Opposition seriously mean to say that if we stood up in an election campaign and said that we will introduce no capital gains tax or we will introduce no gold tax, irrespective of whether or not we say it is going to be for three years or whatever, and it is not challenged, and then we subsequently go to the election and a year or two down the line we put up a gold tax, the Opposition would come into this place and say, `The Government is absolved from lying to the electorate.'?

Does the Opposition seriously mean to say that it would come into this place and say, `Look, you did say in the election campaign that you would introduce no gold tax. You did say that, but it is now 18 months on from the election campaign. So now that you have introduced the gold tax, we do not think you are liars; we do not think you lack credibility; we do not think you have gone to the people on a false premise or false promise. Oh, no. We the Opposition accept absolutely your bona fides. We accept absolutely that if you wish to do that, you may, without criticism from us, because as far as we are concerned, promises in election campaigns last six months after the election campaign.'?

This is an interesting element of psychological projection on the part of the Opposition. We now have a fairly clear idea of what it thinks about promises it gives in undertakings when it goes to the electorate. As far as it is concerned, when it goes to the electorate, whatever it says lasts somewhere around six months after that election and from that point on its interpretation of democracy is that it has nothing more to say to the population. What an absolute nonsense proposition it is that is put forward by the Opposition.

If we were here, as I said, in another context, a context of having reversed the policy that we announced during the course of the election campaign and re-announced during the course of the election campaign, the situation might be different. The Prime Minister was in the course of the election campaign when he was being questioned by Diana Warnock, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was in the course of the campaign when he was quizzed a couple of weeks before that, and in fact the Prime Minister was, in effect, in the course of the election campaign back on 7 May when he made the statement about gold taxes. We were not making statements about the next Budget, the next six months or whatever; we were making a simple statement about what our intentions were, were we to be re-elected to government.

The Opposition has gone around and around the garden like a teddy bear on this blinking subject, but as far as it is concerned it cannot establish a single sensible point about it. On that hook swings all its arguments and on that hook swings the entire Opposition. Its position in this matter, from that point of view, is totally discredited. There is only one question for the Prime Minister to answer as far as that particular lunch is concerned, and he answered it. The question is this-and it has been raised by the Opposition-were any private undertakings given to Connell in return for cash? At any meetings that he had with Connell, in any circumstances, were private undertakings given to Connell in return for cash? Nothing else matters.

Leaders of governments and leaders of oppositions meet with business all the time and discuss policy issues or whatever; that is a perfectly legitimate part of the process. But if we are now going to go through this line of questioning which the Opposition has put up in the course of this debate, it is also perfectly legitimate for us to go down a similar line of questioning with it about the meetings with Bond, about the discussions Senator Durack and others may have had with people up and down St George's Terrace. We are entitled to ask the same questions of the Opposition because there is a vast gap between its declared donations in the course of those last two election campaigns and its actual expenditure. We are entitled to argue under what particular artifice was concealed any donations from the goldminers. There are some donations from the goldminers to the Opposition on the public record. The question is: is that in return for policy? If the Opposition wants to put the same question to us, we will put the question back to it.

The Opposition put the question to us on the subject of Laurie Connell-`Did you, Prime Minister, exchange a private undertaking with Laurie Connell in return for cash?'. The answer of the Prime Minister to those two questions was, `No, no'. Absolute nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was answered by Laurie Connell.

—It was to a degree answered by old Laurie Connell at that point when he was asked specifically by the Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other matters, `Did you discuss money with the Prime Minister in terms of donations when you happened to be in there'? His answer to that was, `No.' Not that I suggest that the Opposition necessarily relies on the recollection of Laurie Connell when it comes to dealing with these matters. Just remember that all the things that he has put forward so far to this Royal Commission go unanswered because nobody else has yet appeared to answer them. But one of the points he made, going round to why he might have made the contribution, is this:

SPEECH.PARA: Because I considered that it was a real benefit to Paragon if Labor were returned and I saw it a real detriment to Paragon if the Liberal Party were to gain office and for their policy of introducing a gold tax to be introduced.

Laurie had so firmly in his mind an understanding of what the policies were of the various political parties at the time that he was actually capable of coming out in the Royal Commission and saying that his recollection of the time was that the Liberal Party position was that it was going to introduce a gold tax. So there we are. We now know how deeply Laurie has cast his mind back to the events of those days and what sort of conclusions he has managed to reach on these matters, because of course the Liberal Party was not in a situation where it was going to introduce a gold tax after the election.

The Liberal Party was very firmly on the record as saying that there would be no gold tax-at undeniably boring and huge length from Senator Durack and from others at less length, although it was just as emphatic. The only little glitch in that particular scenario that one can find-and perhaps it is why it had to go on about it at such boring length-is that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in those days, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), did make one effort to do something back in August 1985, and that was when he said he could not guarantee that a future Liberal government would not tax gold. The honourable member for Bennelong, who to some considerable extent was one of the more credible leaders of the Liberal Party over this period, lacks credit entirely in one area-that is, he could never deliver his Party. When he failed to deliver his Party, he did not stand back in semi-embarrassment; he did not walk back in semi-embarrassment for the fact that he had failed to deliver his Party. He embraced the repudiation of his position and rushed to the barrier clutching under his arms the characters who had tormented him in policy debate.

If we want an example of a fellow who was clutching with his arms the people who tormented him in policy debate, we can go no further than to his statement to the goldmining industry incorporated in his letter, which reads:
We are totally opposed to the introduction of a gold tax.
This was Howard 1987 as opposed to Howard 1985:

As my colleague Senator Peter Durack, shadow Minister for Trade and Resources, stated in June last year, a Liberal government would repeal any gold tax introduced by the Labor Government. A gold tax would jeopardise the future of many existing mines and prevent the opening of new ones.
It is passing strange that nobody, evidently, drew Laurie Connell's attention to this at the time. The letter continues:
Exploration and the level of investment in this important sector would also decline rapidly. We have a particular concern about the effects a gold tax would have on our balance of payments.
This was not a rejection by the Prime Minister. This was a detailed argument against his own convictions obliged on him by Senators Durack and Chaney. It continues:

The Liberal Party has a firm commitment on this matter. We are opposed to the introduction of a gold tax. Recognising the need to provide a climate of certainty for investment . . . I trust that this clear and unequivocal undertaking is of assistance to your industry.

So that is where the letter from the honourable member for Bennelong left us as far as the Liberal Party was concerned on the issue of gold tax in that campaign. One could not be clearer than that in a statement and one could not be clearer in the sorts of statements that have been brought out.

Getting back to the nub of what the Opposition seems to think, far from being an announcement by the Prime Minister about our intentions for the next three years, the advertisement which appeared on 10 July, being a letter of 7 July, reads:

I understand that there appears to be an element of uncertainty among members of the Australian Goldmining Industry Council about the Government's intention concerning the tax exemption for goldmining issues, despite my public statements on the matter.

The Prime Minister in that letter clearly referred back to previous public statements that he had made. There are quite a lot of them and they have been detailed in this House in the course of these exchanges. At that point the Prime Minister went on to reiterate those public statements: `No, when we get into office after this election, we will not be implementing a gold tax'.

So the Prime Minister's statement in that letter clearly referred back to the fact that it was not a new commitment. It referred back to commitments that he had made. The Opposition has to suspend its total understanding of politics. A statement made in the course of an election campaign that unequivocally one will not introduce a gold tax means what it says: unequivocally one will not introduce a gold tax. In so far as there was any doubt about that, it was not a doubt being created by Labor Party spokesmen at the time; it was a doubt being created by Senator Durack. Others in the Liberal Party were wandering around saying, `Even though the Labor Party says it, it does not mean it'. This was the position being adopted by Senator Durack and the others at the time: `Even though the Labor Party says it, it does not really mean it'. Therefore, we had to have yet another commitment from the Prime Minister that he had made a decision not to go ahead with a goldmining tax.

The reasons that the Government made that decision not to go ahead with a goldmining tax were many and varied at the time, and none of them went to the question of political donations. They were the sorts of things that influenced many other people doing their analysis of this tax. I go to an Australian editorial written in September 1986 which advised us that it was a `bad time for a gold tax'. The editorial went on to point out:

The Australian Mining Industry Council has reminded the Government that there are nine House of Representatives electorates that have gold mines and gold miners within their boundaries, and four of them, Kalgoorlie in Western Australia, Leichhardt in Queensland, Ballarat and Bendigo in Victoria, return Labor members and have a substantial gold mining component.
The Australian editorial said, `This is not the time for a tax on goldmining'. There was a wonderful little editorial in the Australian about a week ago which read:
Mr Hawke succumbed, in the process producing a very poor policy decision. He decided, against sound advice, not to introduce a gold tax during the life of the next Parliament.

We are all good at twenty-twenty vision whether we happen to be in the media or in politics. The advice of the Australian at the time to the Government was: introduce no gold tax, firstly because it would be bad in principle and, secondly, because we would cut our own throat politically. That was fair enough. That is why in the end we arrived at that position. And that was, I suspect, to a degree why in the end the Opposition did too.

The Treasurer has already made reference to a particularly informative article. I will go on to make one or two more points about it. It quoted the honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney), and stated:

After the WA election there was a feeling in the leadership group that much of the heat had gone out of the gold tax debate. Senator Chaney is understood to have made the observation to colleagues that there were now no votes in it.

That is real principle! The Opposition comes into this place criticising us on the ground of principles. We are the ones who turn on the spit trying to get decent tax into this country.
