DEBATE.TITLE: MILITARY SUPERANNUATION AND BENEFITS BILL 1991[COGNATE BILL:DEFENCE FORCE SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 March, on motion by Mr Bilney:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Military Superannuation and Benefits Bill 1991 concurrently with the Defence Force Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1991. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is not opposed to this important legislation which goes to the core of providing adequate benefits for the armed forces-Navy, Army and Air Force-personnel upon retirement as part of the total approach to military superannuation and benefits. My colleague the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) will be giving a more historical background in relation to this important measure.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) is present, I want to take this opportunity to say that it was a rare privilege yesterday to go to Darwin to visit HMAS Sydney and HMAS Brisbane as they were on their final leg home from the Gulf to Darwin, their first port of call on mainland Australia. They returned from a tough job well done. I salute the Australian contingent in all its component parts, including the ships, the medical teams, the Naval diving team-as we speak here today it is still in the Gulf carrying out some very dangerous work near Kuwait-the exchange officers, liaison officers and others who were part of that contingent. I especially salute those who served on HMAS Sydney and HMAS Brisbane. They were in good spirits yesterday as they saw Australia for the first time in many months. I passed on the best wishes of the Minister, the Opposition and others. The honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) went to the other ship, the HMAS Brisbane, and did likewise. We swapped over when we got into the wharf.

I add in passing that there is one item of concern which I have discussed directly with the Minister-I know that he is looking at possible ways and means of responding adequately on this matter between now and Friday-that is, striking the right balance and cut-off points of recognition of their service. As things stand, it could be that the sailors who served on our supply ships HMAS Success and HMAS Westralia, and did it well, will receive two medals, the Australian Active Service Medal and the Australian Service Medal, associated with the Persian Gulf. Those who served on HMAS Sydney and HMAS Brisbane might only be eligible, due to a very complex formula and difficulties associated with that, for just one medal, which would be the Active Service Medal, but not the Australian Service Medal. If we go to the regulations covering this we find a very adequate discretion available to the Minister and to the Chief of the Defence Force to exercise a leeway, especially as the total number of days involved were reached in a combination of both regular service and active duty service. I hope that the Minister will be successful in reviewing this matter. I know that there will be a popular homecoming for these personnel in Brisbane. I do not want to lock the Minister in because I know that these things have to be worked through very carefully, but it would go down very well if there could be a breakthrough on this matter between now and Friday, when the ships arrive in Brisbane for a formal welcome by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), because they deserve appropriate recognition. They have served Australia well, and the legislation before the House will help to look after their superannuation interests when they eventually retire.

On 11 May 1989 the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel announced that there would be a complete review of the existing defence force retirement and death benefits (DFRDB) scheme, which would result in the development of a new superannuation and death benefits scheme for Defence Force members. This legislation brings into force a new scheme, called the military superannuation and benefits scheme (MSBS), to be implemented from 1 October 1991. In this regard the shadow Minister for veterans' affairs and defence personnel, Senator Jocelyn Newman, will have more specific detail to give in the Senate. On her behalf I signify, once again, that the Opposition is not opposed to the Military Superannuation and Benefits Bill and the Defence Force Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill.

The military service benefits scheme is set up by a trust deed, administered by trustees in accordance with the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987. The trust deed sets out the powers and functions of the board of trustees. The rules contained in the schedule to the trust deed specify details of the contribution to be paid and benefits to be provided.

The Bill provides for the following: a trust deed, which is to be executed by the Minister on behalf of the Commonwealth, the form of which is set out in the schedule of the Bill; Commonwealth Funds Management Ltd to manage the moneys in the fund until such time as other arrangements are made, if desired, by the trustees; the appointment of a board of trustees to manage the fund; the Commissioner of Superannuation to be responsible for the provision of administrative services to the board; contributions to be made by members and the Commonwealth and benefits to be paid to members; financial arrangements between the fund set up under the trust deed and the Commonwealth; members of the Defence Force to be members of the scheme and other members to be eligible to join the scheme; transfer arrangements to be created to allow existing members to transfer from the DFRDB to the MSBS; and the payment of a retention benefit to certain members who undertake to complete 20 years service.

The Bill amends the Defence Forces Retirement and Death Benefits Act 1973 to give members of that scheme, under the Act, 13 months from 1 September 1991 in which to decide to transfer to the new scheme or to remain with the DFRDB. The Opposition supports the passage of this legislation, which is almost entirely based on the recommendations of the report by Sir William Coles of June 1990.

There will be a significant financial impact on the Australian Government-from approximately $152m in this financial year to $209m in 1994-95. In the longer term, however, there are expected to be budgetary savings. It is my firm view that this is a correct priority because for too long governments, and in particular the Hawke Labor Government, have taken a short-sighted approach to the conditions of service of our service personnel. The result has been very high resignation rates which, in turn, create a massive cost burden on defence, especially when experienced personnel are resigning and we then have to recruit. The cost of recruitment and training is very significant. Any perceived saving by cutting back on conditions of service is, therefore, often a mirage. What happens is that high resignation rates mean very significantly higher training costs.

In the end, the Navy, Army and Air Force can be gutted of their most experienced personnel. This Parliament supplied the members of the Manfred Cross inquiry, which was an attempt to turn this around over a period, but much more needs to be done. I add that the Government has really dawdled since 1983- perhaps, to some extent, the previous Government did as well-in attaining a DFRDB scheme throughout the 1980s which did not keep pace with superannuation benefits offered to most other private and public sector employees. The military was left, in a sense, in a cocoon and this cost dearly.
I have to say that I am pleased to see that at last the Government has seen the sense of adopting elements of the coalition's defence science and personnel policy. It states that the coalition will-

. . . ensure that service personnel are not disadvantaged relative to the civilian community in relation to superannuation benefits. Anomalies which also will be examined include-the lack of interest on personal contributions, the effect of nominal retirement ages for officers, and the lack of employer contributions below 20 years of service.

The second related measure is the Defence Force Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1991. This makes amendment to the parent Act of 1973 and, where appropriate, to the Defence Force Retirement Benefits Act 1948. As I have already mentioned, the Military Superannuation and Benefits Bill 1991 seeks to establish a new superannuation scheme. The MSBS makes consequential amendments to the DFRDB, which have the effect of rendering the DFRDB a closed scheme; that is, the only persons who will be in the DFRDB scheme are those who opt not to transfer to the MSBS. The only persons permitted to join the scheme will be pensioner re-entrants who also opt not to join the MSBS.

The amendments in this Bill will improve the administration of the DFRDB Act, taking into account that new dimension. The amendments, in brief, are as follows: changes to the constitution and manner of appointment of the DFRDB Authority which administers the scheme under the DFRDB Act, to reflect its more limited role by transferring the power from the Governor-General to the Minister, and compulsory cessation of contributions by members who have reached 40 years effective service. I am not sure that there will be very many of those; but it was interesting to find that the chief engineman on HMAS Sydney, who was a Vietnam veteran, is getting on to 30 years of service. Likewise, at the weekend, on HMAS Brisbane I found that some people have given many decades of service. Forty years is a very long period of service in the armed forces.

The second Bill will also provide for specific power for the Authority to classify and reclassify members for invalidity purposes in certain cases of death. It will provide for continuation of payment to a spouse of a deceased pensioner, for a period immediately after the death of the pensioner, of a pension at the rate previously payable to the deceased pensioner.

Changes in the nature of benefits payable to members who retire a second time are catered for, and the amendments are consequent on the Superannuation Act 1990 coming into operation. This is a cognate debate and, therefore, I will not dwell on it greatly, other than to say that the Opposition does not oppose either the Military Superannuation and Benefits Bill or the Defence Force Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill.

I issue one final note of warning in respect of this legislation: it is a very sensitive area; it goes to the morale of our hardworking members in the Navy, the Army and the Air Force, many of whom are still overseas. For example, HMAS Westralia is still in the Gulf; there are still United Nations peacekeeping forces in reduced numbers in the Middle East and, as I mentioned, a clearance diving team is also still in the Gulf. Of course, many back here in Australia have plenty on their hands and are quite often involved in dangerous exercise situations and the like. This is a very important matter to them, to their security and to the well-being of their families in the event of an accident or death or upon retirement from the armed forces. The new scheme is not well understood amongst members of the Navy, the Army and the Air Force.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lack of consultation.

—I will not dwell unduly on the reasons for this, but I take the point of the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) that one aspect of that is a lack of consultation. The second aspect is that the extent of complexity of the Bill is such that, no matter who the government of the day is, it will require a massive educational effort to bring everyone up to speed with this new comprehensive scheme. The Government should proceed with that task; otherwise it will create difficulty if there is an inadequate understanding of the complex changes involved-changes which, by and large, we support but, nevertheless, changes which are not yet familiar to so many in the Navy, the Army and the Air Force, particularly to the younger elements who, in their first couple of years in the armed forces, think very little about their superannuation arrangements, a defence service home loan or housing arrangements more generally. Therefore, I ask that the Minister take note of the fact that there is still a need for a continuing educative process in relation to these complex schemes. The Opposition is not opposed to the legislation before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Military Superannuation and Benefits Bill and the Defence Force Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill, which are before us today, follow on from Government announcements last August to introduce a new superannuation scheme for all Defence Force personnel. In September, I had the pleasure of congratulating the Government and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) for the preparation of the legislation and for the contents of the report of the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefit Scheme Review Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a pity that in his speech today the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer), in acknowledging the good points of this legislation, sought to score the odd cheap political point by telling us that it was National Party policy first. In his own speech, he addressed the fact that it had been the subject of recommendations from various committees.

Equally, I cannot let pass the comment from the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid), who clearly has not been involved in this debate in the past and has not followed it. If he had been involved, he would be aware of the extensive communications last year to all serving personnel providing details of the program, not only in a comprehensive way but in a very clear and readable manner, to try to translate what is a complex matter of law into a readable fashion for those who are affected by it. The interjection from the honourable member for Bendigo clearly indicates his ignorance of the subject and lack of involvement in it.

This scheme was recommended in the report of the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefit Scheme Review Committee, which was tabled in June of last year. I am also pleased to say that it followed a report of a subcommittee-chaired by my predecessor in the electorate of Brisbane, Mr Manfred Cross-of the Joint Committee of Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade in 1988. I take this opportunity to again acknowledge on the record the very extensive and fine work conducted by that Committee and, in particular, the many long years of work put into Defence Force matters by my predecessor, Manfred Cross, in his excellent report Personnel Wastage in the Australian Defence Force. I am pleased that the Leader of the National Party had the good faith to acknowledge the importance of that report and, in spite of the interjection from the honourable member for Bendigo, to acknowledge that the difficulties confronting this question have as much to do with the complexity of the issue as they do with any question of a lack of consultation. `Lack of consultation' are the precise words that the honourable member for Bendigo used. That is not the case and he should go back and do his homework.

This new scheme updates what is in many ways an outdated scheme which does not reflect the current superannuation provisions in private industry nor the provisions in State and Commonwealth public services generally. The new scheme is designed to comply with the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act of 1987, thereby bringing it into line with the normal provisions pertaining to employees in the work force generally. It provides Defence Force personnel the same degree of protection and access to benefits that they could rightly expect to obtain in other places of employment.

Throughout the superannuation industry there have been dramatic changes in the last decade. These changes have more accurately reflected individual career paths. The changes have sought to ensure that benefits provided to contributors take account of the movements throughout their career lives and ensure that at the end of their working lives they have access through an accumulated fund to sizeable superannuation payments that will assist them in their later years.

With respect to benefits, a major shift has occurred in the last decade concerning the vesting entitlements of superannuation funds. The changes have improved to a marked degree the vesting entitlements of contributors throughout the superannuation industry. By and large, those changes have sought to provide benefits for all employees preserved to the age of 55. The previous industry standards, which were largely reflected in the old Defence Force retirement and death benefits (DFRDB) scheme, provided for no access or little access to employer contributions prior to retirement or prior to attaining the age of 55. That was a characteristic of the old DFRDB, and it was a characteristic of insurance throughout the last 20 years.

It is not necessarily a reflection on former governments, and it is not an effort to score cheap political points as we have seen, unfortunately, earlier in this debate. It is a fact that throughout the period of life of the Opposition in government it took no steps to correct this. That was the prevailing standard throughout the superannuation industry at that time. That has changed, and this Government has properly recognised that, acting on the recommendations of those two committees to which I have referred.

The changes introduced by the Hawke Government generally in superannuation encourage funds and contributors to preserve their entitlements until age 55. That has been done by the introduction of approved deposit funds, and similar organisations and funds, in conjunction with tax incentives. Those tax incentives have rewarded employee contributors and fund managers for structuring funds in a way that preserves superannuation entitlements to age 55.

Some specifics of the legislation before us that I think are worthy of mention in this new military superannuation and benefits fund pick up on the earlier comments I have made. At present, service personnel must complete 20 years of service in order to get more than just their own contributions back. That is clearly out of kilter with prevailing standards in superannuation. The new scheme, introduced by way of this legislation, provides for these people to receive interest on their contributions and an entitlement to part of their employer contributions. The employer contribution is preserved to age 55, again in accordance with industry standards.

The employer's contribution will be based on the final annual salary of the member, averaged over the previous three years. This will be multiplied by a factor for each year of service, with the factor depending on the length of service. For one to seven years of service that factor will be 18 per cent; for eight to 20 years, 23 per cent; and 28 per cent for longer service. It should be noted that these are not cumulative. No matter what the length of service, the first seven years will have a factor of 18 per cent for each year of service during this period.

The employer contribution will not fully vest with the members until after seven years service and, prior to that, will vest at the rate of 10 per cent per year for the first five years and 25 per cent for the next two years. Providing full vesting after seven years compares quite favourably with many industry standards. From my own investigations into different superannuation schemes and my own experience as a former union official, I know that many industry standards now hinge around the 10-year mark. A seven-year full vesting payment is a quite proper payment and certainly at the forefront of what would be the case outside in other employment.

Part or all of the lump sum may be commuted into a pension at rates more favourable than current commercial rates. The Government has recognised the likely effect on some service personnel who may currently be enticed to serve 20 years, primarily to receive their superannuation entitlements. It is a fact that a scheme which provides reward for staying for 20 years, but nothing other than one's own contributions if one leaves beforehand, inevitably will entice people to stay those extra few years to get the financial security that the 20-year service provided. Under the new legislation, those people will be able to leave with less than 20 years service and obtain substantial payments and a preserved entitlement for their retirement at age 55. These are significant improvements for current serving personnel.

The Government has recognised the likely effects on retention rates that such a proposal creates and accordingly the Government is introducing a retention payment for selected personnel. Those eligible to receive the retention payment are personnel with 15 years of continuous service under various categories: an officer who holds a rank not lower than major or equivalent, or was previously an enlisted member; an enlisted member who holds the rank of sergeant or equivalent; or, thirdly, a member declared by the Minister to be an eligible member. It is expected that this will be necessary to declare members who meet certain requirements in an employment category where the normal opportunities for promotion do not exist. They are quite appropriate categories in which to provide that retention payment incentive.

The retention payment incentive is a significant one. It represents an annual salary payment as a one-off payment to the serving personnel-male or female-to re-enlist for a further five years, with appropriate safeguards in the event that they decide to leave prior to that five-year period concluding. It is a significant financial payment which is estimated to cost $96m in the first year, with an ongoing annual cost of approximately $55m. The Government is clearly setting aside substantial amounts of money by way of a retention bonus to encourage selected personnel to maintain their period of service in the Defence Force. It is a far preferable scheme to the inducement of the current 20-year arrangement which, inevitably, wherever it is applied, leads to people being retained in service without genuine or strong motivation.

The contributions under the new scheme will earn interest through investments in a fund. At present the DFRDB contributions are paid into Consolidated Revenue and no interest is paid to members. It therefore provides a substantial improvement to service men and women. The contributions will be at a variable rate. Service personnel can choose to contribute between 5 per cent and 10 per cent. At present, the DFRDB provides for a fixed payment of 5.5 per cent.

Importantly, there is no notional retiring age penalty in the military superannuation and benefits scheme (MSBS). At present, officers who contribute to the DFRDB scheme and retire before reaching the notional age have their pension reduced by 3 per cent for each year that age on retirement is below the notional retiring age. This initiative achieves equity between other ranks and officers and removes a source of justifiable contention held by ADF officers.

The MSBS dependant benefits will be automatically updated annually in line with the consumer price index (CPI). This is a major improvement guaranteeing maintenance of real value of benefits. It corrects the situation which led to DFRDB orphan benefits remaining at a figure of $702 for nearly 20 years. That benefit is now $5,000. I might add that again in terms of what is standard throughout the superannuation industry, indexation of those benefits is now a standard feature. It was not 20 years ago but it is now and is quite properly a benefit that should be paid. It provides to the contributor the peace of mind of knowing that in the event of dependant payments being required there is a realistic payment that their dependants will receive. It is linked to the CPI, not to average wage movements or any other indicator. It is linked to the most useful indicator that is available and will provide a significant benefit to serving personnel and, of course, to those dependants who will one day draw upon it.

The MSBS members have the option to continue contributions and accrue employer benefits during periods of leave without pay in some circumstances. This will be of particular benefit for women taking leave for childbirth. This is a new provision and it compares very favourably with other schemes. It demonstrates the Government's clear commitment to equal employment opportunities. In many respects, we are at the cutting edge of the industry here because it is not a widely held provision to enable people on unpaid leave to accrue employer benefits as well. It is not uncommon for people on unpaid leave to be able to contribute themselves and to earn whatever interest may accrue to their funds and whatever benefit they may derive from that. It is, however, not usual for people in that unpaid situation to gain the benefit of employer contributions at that time. I commend the Government for its initiative in this respect and its clear demonstration of a commitment to equal opportunities by its inclusion.

Persons joining the regular Defence Force on or after 1 October this year will automatically be able to avail themselves of those new features in the MSBS. Those members who are currently contributing to the DFRDB scheme will have the option of remaining in that scheme or joining the new MSBS. They will have until 30 September to decide whether to join the new MSBS or stay in the current DFRDB scheme. Of course, those retiring or resigning before the end of September 1991 will have to make their choice before they leave.

I wish to conclude by referring to some of the matters that I raised at the outset. In doing so, I commend the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel and the Department for what I regard as the excellent work they have done in preparing information to send to service personnel. The kits, the brochures and the material distributed last year and widely publicised in all service magazines and newspapers provided comprehensive information for all personnel upon which they can base their decision.

Clearly in matters of this sort it is difficult for people to arrive at a conclusion. Anybody who has been involved in a scheme introducing new superannuation benefits-even modifications to existing schemes-particularly if they have been involved in going to the contributors, the employees, and explaining to them the differences between the two systems, will know the complexities and the difficulties confronted in conveying to people the necessary detail upon which they can base their important decision.

At the end of the day, the contributions made to superannuation funds become critical. We in this place all know the importance which superannuation will play in the early part of the next century, when the population skew within Australia will result in more people being in the age group over 60 than in the working age group of 15 to 60. That will place enormous strains on government's capacity to provide pension benefits and the like. It therefore becomes imperative that we ensure that superannuation funds throughout the land provide equitable and complete cover for wage and salary earners and self-employed people in all walks of life.

This Government initiative goes a long way down that track in ensuring that our Defence Force personnel are able to access the very best of services through an updated fund that accurately reflects current industry standards and, in some respects, is at the cutting edge of those industry standards. I again congratulate the Minister on the legislation, on accepting the advice of the two committees that have reported on this matter and on the professional way in which the Department and the Minister have gone about explaining these issues to defence men and women. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleague the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) said earlier, the Opposition supports both the broad thrust and the specifics of both pieces of legislation before us this evening-the Military Superannuation and Benefits Bill, covering the military superannuation benefits system, the so-called MSBS, and, secondly, the Defence Force Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill, covering amendments to the Defence Force and Retirement Death Benefits, or DFRDB, Act-about which we have heard so much.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) that I too do not want to indulge in cheap party politics on this legislation, but it is not before time that this legislation is before us; and I point out that the Opposition, in developing its existing policy, as early as 1987 was making these points. They continue to be reflected in our current policy, which of course will have to be amended as a result of this legislation. In particular, we emphasise at this point the need for that consultation process, moving towards the prolonged implementation of MSBS.

Both of these Bills are very important for the Australian Defence Force, albeit of necessity being very technical in nature. I would like to reiterate a couple of points made by the honourable member for Farrer. I agree entirely with what he had to say in two points that he made. They were, firstly, that this legislation goes to the core of the Australian Defence Force financial conditions of service and, secondly, that, as a result of that, it goes very much to the heart of morale in that force.

The basic question is: why change? Before I go on to that, perhaps I should spell out some of the comments that were made by a number of commentators across the country when the ministerial announcements were made on the subject. Firstly, I refer to what the National President of the Returned Services League (RSL) of Australia, Alf Garland, said on 8 August last year:

It has been clear for some time that the old DFRDB scheme has a number of deficiencies. It does not encourage retention in the ADF. For those that resign before the 20 year point there is no employer benefit payable and no return of members' contributions.
These points were made quite clearly by the honourable member for Brisbane. Mr Garland went on:
There are also deficiencies in the cover offered for widows and orphans. These will be overcome in the new scheme.
He went on to say:
While recognising that the scheme was required to comply with the Occupational Superannuation Standards we welcome the main features of the MSBS.
He set these out:

. . . availability of benefits for those who serve less than 20 years; the flexibility offered by either the lump sum or pensions; the retention incentive payable at 15 years point for senior NCOs and officers; and the flexibility for additional members' contributions.
He also said-and there was a little concern implicit in his comments:

The RSL is concerned about the vesting provisions which are more stringent than in other public sector superannuation funds. There is less flexibility available for members of the ADF to fund their retirement benefits. This puts members of the ADF at a disadvantage.

I will come back to those points at the end of what I have to say. Secondly, I want to refer the House to what Pat Jones, the Executive Officer of the Armed Forces Federation of Australia, said on the subject. Firstly, he said that the MSBS `provides significant improvements for most Service personnel' and `the ADF employment conditions package is the better for it'. That said, he highlighted one or two points that I hope the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths), who is at the table, will convey to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney). Pat Jones said:

The Federation is not entirely confident that the retention benefit in the new scheme will achieve its aim. We suspect many people will transfer to the new scheme and resign soon after. Those who seek to remain to 55 have the potential to choke the promotion system. There is also a problem with members subject to management initiated early retirement. The Government will therefore need to look to more than MSBS to attract and retain Service personnel.

I agree with that comment in particular, and again I will have some comments to make on that. Turning to why we need change, I think it is important that we look at the historical origins of the need for change. For the information of the House, the first retirement benefits scheme specifically designed for members of the Australian Defence Force (ADF), the old Defence Force retirement benefits scheme, was introduced in 1948 and ran until September 1972. From that time on, entitlements were calculated under the existing Defence Force retirement and death benefits scheme.

Since the introduction of that scheme there have been substantial changes in the laws and rules governing superannuation-most importantly, the introduction of occupational superannuation standards (OSS), a national wage case decision to require employers to contribute 3 per cent of salary to superannuation. The OSS must be complied with for a superannuation fund to receive concessional tax treatment. The honourable member for Farrer and the honourable member for Brisbane both made the point that the DFRDB scheme is unfunded so that members' contributions are paid into the Consolidated Revenue fund and entitlements are met from the same source as they become due. There is no investment fund to invest the members' contributions as in other Commonwealth superannuation schemes.

The DFRDB scheme was briefly reviewed by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and the findings published in 1988 as the so-called Cross report, entitled Personnel Wastage in the Australian Defence Force. Like the honourable member for Brisbane, I once again congratulate Manfred Cross and his cross-party team on an excellent report which highlighted some of the deficiencies.

The report found that while benefits were greater than the community norm in some areas, in some cases, particularly for people retiring before 20 years of service, to whom only a refund of contributions is made, the benefit was behind the community norm. It also noted that the current scheme does not encourage people to serve past their initial engagement term and called for a review of the scheme. In the response to the report on 11 May 1989 the Minister announced that a review of the DFRDB scheme would be conducted. The terms of reference of the review included the examination of the suitability of the DFRDB scheme and any possible changes to that scheme or the creation of a new scheme for members of the defence forces.

As previous speakers have said, the review team delivered its report in June last year and recommended the establishment of a new scheme rather than amendments to the DFRDB scheme. Reasons for this included that it would be very difficult to adapt the current scheme to conform to the OSS, there would be substantial cost increases, and the current scheme drives rather than assists Defence Force personnel policy. It was recommended that the DFRDB scheme remain for current members, that new members join and that those currently members of the DFRDB scheme have the option of joining the new scheme, which, as previous speakers have said, will be known as the military superannuation and benefits scheme, or MSBS. In many aspects, it is similar to the new public sector superannuation scheme for other Commonwealth employees.

It is important to highlight the new scheme rather than a variation of the old scheme. I point out to the House that the review committee's findings said that it was not possible to build a superannuation scheme which would serve the needs of both ADF members and management on the foundations of the existing DFRDB scheme. The committee said that one of the most noticeable deficiencies is that members who serve for less than 20 years receive no contribution towards their superannuation. In part, it said:
This grossly affronts the spirit of the OSS . . . and the intention that employer benefits be both vested in the member and preserved. Thus the status quo is not an option . . .
It went on to state:
The lack of any investment return on members' contributions also has been widely criticised.
To provide both full employer vesting and earnings on members' contributions would have added about 15% to the annual cost of the DFRDB Scheme.

The OSS also require that the employer benefit be preserved in new schemes until the member retires from the workforce at or after age 55. The DFRDB Scheme pays a pension from ages as young as 36 and allows, at the present time, for 4.35 . . . times one year's pension to be commuted to a lump sum.

To bring these arrangements into line with the OSS clearly would have meant abrogating the Government's iron clad guarantee that `. . . the benefits for which members are currently contributing will continue to be available when they leave the Defence Force'.
Thus any proposal to overcome these obvious deficiencies of the DFRDB Scheme would have involved substantial additional cost without the possibility of any offsetting savings.
This would be contrary to the Terms of Reference and the Minister's requirement that any new scheme should not be more expensive than the present scheme in budgetary terms.

There were numerous commentaries on the changes. I have looked at many of them. One that struck me was an article by Daryl Dixon, a financial commentator, in the Canberra Times on Sunday, 9 September of last year. He said, in part:

After 20 years' membership, the DFRDB provides excellent Tattslotto type benefits-a partly commutable generous indexed pension usually payable at a relatively early age. Before that period of membership-except in some situations such as death, disability or retrenchment-the DFRDB is one of the most ungenerous schemes to be found in Australia.
The DFRDB does not even comply with government guidelines to pay interest on members' contributions to the fund, let alone provide any vested employer benefits to departing employees.
The MSBS, by contrast, has been devised to comply with the Government's rules and provide benefits to all employees, including those with short stays in the defence forces.
The MSBS will also, as with all the new schemes, save the Government money in the long run . . .
He concluded by saying:

However, departing employees will also be able to take a refund of their own contributions plus accrued fund earnings when they leave. Under the DFRDB, the only pay-out on resignation is a return of the employee's contribution with no interest at all.
It is not surprising that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel made some announcements on this subject in August. He said that the major features of the scheme were:
* It will offer a full range of options for retiring members including lump sums, pensions or a combination;
* A selective retention benefit of one year's salary after fifteen years service for members who commit themselves to serve for a further five years;
* Employer benefits which must be preserved until age 55; and
* Variable rates of contributions between five and ten per cent of salary.

On the specifics, the Government has accepted amendments to the DFRDB legislation which aim at remedying perceived deficiencies. These amendments are more in the nature of tightening up the existing provisions rather than entailing changes to the general structure of the scheme, although some of the proposed changes are significant for those affected. For example, there is the very welcome indexation of the $5,000 per annum payable to orphans and the $312 per annum children's benefit; there is provision for widows of DFRDB contributors to commute up to two years worth of the former spouse's salary, with commensurate reduction in the widow's pension; there is the $160,000 per annum, or thereabouts, for the six pay periods after a death which will be paid to the spouse of the deceased pensioner; there is the adjustment of the re-entered DFRDB recipient member's final pension to match, as nearly as possible, the benefit provided to a continuously serving member with the same length of service, together with further commutation at the second exit; and, finally, there is the cessation of contribution after 40 years, as benefits cease to accrue at 40= years service.

It would be reasonable to say that the proposed MSBS meets the occupational superannuation standards and resolves some anomalies in the present DFRDB scheme. It is a vast improvement on the DFRDB scheme for short term employees and does not disadvantage service personnel when compared with the civilian community, although some would argue that that point is debatable. However, most DFRDB scheme members intending to serve to the 20-year mark would be financially advantaged by remaining in the DFRDB scheme.

One disparity between the MSBS and the new Commonwealth superannuation scheme-or the PSS-is with vesting. The PSS allows for the employer benefit to be fully vested at four years, whereas the MSBS does not allow full vesting until year seven.

I finish by posing a number of questions to the Minister about retention benefits. I go back to the questions that Pat Jones and the Armed Forces Federation asked. Does the Minister agree that there will be a problem with retention? Earlier in my speech I also referred to a number of other questions about management initiated early retirement, promotion choking, et cetera. The second question is about funding. As the honourable member for Farrer has pointed out, very substantial costs from about $151m in 1991-92 to $209m in 1994-95 are involved here. My question to the Minister is: who will bear the cost of that expenditure? Will other elements within the Defence budgetary outlays go towards influencing the Minister's view? About vesting, I ask the Minister whether he agrees with the Returned Services League about seven years as distinct from four years?

One last point-a very important point-which I do not think has been referred to by either of the previous speakers, is the so-called 3 per cent penalty. I understand that the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) will say a little more about this matter, so I will leave the bulk of it with him, but I point out that in the Cross report some very persuasive comments were made about the 3 per cent penalty applied short of notional retiring age, particularly as it affects officers being removed. In fact, in the findings of the review and the Government's decisions, that matter has not even been commented on. I ask the Minister whether something is going to be done in relation to that 3 per cent penalty within the DFRDB area.

In conclusion, I do not think it is cheap politics for the honourable member for Farrer to raise the question of the high rate of resignations and discharges from the Defence Force over the last four years. These two Bills are very important pieces of legislation and they need to be understood more fully. As I said at the outset, they are very technical. I ask the Minister to recognise that whilst this legislation goes to the core of conditions of service it is not a total solution. I ask him to give some assurance that other initiatives will be taken in the conditions of service area as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am particularly pleased to have the opportunity to rise tonight to speak on the Military Superannuation and Benefits Bill and the Defence Force Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill, particularly as they relate to superannuation and how it affects our defence personnel. I am particularly pleased that we have a bipartisan approach to these Bills, although the Opposition has made its comments. That is fair enough because the Opposition is always entitled to make its views known. I think it is good that both the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) and the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) have indicated the Opposition's support for these Bills now before the Parliament. As we saw recently in regard to our participation in the Gulf, a bipartisan approach in this place certainly goes a long way to improving debate-particularly when we look at the conflict we have had over the last few days and earlier today in the House.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased that a lot of these initiatives were recommended by the Cross report entitled Personnel Wastage in the Australian Defence Force. I would like to endorse the earlier remarks of the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) about Mr Cross, who was a longstanding member of this place and well-respected not only in his local community but also amongst defence people. Mr Cross was always very aware of the needs of defence people as he had a large military base in his electorate of Brisbane. It is good that those recommendations have been recognised here tonight.

Superannuation is certainly a complex area. Those of us who have had experience in that field before certainly treat it as a complex area. Planning for people's retirement is not an area that should be taken lightly. Superannuation is a subject that we really need to think about in terms of how it will place us in our retirement years. Defence personnel, of course, need to have that information as well.

The Military Superannuation and Benefits Bill does much to increase the benefits in pay and conditions for the men and women of our defence forces. In the superannuation area it is only right that our defence personnel are given the same flexibility and ability to save for a diverse range of retirement alternatives as their counterparts in civilian life.

It was only last week that we saw evidence in the Occupational Superannuation Laws Amendment Bill 1991 and the Superannuation Supervisory Levy Bill 1991 of the Government's intention to make superannuation a means whereby all Australians have independence with dignity in retirement. This will be achieved for defence personnel through the military superannuation and benefits scheme. Having the country's largest operational Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) base in my electorate at Amberley, I am patently aware of the demands placed on defence members and their families. I am pleased to have this opportunity to speak on legislation which further improves the benefits they rightfully deserve.

I believe it is timely to put on record my appreciation for the 70 years of service the Royal Australian Air Force has given to Australia-service which was commemorated recently by way of several ceremonies around Australia, in particular in my electorate on the weekend. On a local level, I pay tribute to the administration and personnel of the Amberley RAAF Base in my electorate of Oxley-which celebrated 50 years of operations last year-who have played their part in this 70-year history of the RAAF.

As most honourable members would be aware, Amberley is home to two squadrons, Squadron No. 1 and Squadron No. 6, of F111 strike aircraft. Since the introduction of the F111 to the RAAF in 1973 it has proven to be a most versatile addition to our defence forces. With its swing wings and terrain hugging radar, the F111 can fly at supersonic speeds over land or sea to strike with great accuracy using the latest high technology weapons.

Amberley is by far the greatest employer in the electorate of Oxley, having some 2,800 personnel amongst its ranks. Once the immediate families are taken into consideration, this figure swells to about 10,000 people-a significant proportion of the population of the city of Ipswich. This proportion is even greater once the large number of civilians involved in the operations of the air base are taken into account-not to forget the employees of the Australian Construction Services who have a lot to do at the Air Force base as well.

What this figure tells us is that defence communities across Australia, such as those at Amberley, and the infrastructure in which the personnel at those bases work, need to have strong and committed support from the government of the day. Let us not forget though that behind the spending each year on things such as upgrades of aircraft, ships and munitions it is the defence families that constitute the real heart of our defence forces.

The Bills before us build on the Government's recognition that defence families are every bit as much a part of the central community as they are of the defence community. That is something reflected in so many of the defence initiatives that have been implemented since this Government came to office in 1983. While the Military Superannuation and Benefits Bill deals specifically with the area of superannuation benefits, it is important that we view this improvement in the context of the broader benefits picture, particularly the commitment of this Government to giving defence personnel just reward for their contribution to our national defence effort. While the Opposition persists in firing sporadic misguided outbursts at Government initiatives, I believe that there remains absent any genuine concern for the overall well-being of our defence personnel. In contrast, the Hawke Government has a record on which it can stand proud.

In 1987, a special portfolio, separate from the main Defence portfolio, was established to look after the unique needs of defence personnel and their families. Since this time a wide range of substantial improvements in defence pay and overall conditions of service have come about. Changes to the taxation system implemented by the Government in this time have helped these initiatives to bring even greater rewards to service personnel in both salary and tax terms.

Up to 1 February this year, the smallest effective total increase in pay scales between $20,000 and $50,000 per annum, when considering direct wage rises and indirect benefits to the tax system, was just under 22 per cent. This compares with a consumer price index increase of 18.5 per cent for the same period. The Government has also addressed the problems associated with the mobility side of defence life faced by Australian Defence Force (ADF) families.

The Defence Housing Authority was established to provide commercial flexibility in managing defence housing, to reduce costs and to improve the maintenance of defence homes. Backing up its commitment, the Government will spend $1 billion on defence housing over the next 10 years. During the 1988-89 financial year alone, the Hawke Government spent $135m on defence housing, including repairs and maintenance. This compares with an average of $35m for the last five years of the Fraser Government.

The long term planning and consideration for Australia's defence families is evident in the plan of the Defence Housing Authority to take over, on a progressive basis, the leases of private houses which are rented by defence families, thereby alleviating these families' up-front costs such as security bonds. Other steps have been taken to help families. For example, to assist in the frequent transfers which occur in the ADF this Government established the family information network for defence (FIND), an initiative which has proved very popular. It provides a confidential, up to date, plain English version of personnel provisions and issues. In its first month of operation FIND received more than 1,000 calls, clearly reflecting the Government's recognition of the need to provide general information to allow individuals to better pursue their cases or to understand their rights.

This highlights the fact that, when it comes to having a genuine interest in the future of the ADF and its personnel, there has been a mix of policies implemented by this Government, which has best served and will continue to best serve the interests of our defence forces. It is with this strong background that we come to the extended benefits which will flow from the Military Superannuation and Benefits Bill 1991. (Quorum formed)

I am pleased that my colleagues have come in. We were not talking about the Broncos but about defence personnel. I am a bit disappointed that the Opposition is not adopting a bipartisan approach to this matter. I was very pleasant to Opposition members earlier. Perhaps I have learned a lesson. I was coming to some important points about the Military Superannuation and Benefits Bill 1991. I will list some of the particular advantages to defence personnel of the military superannuation and benefits scheme (MSBS) compared with the Defence Force retirement and death benefits (DFRDB) scheme are as follows. A significant benefit is available to those who serve less than 20 years-as has been highlighted here today. Final benefits, for most retirees, can be taken wholly as a lump sum at age 55, while 50 per cent or more of this lump sum can be converted to a pension at favourable rates.

The retention benefit at the 15-year point provides a significant lump sum when it is needed most, without having to resign to get it, as occurs with DFRDB commutation. Members who leave the ADF and later rejoin are treated favourably, a particular advantage for female members who leave to raise a family-as the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) mentioned earlier. Members' contributions are invested in a fund. Like other superannuation funds, the return will depend on the performance of the fund. Members receive regular advice on the accumulation of their contributions plus interest. Additional contributions can be made if a member thinks fit. It is very important that we have this flexibility of contributions to the new MSBS fund. As with the DFRDB, long-serving members obtain a generous benefit compared with community standards.

It is the Government's desire that no Defence Force member or their family be left not knowing where they stand with the new scheme, and for that reason has made available a comprehensive kit for Defence Force members. I compliment the Minister and his department on the preparation of that kit. It is certainly a quite intensive kit and I am sure it will be of great assistance to defence personnel in their making up their minds on what they need by way of future superannuation requirements.

There has been a special toll-free telephone number set up to serve as a handy first-up contact point for information members may need, which I am sure will be of a great assistance to our defence personnel as well. Both these measures will also be followed up by an intensive publicity campaign designed to assist members reach an informed decision on whether to transfer to the new scheme or to remain with the DFRDB scheme. Once the MSBS scheme commences, Defence Force members will have a full 12 months in which to decide the scheme that best suits them.

The MSBS will have two components-superannuation and a retention benefit. The superannuation component will provide a lump sum on leaving the ADF and will give members access to an income stream on retirement from the work force by providing them with a choice of a lump sum or pension at that time. It will also provide them with insurance cover in the event of invalidity, retirement or death. The retention component will provide a lump sum to long-serving members so that the ADF can retain its most experienced personnel. The payment, although part of the MSBS, will be quite separate from the MSBS superannuation benefits. The DFRDB scheme is effective in retaining personnel to the 20-year point and it achieves this by offering a commutation lump sum to those who resign with 20 years of service. However, as Government standards prevent new superannuation schemes paying commutable pensions to anyone under age 55, the MSBS cannot offer a commutable lump sum.

To counter this, and still make the Defence Force an attractive long term career path, the MSBS will pay a retention benefit and, unlike the DFRDB scheme, it will not be necessary to leave the ADF to receive the lump sum. These benefits will be calculated by offering a lump sum of one year's salary to all members on completion of 15 years continuous effective service. I am sure this particular initiative will be welcomed by all members of the Defence Forces.

Significantly, reflecting the Defence Force's recognition of the varied circumstances behind the requests for leave without pay, most periods of leave without pay where the member continues to continue to contribute to the MSBS will be counted towards that 15 years. The lump sum will be based on actual salary, including service allowance at the 15-year point. No other allowances will be included. Because the retention benefit is not a superannuation benefit and because it is paid in service, it will be taxed as income in the year received. Members who accept the retention benefit will have to give an undertaking to serve for another five years, at which time a medical certificate of fitness for further service will be required.

Those members who are within five years of their statutory retiring age at the 15-year point will be offered a retention benefit but it will be reduced in line with the amount of time left to serve. For example, a member who has four years to serve to statutory retirement age at the 15-year point will be offered a lump sum of four-fifths of one year's salary. A member who resigns, or who is discharged for disciplinary reasons, before completing the further service undertaking will have to repay part of the gross retention benefit. The amount to be repaid will be in proportion to the incomplete service undertaking. No repayment will be required if separation from the ADF is beyond the member's control; for example, on invalidity retirement, retrenchment or if the member dies. The MSBS has been designed to provide a more equitable range of benefits for all members of the ADF. Nevertheless, it still provides the greatest rewards for those who choose to make a career out of the Australian Defence Force. At the same time, it is a more flexible scheme for it will give members greater choice in the level of contributions they make, whether their benefits are paid as a lump sum or pension.

When members of the ADF leave the defence forces, they get paid a benefit from the MSBS and, unlike the DFRDB, this benefit will be paid no matter how long they have served. It is proposed that the benefit will be in two parts. The first comes from the members' own contributions plus the money they have earned in the investment fund. This will be paid as a lump sum when the person leaves the ADF. The second comes from the Government, which makes a contribution to the member's superannuation of three or four times the money contributed. The Government's contribution will not be invested in a fund.

Under the legislation, members pay a minimum of 5 per cent of their pay to the MSBS. However, they can pay up to 10 per cent of their salary if they seek a larger return on their contributions. I believe that this will be particularly welcomed by those in their later years who are coming towards the end of their career, as they can better afford to increase their benefits on a higher salary and their family commitments are much more limited. It will assist them greatly, I believe, in preparing for their retirement, giving them greater benefits in their retirement.

As is reflected in all modern superannuation schemes, it is the Government's intention to make superannuation an attractive means of planning for one's retirement, so it is important that mild restrictions be placed on accessibility to contributions before a certain age. It is intended that this also be the case with the MSBS, with the Government's contributions to superannuation not being accessible until the member retires from the work force either at or after age 55. If members do retire before turning 55, the Government's contributions will be preserved until the actual age of 55.

Further, in line with the benefits offered to civilians taking up superannuation to give themselves greater independence in retirement, instead of taking the Government's share as a lump sum, members can decide to turn half or more into a more generous pension. The same condition applies to the 3 per cent benefit which is also paid by the Government. This benefit has been paid to members of the Defence Force since 1988 and will be invested in the same fund as the member's actual contributions.

Entitlement to the Government's contribution to superannuation is phased in over seven years. However, entitlement to the full amount of the 3 per cent benefit begins when members actually join the Defence Force. Entitlement to the Government's contribution of superannuation will be phased in over that period and the entitlements have been highlighted again today.

As my time has almost expired, I would like once again to compliment the Minister, his staff and the Department on the efforts they have put into this. It comes back, again, to the efforts of a whole range of people, including Manfred Cross, who was the chairman of the committee of inquiry. I believe, as I said earlier, that this issue should be considered in a bipartisan manner because our defence people work extremely hard. They put up with a lot of things in their working life and indeed there are many problems in their place of work.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support the Military Superannuation and Benefits Bill and the Defence Force Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill. I have had some concerns expressed to me over the level of consultation which the Government has carried out in respect of these two pieces of legislation and I will deal with them shortly. What I want to say firstly is how important this legislation is to members of the Australian Defence Force and particularly to the members of the Survey Regiment in Bendigo, which is in the electorate I represent. That regiment has had a very long and colourful history in Australia, and has a very bold and brilliant future ahead of it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Survey Regiment in Bendigo is located in the historic Fortuna Villa, which was once the home of George Lansell, the Quartz King of Bendigo, who made his fortune on the Bendigo goldfields last century-and it was not an insignificant sum; in fact, it was #3m during the 1880s. Comparing that with someone's wealth today, it is quite significant. The history of the Army Survey Regiment in Bendigo evolved from the Land Headquarters Cartographic Co., which was established in Melbourne in 1941 to meet World War II mapping requirements and moved to its present location in 1942.

In 1955 the Cartographic Co. became the Army Headquarters Survey Regiment and subsequently the Army Survey Regiment. The role of the regiment has essentially remained the same since World War II, except that emphasis is now placed on producing a digital topographic database from which topographic by-products are generated, rather than producing individual maps as was the case previously. I had the pleasure of inviting the Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Farrer (Tim Fischer), to Bendigo and we visited the Army Survey Regiment recently. He was most impressed with the quality of the work which is being done at the Army Survey Regiment.

The Government's proposal to establish a new superannuation benefits scheme for defence personnel has come about over quite a period, and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) has been responsible for much of this work. My concern and the representations that I have had referred to me are in regard to the military superannuation and benefits scheme (MSBS) and the Defence Force retirement and death benefits (DFRDB) scheme.

The honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) was quite correct when he said that I was not a member of this House when the consultation with Defence Force personnel should have occurred. The seat was then held by an Australian Labor Party member and it is an indictment of him that many members of the Survey Regiment at Bendigo believed that the recommendations contained in this brochure had been passed by the Parliament and that the matter was a fait accompli. No consultation on the content of the package or the proposed legislation has occurred until this day; there has been consultation only on which scheme members of the Defence Force may elect to participate in.

The Government's package added to that perception with all of the brochures contained in it. In fact, the message from the Chief of the Defence Force which was submitted in that package to defence personnel-even in the foreword-reads:
From 1 October 1991 until 30 September 1992 you will have the choice of remaining as a member of the DFRDB scheme or transferring to the new Military Superannuation and Benefits Scheme (MSBS).

No mention was made of the Parliament having considered it, or members of the defence forces perhaps offering some input into whether the scheme was what they wanted or not, whether it was appropriate and whether they had the opportunity to put up some suggestions for possible amendments to the scheme. There may have been a need to have some input, and I am sure that they would have liked to have had an input into it. In fact, in all the little pamphlets there are questions and answers on the MSBS. One states:
On 1 October 1991 a new superannuation scheme, the MSBS will start.

Who said it will? It had not been through this Parliament. What about the members of the defence forces having some input into whether that scheme was what they wanted? Did the Government ever talk to them about it once this range of glossy brochures was sent out? Did it just say, `Well, here it is; here is the package. That is what you are going to get'?

I am not knocking the work that was done by the committee which was put together by the Minister. But surely the people who are to become the beneficiaries of that scheme and the participants in that scheme should have had some input and discussion when that brochure came out. They should have been able to contribute their ideas and outline what they wanted. I think that all the information that came out was couched in such terms. Is it any wonder that members of the Survey Regiment at Bendigo believed, in fact, that it was a fait accompli and the legislation had already been passed?

This is typical of the way this Government carries out what it believes to be its consultation processes. There were even people affected who were involved in financial advice areas. I have one advice dated March 1991 which presents a summary so members of the armed forces can compare the various benefits under the scheme and compare one with the other so they can get an idea of exactly what the two schemes entail and make a decision on which way to go.

That leads me to another area where lack of consultation occurred and that was the date of commencement of each of the schemes and the date by which members of the DFRDB scheme would have to make a decision either to stay in the scheme they were in or elect to go into the MSBS. Why the hurry, I ask. I trust that the Minister will be able to answer the question. Why the hurry for the closing date for a decision on whether to join the MSBS or not, because both schemes will be running in parallel for as long as there are members remaining in the Force and wishing to remain in the DFRDB scheme.
