TALK.START.PARA: —Just prior to the dinner break I was discussing the merits of the legislation before the House and the impact that those two pieces of legislation would have on the Army Survey Regiment personnel in Bendigo. That organisation is at the leading edge of technology in Army terms and is an organisation which comprises 25 officers, 284 other ranks and 20 civilians. It does play an extremely important role in the affairs of the Defence Force, work which I have had the opportunity to witness and which I was most impressed with, as was the Deputy Leader of the coalition, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), on his recent visit.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to see this role enhanced in the future with the allocation of the maps storage and distribution centre to the Bendigo area so that not only will those Army maps be produced and printed in Bendigo, but also they will in fact be distributed from there throughout Australia and the world.

I was indicating to the House that the two schemes-the MSBS scheme and the DFRDB scheme-will both run until every member of the Defence Force retirement and death benefits fund has received his total entitlement. In fact, if any confirmation of that is needed, it will be found in the second reading speech of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel when he indicated that the DFRDB scheme will last for many years as, when all existing contributors have retired, there will still be pensioners under the scheme.

I question the need for people who have entered the Defence Force under the terms and conditions of that scheme to make a decision on 1 October or before September 1992 either to stay in that scheme or to go into the new scheme. Members of the Defence Force entered under a set of conditions of service which they quite correctly believed at the time would enable them to make a decision at the time of their choosing, not of the Government's choosing. They now find that they are being forced to make a decision in the next 18 months which will in fact affect their lives and the lives of their families-and not only their working lives, but also into their retirement.

I believe that the Government has not offered enough consultation to these people. I still have to be convinced of the necessity for them to elect to go, particularly when all the mechanics of that superannuation scheme, or the retirement benefits scheme which is in place, will run for many years, and in fact will apply only to the people who are serving in the defence forces at this time.

Anyone joining the defence forces, upon coming in after 1 October 1991 of course, will automatically go into the new scheme and will be aware that that is the only scheme that they can enter. They will not be able to get into the Defence Force retirement and death benefits scheme because that will be closed off to them, so they will know the rules of the game right from recruitment and right from induction into the defence forces. They will know what the acceptable superannuation scheme is to them and the terms and conditions of it. But the people who are in the existing scheme at the moment, of course, will have to make that decision now because they are being forced by the Government to make a decision one way or the other before September 1992.

I would have thought that, when the Government carried out its review of the superannuation schemes that the defence forces were acting under, it would have been an opportune time for it to review the Defence Force retirement and death benefits fund, because the underlying philosophy of the Army and defence forces at the moment is that it should be a young person's Defence Force.

I want to highlight an anomaly which I believe exists under the DFRDB. If, for example, one were to enter the defence forces at 17 to 18 years, did 20 years service and retired between 37 and 38 years of age, one would be eligible for 50 per cent of one's funds as a lump sum, and the balance would be available as a fortnightly pension. Let us say that one decided to retire at 38, having attained the rank of major. The nominal retirement age for a major is 42 years and the compulsory retirement age is 45 years. If one retired at 42 years of age, one would be eligible for 35 per cent as a fortnightly pension but, if one retired at 38-four years earlier-one would lose 3 per cent per annum of that benefit, which would mean a loss of 12 per cent, in that instance, of that fortnightly benefit.

If we are trying to encourage young people into the Defence Force, that is a very heavy penalty to pay should they choose to go out at an earlier age and seek some other form of employment in their career and in their working life. In fact, that condition does not apply to warrant officers. Non-commissioned ranks, in fact, do not have to meet that requirement at all. But a commissioned officer, a major, would suffer the penalty of the reduction of 3 per cent per annum for each year under 42 years of age.

As I say, that does have an impact upon the men and women of the defence forces who are serving under the existing scheme, which is the Defence Force retirement and death benefits scheme. It has an impact upon their families and their children, particularly in these days with the cost of tertiary education. There is an impact upon their spouses and also on their future career prospects. I raise that issue particularly.

It is regrettable that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel is not at the table, but I am sure that the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Crean), who is at the table, will take up those queries I have raised. A number of the issues have caused me concern and have caused concern to the serving personnel within the Army Survey Regiment in Bendigo.

The first issue I raised was that the MSBS scheme was presented to this House and to defence personnel as virtually a fait accompli. Secondly, the dates of election for decision are apparently also a fait accompli. In other words, there is no area to manoeuvre or no opportunity for discussion so that defence personnel may negotiate a position there-either as to the dates of election to decide which scheme they will enter, whether they will remain in the Defence Force retirement and death benefits fund or whether they will in fact enter into the military superannuation and benefits scheme. Thirdly, I raised the anomaly of the 3 per cent penalty for commissioned officers under the DFRDB scheme.

I ask the Minister at the table to bring these matters to the attention of the Minister between now and when this matter will be debated in the Senate. I know that our spokesman for defence personnel, Senator Jocelyn Newman, will be canvassing a number of other issues which quite properly should have been canvassed with the defence personnel before the Bill was presented to this House in the typical style of this Government-a fait accompli: `Here is what you are going to get and you are going to like it'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, wish to speak tonight in this cognate debate dealing with the Defence Force Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill and the Military Superannuation and Benefits Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Like earlier speakers, and noting particularly the comments of the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) and the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis), I am pleased to note a degree of bipartisan support for this legislation. Although both those honourable members sounded very pleased about that, and put it in the context of the bipartisan support for the Australian effort in the Gulf conflict this year, I remind them that we on this side of the House are always prepared to offer that sort of bipartisan support whenever the Government is prepared to accept our point of view. In fact, the Opposition often offers it in this place; yet ultimately it is only on very few occasions that we are able to come together. However, we agree substantially with the Government's treatment of service personnel in this instance, although I can point to many instances over the past 12 months and beyond in which treatment of them has not been as good as it could be. Government members said that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) had done a great job, but in my view there are many deficiencies and lots of ways in which conditions for serving personnel and their families could be improved.

However, we are dealing here with a new superannuation scheme. The Military Superannuation and Benefits Bill effectively establishes a new, equitable scheme for the contribution of superannuation for Australia's regular defence personnel. The Defence Force Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill effectively closes off the old scheme and provides for transfer arrangements from it to the new scheme for those personnel who are serving at the moment. As I said, I join with other members on this side of the House who have expressed their concern that the old scheme, with its inequitable provisions for short term members of the service, was able to continue for so long. I had direct experience of it during the time I was in the Army over 20 years ago, and I recall that during the years I served people were constantly pointing to deficiencies in the scheme. Yet here we are down the track-for me at least some 20 years later-finally coming to the point at which some action is being taken to come up with a superannuation scheme that really meets the needs of, and lives up to the standards expected by, the community in respect of superannuation for service personnel.

In a sense I suppose we are given some insight into the sorts of priorities the Federal Labor Government has in respect of service personnel by the fact that it has taken so long for the Government to rectify an obvious problem. I will put that in some sort of context in a moment. I suppose at this time, Australia just having had personnel serving in an active theatre of war in the Gulf, the spotlight has been placed very firmly on Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel. Honourable members on both sides of the House observed how well Australian service personnel served this country during that conflict, as they have done on so many other occasions. Once again we are extremely proud of them and I do not think we can do too much for them. Therefore I am very pleased to support a Bill which introduces a modern, attractive and, in some respects, generous superannuation scheme.

Those of us who have been closely involved with the defence forces over the years and those of us who are currently members of the Returned Services League of Australia (RSL) and other groups know, as I have already alluded to, that the Government does not have a particularly good record when it comes to meeting the needs of those who served this country or who are currently members of our armed forces. Hardly a day goes by when most honourable members, whether they have direct service involvement or not, do not have veterans coming to see them in their offices. Those veterans are Defence Force personnel who have done a terrific job of serving Australia in a theatre of war, whether that be the Second World War-although some of them are even older than that and served in earlier conflicts-or the Vietnam War, in particular.

Visits from Vietnam veterans are very common. Those men have real and justified grievances about the treatment they are continuing to receive. Quite often, as I go in to bat for them-as I am always willing to do because I have great respect for returned service personnel-I find that the Government, notwithstanding all the tribunal mechanisms in place, is nevertheless not as generous as in my view it might be. I go to great pains to point out that I believe we should be bending over backwards to support those who have very often given so much to serve their country. However, as I mentioned earlier, this legislation, although long overdue, comes one step closer to redressing the imbalance between the treatment of Defence personnel in respect of superannuation and the treatment of the general community.

The Military Superannuation and Benefits Bill is almost entirely based on the recommendations of a report of June 1990 of the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Review Committee, which was chaired by Sir William Cole. I pay tribute to Sir William Cole for the work he and his Committee did in that report. I found that document extremely interesting and very well researched with a significant number of appendices of various sorts. It covered very adequately the needs of service personnel in respect of their superannuation.

The new military superannuation and benefits scheme, which will be in place once this legislation is adopted, has two main components: it has a superannuation component and, very importantly, it has a retention benefits component. Those two aspects of the scheme are extremely desirable. Sir William Cole's report pointed out that the former scheme, the Defence Force retirement and death benefits scheme (DFRDB) as it was known before, failed to meet either, as the report says, `the letter or the spirit' of the occupational superannuation standards which currently regulate all superannuation schemes in both the public and the private sector. In summary, the previous scheme fell a long way short of community standards.
The terms of reference for the review which was carried out by Sir William Cole included:
. . . to recommend changes to the DFRDB scheme or, if applicable, creation of a new scheme.
The Committee, as we now see, subsequently decided upon examination of the Defence Force retirement and death benefit scheme that:
. . . it is not possible to build a superannuation scheme on the foundations of the 1973 scheme which will serve the needs of both the ADF and members into the 21st century.

The major downfall of the old scheme was that while it provided in some respects generous benefits to those who had served for 20 years, nevertheless for those who resigned before the 20-year point there was no employer benefit payable and there was no return in the sense of interest payments on member contributions. Of course, that turned out in many respects to be completely inadequate, especially when one considers that the majority of serving personnel resigned before they had actually completed that 20 years of service.

In working in that fashion, the scheme did not provide incentives to personnel to stay on beyond the 20-year minimum required for a commutable pension. Figures I have seen suggest in fact that up to 40 per cent of those in the forces at that time retire upon reaching 20 years of service. If one looks specifically at some groups of service personnel-for example, the male component of non-commissioned ranks and others; that is, the non-officer ranks-one finds that 80 per cent of serving personnel do not go beyond 20 years service.

That in itself is a concern, but when we look at the new scheme, it is pleasing to note there will be strong incentives to people to serve on. The cost of training service personnel is absolutely enormous, and as personnel who have those years of service up are, in many respects, the most valuable members of the service, there ought to be some very strong in-built encouragement to them to stay on. That would be better than losing those trained and experienced personnel, and having to bear the cost of training new people recruited to fill vacancies.

As technology moves rapidly-we saw the end result of it in the Gulf war-the training costs will be commensurately higher and it will become more difficult to replace experienced people if they are not encouraged to stay on. So there is every reason why people should be encouraged to stay on in the forces and to serve for as long as they possibly can and as long as they are physically able, which is important as well.

The whole context of the review into the Defence Force superannuation scheme was outlined in the terms of reference of the Committee, which required that the Committee was to have particular regard to the nature of Defence Force employment. It was this aspect of the terms of reference that I was most interested to read and then, ultimately, to see the decisions that the Committee had made in the context of those particular terms of reference. As someone who has had the distinct privilege of serving as an Army officer, I am aware-as the report states-that the conditions of service in the ADF are designed to meet the needs of the Force and that these conditions of service differ substantially from those of the broader community.

All military personnel have vastly different lifestyles. I do not think that anyone who has not actually served, or at least been closely associated with military personnel, would have even the slightest understanding of how different it is from a family perspective and from a personal perspective to actually serve in one of the armed services. Each has its particular exigencies and difficulties. I always thought that at least in the Army one had the chance of being home reasonably often; but when I think of Navy personnel in the Gulf situation, I realise that they are away from home on ships for many months at a time, separated from their families. Some of our Navy personnel serving in the Gulf came home to children whom they had not seen before, born during the months that they were away at sea.

The report outlined a number of what it termed as the main characteristics of military service, or service in the Defence Force, not the least of which is the liability for combat operations. One does not join the forces without it being paramount in one's mind, or in the minds of one's family, that there is always the very real risk that one can be ripped apart from one's family to serve on active service. That is something that service personnel live with, it is something that they train for and it is something that they see as part of the job, but it makes them very special.

In terms of the years that they can be used on active service, and bearing in mind that they are limited, it becomes extremely important that the superannuation scheme or the retirement benefits that they will look forward to having at the relatively young retirement ages in place, which may be as young as 45-and being around that age, I know that one feels reasonably fit and able to go on--

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree.

—The honourable member for Macquarie agrees that I am fit and well. At 45 years of age military personnel could be facing retirement. It is not easy to start off a new career at 45 years of age if they have been in the Force for 25 years. For that reason, it is important that superannuation benefits are generous. As the report by Sir William Coles notes, these military personnel are subject to a military discipline code which far exceeds anything that the average community would be used to having to contend with or live under. Both literally and metaphorically they have an extremely regimented way of life; they work long and irregular working hours when they are on duty; they have statutory retiring ages well below community norms; and they have a requirement for high standards of physical fitness. I talk to service personnel very often and they complain-I use that word loosely-about the frequent relocation and separation from family, and the fact that they rarely get the opportunity to put their roots down anywhere. They become a part of a community for a year or two and are then posted on to another area. They have to make new friends and, worse in some respects, their children have to make new friends and go to new schools.

SPEECH.PARA: All of these things add up to making service life difficult and sometimes harsh; therefore, there is every reason why we should be taking this particular action in the legislation of adopting a scheme for retirement and superannuation that makes service life bearable and gives service personnel something to look forward to in their retirement. These conditions are taken account of in the formulation of the latest scheme. As I said before, I am very pleased to commend the Committee for the work it does and to note that the drafting of the scheme takes account of the fact of what service life is really like.

When we look at the background of the former scheme, it is difficult to understand why it has taken so long for this Government-and, I suppose, implicitly, previous governments-to act earlier in respect of coming up with a scheme that was fair, equitable and attractive. In 1983 the then Minister for Defence announced a review of the DFRDB scheme. Before deciding on the form of a review, the Government commissioned a report by the Australian Government Actuary on the long term costs of the scheme. The Actuary reported in September 1984. But the Government did not proceed with the full scale review that we are dealing with tonight: it waited until 1987 before it announced a `limited examination' of the scheme's invalidity and the dependants' benefits scheme, with a view to obtaining greater equity in that scheme. That examination that was talked about in 1987 was still being carried out when the review committee was appointed in 1989.

Four issues prompted the examination that was still unresolved at the time of the review. Firstly, an unacceptable decline in the value of orphans' benefits; secondly, a perception that ADF widows were at a disadvantage compared to widows of members of the Australian Public Service; thirdly, the fact that widows are not entitled to a lump sum benefit; and, finally, the calculation of invalidity benefits on the basis that every member could have achieved 40 years service rather than the industry practice of determining benefits according to a member's actual salary plus the amount of service he or she could actually have completed by normal residence. Four years later these problems have been addressed by the new scheme. Whilst I was prepared to say-I am not holding back; I am being critical-that the Opposition was being bipartisan, it still makes me wonder why it took so long for these obvious inequalities to be fixed up.

One of the main problems with the introduction of a conventional superannuation scheme, in a non-military sense, was that there was a need to ensure that retention rates-we have already noted that they were extremely poor in many respects in the ADF-were not adversely affected. The Cole Committee found that the provision of a commutable life pension benefit to members in the DFRDB scheme had acted as an effective retention magnet, drawing members to serve from the 12-year point to the 20-year point. The occupational superannuation standards require that employer benefits are not to be paid to members of the scheme until after their retirement age or after the age of 55. This made the pension at 20 years service not permissible under the new scheme.

The solution that the Committee came up with-in my view it is the correct solution-was the payment of a lump sum retention benefit, equal to one year's salary, offered upon completion of 15 years service. A number of conditions were to apply for the payment of that particular retention benefit. It is anticipated that this will help maintain the numbers serving 20 years. As I said earlier, I believe it is very important that the scheme does that. It will curb the large resignations at 20 years which have resulted under the old scheme, where benefits were available only if one left the Force.

The Opposition supports this legislation. We ask: why has it taken so long? It is widely supported by military personnel, it is supported without very many major reservations by the RSL and, personally, I am sure that it is better now than never.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased that I am able to be here tonight to speak in this debate on the Military Superannuation and Benefits Bill and the Defence Force Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill, which are two very important Bills. I am very pleased from the point of view that within my electorate I have a substantial number of military bases, not the least being the largest transport base in Australia-the Richmond Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) base, which has about 3,000 members of the forces staffing it. I have the operational headquarters of the RAAF at Glenbrook, just on the boundary of my electorate. I have Nirimba, the Royal Australian Navy apprentice training centre, at one end of my electorate and I also have as part of my electorate the St Marys munitions factory and a number of Army units. Every year in August the largest gathering of Vietnam veterans in their annual parade takes place at Springwood, which is the centre of my electorate. It has become the premier Vietnam veterans get-together occasion in the year.

SPEECH.PARA: Just recently, I had the privilege of being part of the group that welcomed home the medical people from the Gulf. I must commend the staff of Richmond RAAF base, particularly Air Commodore Stan Clarke, the officer in charge, and Group Captain Paul Rasmussan who, at very short notice, were able to put together a welcome home that was worthy and fitting for those people who served so well in the Gulf from the medical support point of view.

It is encouraging to see that the Government has made a major effort to make sure that our forces, from the Navy or wherever, who rendered services in the Gulf, have been given a very fitting return home welcome. The morale of the base at Richmond, which has been a bit low on and off-I have drawn this to the attention of the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Crean) who is at the table-because of the lack of Government attention to the very important needs of our defence forces, was given a tremendous boost in the last week by the fact that at least one of the new tankers was able to be commissioned. The 707 tankers that the RAAF has been able to fit out have been resoundingly successful and a great credit to the people who are responsible for converting these aircraft and also to those who fly them. The reports are that they have been 100 per cent successful, so I congratulate all those concerned at the base with that particular project. I hope that all the money that is required for the completion of the other two-there are four altogether-will be forthcoming at an early date so that the whole fleet will be available in the event of emergencies such as confront us from time to time with regard to refuelling our fighters and so on. I hope it will not be long before we are able to equip these tankers with the appropriate booms to refuel our F111s because the current fit-outs only allow the refuelling of the F18s. I hope the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) will make sure that this is done expeditiously.

A military force has been defined as `a body of men gathered together to correct the mistakes of politicians'. Tonight we are actually seeing the reverse of that. We have a group of politicians together to correct the mistakes done to the military. I am very pleased, as have been all other members who have spoken tonight from both sides of the House, to come in here and support this legislation. I welcome the opportunity to speak in support of what many have said is long overdue legislation related to the improved superannuation benefits of our military defence forces which will be implemented from 1 October this year.

One of the most important features of this legislation is that it provides equitable treatment for the members of the Defence Force who have served for less than 20 years. In the past those who have not met the 20-year criterion under the Defence Force retirement and death benefits (DFRDB) scheme have been penalised. Under the present Defence Force retirement and death benefits scheme, these members receive only a refund of their contributions when they leave the Defence Force. That has been going on for years and years and it is quite unacceptable. They receive no interest on their contributions and no employer benefits except for the 3 per cent productivity benefit. This is contrary to community standards.

I do not want to go into all the details of the Bills before us because I know that Minister has provided every member of the Defence Force-and I commend him for this-with a very comprehensive booklet that explains in minute detail the workings of the new superannuation scheme that will be available to them after 1 October. As I will mention a bit later on, I am also glad that the consultation areas have been put into place so that individual members will be able to seek personal help.

Under the military superannuation and benefits scheme members will have returned to them not just their contributions but also whatever those contributions earn in the MSBS investment fund and they will accrue an entitlement to a substantial employer benefit in addition to the 3 per cent benefit that they are getting.

Another important feature of the Military Superannuation and Benefits Bill is that it provides a retention benefit payable to certain members who complete 15 years continuous full time service and undertake to serve for another five years. This benefit is equal to one year's salary and is taxable. It is a very welcome part of the legislation.

The existing DFRDB scheme does not comply with occupational superannuation standards at all and is not an acceptable scheme by today's standards. However the MSBS, as has been indicated many times already, meets all the occupational superannuation standards. The new scheme appears to be an excellent scheme, very much on a par with the new public sector scheme.

I applaud any legislation or benefit that will encourage our defence personnel to serve longer terms, given the appalling resignation rate that has been taking place over the past few years and which is currently of great concern to the coalition. I have repeatedly expressed in the House my concern over the number of resignations from our defence forces and the very low morale that has existed on and off over the years.

Let us look at the figures since this Government came to power in 1983-I do not bring them up in any supercritical way, but it is important to look at them-when the total of separations was 6,485 in that year. That figure rose steadily to a peak of 9,279 in 1989 and dropped to 8,156 in 1990. In situations such as this I believe in the saying that we have to `praise loudly and blame softly'. I think it is important that we remind the Government of these areas of concern and of the fact that there has been a bit of dilatory behaviour on its part in getting this to this very important stage tonight.

Another disturbing set of figures is the total service personnel in the Australian defence forces. In 1979, the total personnel was 70,198 and in 1989 it was 70,582-almost no growth rate in a country with a growing population and whose defence needs are of vital importance.

I suppose it is comforting that the figure has not dropped any further. It is ominous that there is a lot of talk at the moment about the tremendous cutbacks in actual service personnel and the suggestion that these men and women will be replaced by civilians. This is causing defence personnel a lot of worry because they are not convinced that some of the activities proposed to be handed over to civilians will be the right ones to hand over. Certain aspects of security and refuelling and so on need to be taken into account.

If we look at the figures for the past 12 years we observe that the only time the rate of separation decreases is at a time of recession. The trend appearing today, where we have a drop from 1989 figures to 1990 figures, would indicate that fact. I believe it is a sad indictment of the Government when our defence personnel choose to remain in the services for job security only and are not encouraged to stay on for the right reasons.

One of the other areas in which I believe there ought to be an inquiry is that of postings. Being in an area which has a large base and a large number of RAAF personnel, I am regularly confronted by people who are having difficulty coping with the postings situation. I am not suggesting that each and every case is a meritorious one in terms of the attention it needs. There are occasions when people just do not want to leave; they have established for themselves a comfortable lifestyle in the district and it is inconvenient for them to do so. I come across, more often than I think I ought, members of the Defence Force who have very legitimate grievances on the way their postings have been handled. I mention that almost in passing.
The other day I was alarmed when a headline in the Sydney Morning Herald of 21 March read, `Richmond may go in RAAF shake up'. The report stated:
Richmond RAAF base may be closed and 7,000 jobs cut or given to civilians in a major reorganisation of Australia's air force.

I am not suggesting that those 7,000 jobs are coming from Richmond, but that was part of the news item on that day. Of course many of those jobs will be lost from the Richmond RAAF base. The report went on to state:
Some service officers are concerned that permanent damage will be done to Australia's military capability by the proposed changes, without any real debate about the alternatives.

A disturbing aspect of the report was that the Government neglected to consider the effects of its decision on the people. We all know that the human factor cannot be ignored. A number of speakers have mentioned tonight and this afternoon that there has not, it appears, been enough consultation on some of the recent decisions that have been made with regard to the defence forces.

People join the Defence Force for a career and job security and they now find that the Government may be about to axe 7,000 of them. Is it any wonder that morale has reached a fairly low level in our defence forces? I know that this is the case from my weekly discussions with many members of the various defence forces.

I support the legislation before us today. As I said earlier, I will support any legislation that will improve the lot of our defence personnel. It is important that, when we consider this legislation, all Defence Force members receive individual consultation on what is best for them for their future regarding the transfer option. I mentioned earlier in my speech that this was one of the commendable aspects of the Minister's implementation of this very important piece of legislation. The Opposition recommends that we support the passage of this legislation, which is based almost entirely on the recommendations of Sir William Cole's report of June 1990. That report and the Minister's implementation of its recommendations is more than welcome.

I conclude by commending the Government and the Minister on bringing these Bills before the House and for the fact that this has been done on the basis of the recommendations of the report, almost in their entirety. They have been greeted with a lot of pleasure and acceptance from the defence forces throughout Australia, and particularly by people in my electorate who have mentioned their satisfaction with the superannuation scheme now being offered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BILNEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In summing up the debate, perhaps I should begin by thanking those who have contributed to the debate on these very important pieces of legislation-the Military Superannuation and Benefits Bill and the Defence Force Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill. While I was not able to be in the House for much of the time, through the marvels of modern communication I was able to follow much of what was said. I agree with a lot of what has been said. I endorse, in particular, the complimentary remarks made by most speakers about the job done by the committee of inquiry, Sir William Cole, John Cardon and a retired major-general, Derek Deighton. They did a wonderful job. The fact that the Opposition is supporting these Bills, and with very little in the way of cavilling about their provisions, is an indication that the job the committee did was very thorough.

SPEECH.PARA: It is in that context that I would like to take up points that were made by the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid), and perhaps by other speakers in the debate, about the degree of consultation that took place. On behalf of the review committee, and indeed the Government, I say that those criticisms seem to me to be peculiarly ill-founded. There was most extensive consultation with the Australian Defence Force (ADF) and its individual members. As evidence of that, the advertisements which were placed in all major newspapers attracted some 767 written submissions. The review committee toured all major ADF bases and spoke, I understand, to well over 1,000 personnel. It had extensive liaison with the Chiefs of Staff Committee, as I know because I was in on the latter part of that. Of course, it also consulted with the major interest groups, including the Returned Services League, the Regular Defence Force Welfare Association and the Armed Forces Federation of Australia. It seems to me an odd criticism, and an unfounded one to make, that the review committee did not consult extensively and indeed that that process will not continue as we approach the implementation phase.

It is a provision of the Military Superannuation and Benefits Bill that a large sum of money-from recollection over $4m-has been set aside for an information effort designed to give real substance to the undertaking by the Government that every member of the ADF will have all the facts at his or her command before he or she is called upon to elect either to stay in the existing scheme or transfer to the new military superannuation and benefits scheme.

Perhaps in that context I ought to mention another objection which I heard raised in the debate, namely, the supposed need to have an expiry date for transferees. The Government feels-I do not believe that there is any objection within the ADF to this either-that 12 months is sufficient time to communicate to people the information which is necessary before they decide to make the election either to stay with the Defence Force retirement and death benefits (DFRB) scheme or go into the new scheme.

I point out that if there were an open-ended transfer arrangement there would also need to be an open-ended communication campaign. It would be expensive. I am certain that within 12 months that information campaign will be effective. It embodies some quite innovative concepts. Every individual member of the ADF will receive a package which will enable him or her to put in information about his or her own particular situation and to work out whether it is best to transfer or not.

I think those are the main points of criticism which have been raised so far as the Bill is concerned. I guess that I would have more to do with actual members of the ADF than any other member of this House, but I do not hear those criticisms when I go around the bases and I think that those who have raised them do so as much out of ignorance of the Bill and how its proposals are being received than anything else.

I would not like to conclude without saying a couple of other things. Firstly, some complimentary remarks were made about Manfred Cross, the former member for Brisbane, and his work in relation to this legislation. In that context, I should widen those compliments to embrace the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, a committee for which I still have fond affection and which in many ways was the genesis of at least the need to review the old DFRDB scheme.

A second and quite personal thing is that Major-General Deighton, a former member of the review committee, is at present seriously ill in Melbourne. I think that all members of this House would want me to pass on their best wishes for a speedy recovery and for fortitude in the difficult times that lie ahead for him.

I do not have much to say in summing up the debate except again to thank those who participated in it and to assure them that the confidence which both the Opposition and the Government have placed in the measures embodied in this Bill is well founded. In that context I want to refer to the remarks of the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster), who has just resumed his seat, about morale in the ADF. Morale in the ADF is, I would say, extremely high at the present time and will become higher as a result of the moves towards greater professionalism in the ADF which this Government will be making and announcing in the next couple of months.

This part of the improvement to conditions of service will be a large element of that. This Government has set itself to improve conditions across the board for serving members of the ADF and retired members of the ADF, and this is very much a part of that effort. From the fact that, over the last decade, our resignation rate from the ADF has been historically low and our recruitment rates have been historically high, I know that people are voting with their feet, and they are voting for beneficial changes of the kind embodied in this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLachlan Mr I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition has no objection to the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 and the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1991 being debated cognately. The changes proposed under the rather innocuous and bland titles of these two Bills essentially represent the end of the old protectionist era in Australia. After years of debate, the arguments against protection of one sector at the expense of another or more efficient sector, and indeed ultimately at the cost of those who are supposed to gain, seem at least to have won the day-at least, this day.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last few months we have heard much in this House from various Government members about who has actually brought that about. At this stage it is worth reminding honourable members that this debate has been going on for some years. Certain organisations, including certain farming organisations, have been at the leading edge of that debate. They realised many years ago that if somebody is being protected in this country, then someone else in this country is paying for it. There are now not too many who will argue that protection against imports has served Australia well. These days even the manufacturers concede this. Efficient exporters who have been forced to pay higher costs for inputs and factors of production have been penalised. The manufacturing sector has become fragmented and inward oriented. Nor is it a coincidence that the sector is dominated by foreign interests, which have in the past set up here presumably to help themselves behind the tariff walls. The ultimate cost of this has appeared to be, and probably has been, a great loss of jobs, especially well paying jobs, and ultimately lower living standards.

As we know, the Industry Commission estimates that the removal of protection will increase national income by about $4 billion a year. I suspect that this is a conservative estimate. The major benefit to producers of lower protection will be the radical change in attitudes as producers are compelled to meet the market requirements. However, whilst the coalition agrees with the general thrust of the Government's proposal in these two Bills-indeed, the coalition set the agenda last year when it called for phased reductions of all industry protection to, at most, negligible levels by the year 2000-it believes that the Government has failed completely to deliver on the other side of the reform ledger.

The Government has broken its commitment to industry to tackle other reform areas which would ensure cost reductions and give industry a chance on world markets. The 12 March statement, for example, effectively ignored waterfront and transport reform. It did not deal with industrial relations reform. It proposed only marginal reductions in the indirect tax burden on business. Stung, I suppose, by industry's outrage at this omission, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has been forced at least to pay lip-service to some areas of reform. The trans-Tasman shipping agreement which stultifies car exports to New Zealand is an example. However, industry has heard all this talk before, and it does not believe many of the Government's promises.

The Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), has actually signalled retrograde action to remove common law and secondary boycott remedies against unjustified industrial action. This is an extraordinarily retrograde step. Clearly, the Government is also becoming nervous about the implications of the recent Troubleshooters judgment and, it seems, is possibly considering action to plug that `loophole' which allows individual choice should the decision be upheld. To the extent that there are any Government initiatives in the industrial relations area, they will be seen to be taking us backwards.

Rail reform proposals are foundering and waterfront reform is progressing at a snail's pace. This failure to deliver the micro-economic reform which everyone now agrees must take place-one cannot even get an argument about it-coupled with what Senator Button said last week when he described Australia as being in deep recession, will mean that thousands of enterprises faced with lower assistance will not be able to meet the challenge of increased international competition and will simply close their doors, whether they are potentially efficient or not; the reason being, of course, that it seems the Government does not intend to deliver the reforms necessary to keep those doors open.

Manufacturing has been hit hard by this recession. The Australian Bureau of Statistics estimates that 48,000 manufacturing jobs have been lost in the three months since December 1990. The Australian Chamber of Manufactures predicts that this number will at least be doubled by the end of the year. Some 11,000 jobs have been lost in the textile, clothing and footwear sectors alone. I doubt that anyone would claim that all these jobs and all these businesses that are either contracting or closing down are inefficient. Senator Button has acknowledged that many of these businesses are good. How anybody can cope with interest rates that have been running at retail levels of over 20 per cent for most of the last five years, I do not know.

I do not think it is possible for businesses to be so profitable that they can pay these sorts of retail rates, make a profit, pay tax and still have something left over to repay principal. Of course, what has happened to many of these businesses is that they have been accumulating debt and rolling interest into further debt, until finally the end has come when a recession, such as the one we have now, turns up causing their markets to disappear. These same businesses are expected by the Government to cope with further cuts in assistance, without any guarantee from Government to address the impediments they must confront every day.

The Business Council of Australia says that we have arrangements in place in Australia today which mean that we pay between 20 per cent and 50 per cent more than our overseas competitors for coastal shipping, construction costs, international shipping, waterfront services, rail transport, international shipping, international aviation, road transport, post and telecommunications, electricity supply and water. One almost runs out of breath reading out the list and that list is not exhaustive. For instance, the list ignores the pervasive cost of centralised industrial relations arrangements which, according to the Business Council, means that productivity in Australian enterprises is, on average, 25 per cent below their overseas counterparts. It ignores high interest rates and the cost of delays and uncertainty in the environmental approval procedures.

So by taking away protection unilaterally and failing to guarantee to address these other impediments at the same time, the Government has helped in the process of making Australia potentially a less attractive place to do business. Therefore, worthwhile as those protection cuts may be, and are, for the reason that I outlined at the outset, the fact is that if we want a strong manufacturing sector in this country we must do more than simply cut tariffs. Just as we found out that deregulation of the currency in combination with a centralised wages system could spell disaster, so too the introduction of a competitive product market without giving producers the means to compete could be less than successful.

That is why the coalition is committed absolutely to reducing industry protection, at the same time as implementing those comprehensive micro-economic reforms. Done together, the gains to the community will be maximised. On the other hand, the Government's one-sided approach seems to us unnecessarily to be making the going tougher here than anywhere else. The costs will be very tangible in lost investment, fewer job opportunities and lesser wealth creation in Australia.

Looking on the brighter side, the pressure on this Government to tackle these problems will intensify. That has happened since the industry statement. Industry will demand much lower inflation; it will demand genuine competition in the labour market; it will demand more efficient transport and telecommunication services, and so on. Industry knows only too well that the benefits from such reform, on current estimates, are of the order of $40 billion extra dollars of Australian income each year. That would far outweigh any perceived benefits from industry assistance at present.

Indeed, as I have said on a number of occasions, I think that a major unintended consequence of the 12 March statement will be the end of the centralised wage fixing system as we know it; the end of its influence throughout every sector of the economy. The system supported by the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Crean), who is at the table, will go as an unintended consequence of the 12 March statement. The Minister may not agree, but the fact is that in an increased competitive environment we are now getting to the situation where it is illogical for third parties to make decisions which influence the rewards for people in workplaces, which they have never even seen and, in many cases, have no chance of understanding.

Of course, to rely on industry to eke out reforms from an unwilling Government which has lost its nerve or to devote valuable resources to contrive a way through the obstacles seems to me to be an unnecessary, tortuous and costly approach. In any case, it will take too long. Meanwhile the dollars will be flying elsewhere. The longer it takes to extract reform from the Government, the greater the risk that increasingly frustrated manufacturers will demand new forms of assistance. We do not want this; in fact, I do not think any of us in this chamber-there may be one or two-wants that. An increasingly desperate Government might just buckle at the pressure. The proposed citric acid bounty which was debated in this place last week set an unwelcome precedent along these lines. One could not blame the manufacturers if they felt that this was an easier route than getting the Government to agree, for example, to genuine enterprise-based industrial relations.

So whilst the two Bills before the House mean the import protection battle for the time being at least has been won, the Government's failure to tackle micro-economic reforms increases the risk that the war on Government assistance will not be. Because of it, the economy could be doubly cursed. I am not saying that the Minister is not attempting to do something, but I am putting it to him that we in Australia, in an international comparative sense, are failing. The Minister, for his part on his side of the House, is in charge of that failure.

In dealing with the major provisions of the Bills, first let me turn to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill-which implements, amongst other things, general tariff reductions announced by the Government on 12 March. The coalition supports the proposed general reductions to bring virtually all manufacturing tariffs to 5 per cent by July 1996. This is in line with our announcement last year to reduce all industry protection to, at most, negligible levels by the end of the century. I stress again, however, that our commitment included an equally absolute commitment to tackle micro-economic reforms so that industry would be given the opportunity to meet the challenge of lower industry assistance, and I shall be moving a second reading amendment, which is being circulated, urging the Government to reconsider its unbalanced approach.

Australian industry deserves at the very least an even chance. This Bill also implements announced tariff reductions for the automotive and textile, clothing and footwear (TCF) sectors. Broadly speaking, the automotive sector tariff will be phased down from 35 per cent in 1992 to 15 per cent by the year 2000. In the TCF sector, quotas will be abolished two years ahead of schedule and the tariff level applying by the year 2000 will be 25 per cent for most clothing, 15 per cent for footwear and fabrics and 10 per cent for footwear parts and certain non-quota goods. The coalition does not oppose these reductions but, whilst we do not, I wish to make it clear that our preference is to remove all special industry arrangements by the end of the century; in other words, these two sectors should receive the same level of assistance as the rest of manufacturing industry by 2000, given that we will introduce the much needed micro-economic reforms before then.

I am convinced that participants in the car industry, for example, appreciate that whatever level of tariff protection they receive-and they have told me this many times-their industry will not stand a chance without these reforms. The industry's joint submission to the Industry Commission inquiry made this point very clearly. At the moment Australia is ranked third last as a destination for investment in the car industry. It is just above Brazil and Mexico. Japan, Germany, the United States, Taiwan, Canada, Malaysia, the United Kingdom and Korea score above us. With the 34 per cent or 35 per cent annual turnover in the motor car industry, what could one expect? It is a quite disgraceful set of circumstances. In fact, I am surprised that the industry does as well as it does with that level of turnover. So, if tariffs are to be cut without further comprehensive micro-economic reforms, we will slide further down this list-if there is any further to go.

On the other hand, if we really were to address these economy-wide impediments, it is estimated Australia could improve its ranking to third place behind Japan and Germany. That must be worth having a go at; it must be worth making an attempt to get ourselves up the ladder into a position as healthy and positive as that would be. The chief executives of two of the major car companies have told me they could fix their labour cost disadvantage problems if they had the means to deal directly with their work forces without outside interference. The Industry Commission tells us that transport reform alone would increase the industry's output by more than 4 per cent.

I am almost sure that the situation for textiles, clothing and footwear would be similar, although I acknowledge that that sector will require more restructuring than the car industry. I commend the car industry for struggling with its problem over the last few years and, as many people know, it has already undertaken a good part of that task. So in these two sectors the coalition considers that by failing to attack those reforms the Government is badly letting down those sectors and it is also letting down the economy and Australian consumers.

We could have faster reduction in protection; we could have stronger industries and lower prices simultaneously, but it seems this country under this Government has rejected this option. On a brighter note, the Government has adopted the coalition's proposal to freeze the developing country preference rate for the so-called newly industrialised countries-Hong Kong, Taiwan, Singapore and Korea. Their preferential rate will be frozen. As the general tariff rate falls, the preference margin will also fall until it reaches zero, and the general tariff rate will then apply to these countries.

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill also implements the proposed TCF import credit scheme, which is a somewhat less generous version of the automotive industry's export facilitation scheme. This Bill establishes the by-law to allow duty free entry of goods under the scheme. It is not the lack of generosity that we are criticising, but we know the distortions that such a scheme creates. We have said before in this place that we support the facilitation arrangements in the car industry only because we know that, as the tariffs come down, so will the benefit of facilitation. The coalition will be moving an amendment to delete this new by-law because we, as a matter of principle, oppose the extension of export credit schemes beyond the car industry. The only reason we accept continuation of export facilitation in that industry is that it is there, as I said just now, and it will come down as tariffs come down; and it would be too disruptive to withdraw it now.

I will expand on the reasons for our amendment in the committee stage of this Bill but I would point out that many commentators have pointed to the Industry Commission's recommendation for the continuation of export facilitation in the car industry as a general endorsement of the whole concept. In my view, this interpretation is wrong. The Commission was at pains to point out that, in principle, it opposed such schemes because they created distortions between industries and its recommendation was simply based on the fact that to change arrangements at the same time as the tariff was being phased down would be too disruptive-but no doubt I will have an opportunity to explore these arguments further at a later stage in the debate.

Other changes in this Bill include expanded duty free provisions for importation of capital equipment, which the coalition supports. We also support a range of other proposed changes for duty free importation of aluminised steel used in the manufacture of automotive muffler exhaust systems, and the duty free entry of wheelchairs, defibrillators and heart pacemakers, printed circuit boards, and machine tools and parts for working advanced materials.

The Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill essentially complements the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill, implementing certain proposed reductions in textile bounty rates to zero by 1995. The Bill also extends the metal working machine tools and robots bounty until 1997, with bounty rates progressively phased down to 5 per cent by 1996.

The coalition supports the extension of the bounty at reducing rates, as this is consistent with our policy of gradual, predictable reductions in industry protection. Coverage of the computer bounty is to be extended to incorporate local production of printed circuit boards. We do not oppose this change, firstly, because bounties are less distorting than tariffs and, secondly, because the increased costs of the bounty will be accommodated by a one percentage point reduction in the bounty rate. The Bill also proposes to insert into each of the bounties already mentioned, plus the book bounty, a minimum threshold level under which the bounty will not be paid.

I understand that the Government will be moving deletion of the proposed increase in the book bounty threshold because this change would result in a major dislocation in the industry. The coalition welcomes this belated recognition of the effect on this industry at least. We will also, however, be moving an amendment to delete insertion of minimum thresholds in each of the five remaining bounties because the coalition does not believe that the size of an operation indicates its efficiency. If we are going to provide a bounty, surely to ex-communicate somebody from the benefit by reasons of his smallness seems quite illogical and not commercial. We have given this matter serious consideration, after discussions with the Minister's office and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. However, we remain of the view that removal of bounty to small operators could reduce the amount of competition in these industries.

Overall, as I indicated at the outset, the coalition will not oppose these Bills and, indeed, we recognise their significance in bringing to an end the very costly protectionist era in this country. Regrettably, however, the Government is taking a most disruptive and unnecessarily costly approach to achieve this by not tackling the economy-wide reforms. Honourable members will hear those words and sentiments spoken all over this country day by day, hour by hour. It is not merely for us to stand up here and say it without support. It is absolutely universally felt around business as more and more people understand what will happen to them when one side of the ledger only is brought about. Therefore, as I have already outlined, to the motion that the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill be read a second time I will be moving an amendment calling on the Government to change its approach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating two Bills cognately tonight-the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill and the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill. There is also an amendment that I oppose totally which was foreshadowed by the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), the shadow Minister for industry and commerce. I will speak on that later.

SPEECH.PARA: Basically the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill has four general categories-that is, amendments to the three textiles, clothing and footwear bounties; amendments to the metal working machine tools and robots bounty; amendments to the computer bounty to widen its coverage to include printed circuit boards which will be offset by a slight reduction in bounty rates over the life of the bounty; and amendments to five bounties to introduce minimal annual production threshold levels before bounty may be claimed and an amendment to one bounty to increase the minimum claim level.

Of course, the idea is to help create a more internationally competitive textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF) sector. The textile yarn bounty will be phased from 30 per cent value-added on 1 July 1992 to zero by 1 July 1995 and replaced by a 5 per cent tariff; the bed sheeting bounty will be extended to 30 June 1995 without review, but will phase down from 16c per square metre on 1 July 1992 to zero by 1 July 1995; and the bounty on textile printing will phase down to zero by 1 July 1995. The amendments to the Bounty (Metal Working Machines and Robots) Act 1985 provide for the continuation of bounty assistance for local production of certain machine tools and robots from 1 July 1991 to 30 June 1997.

In addition, there are amendments to the computers bounty. The amendments to the Bounty (Computers) Act 1984 provide for the widening of the computer bounty to include local manufacture of printed circuit boards from 1 July 1991 and, at the same time, the tariff on imported printed circuit boards is being made free. There are also amendments to minimum annual thresholds. The total in the bounty Bill in regard to the financial impact is a savings for the period 1992-95. As a result of the accelerated phase-down in bounty rates for the three textile yarn bounties, it is approximately $56m at current prices. The proposed amendments extending the machine tools and robots bounty beyond this financial year are expected to result in an overall cost to 1 July 1997 of $38.6m at current prices, and the bounty is expected to cost $15m in 1991-92 at current prices. This will phase down to around $2m per year by 1996-97.

The amendments to the computers bounty to widen its coverage to include printed circuit boards as from 1 July 1992 will be accommodated as far as possible within the current Budget forecasts by reducing the schedule bounty rates by one percentage point as from the 1992-93 financial year. Total bounty outlays are therefore forecast to remain at $50.1m in 1991-92, $49.5m in 1992-93 and $48.7m in 1993-94. The threshold amendments have no financial implications as they are directed at creating efficiencies within the various industries, rather than being aimed at specific cost savings.

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill gives effect to the tariff changes that were announced in the industry statement. The idea, of course, is that major tariff changes will fulfil the Government's commitment to continue beyond 1992 the tariff reforms that were originally initiated in 1988. The Bill contains measures relating to general tariff rates and measures for the specific industry sectors of agriculture, passenger motor vehicles and textiles, clothing and footwear.

Tariff assistance for agricultural industries will phase down after 1992 at the same rate as the general manufacturing sector to 5 per cent by 1 July 1996 with the following exceptions. Vegetable products, which are phasing down to a tariff of 10 per cent by 1 July 1994, will continue to phase down at the same rate as the general manufacturing sector to 5 per cent by 1 January 1998. Post-1992 assistance arrangements for the dairy, sugar and tobacco growing industries will be determined in the context of Industry Commission inquiries. An inquiry into the dairy industry is currently under way; an inquiry into sugar will commence in the near future; and tobacco growing will be reviewed in 1993.

In the interim, assistance for the sugar industry should be brought back within the spirit of the 1998 decision to reduce general tariffs to a maximum of 15 per cent ad valorem equivalent by 1 July 1992. Accordingly, it is proposed to adjust the specific tariff rate for raw and refined sugar to $76 per tonne at 1 July 1991 and to $55 per tonne at 1 July 1992. By maintaining a specific tariff rate, the sugar industry will remain protected in the event of low world prices over this period.

The new arrangements for passenger motor vehicles maintain the successful policy direction already established by continuing the existing rate of tariff reduction. The new arrangements retain the current schedule for tariff reduction until December 1992 and, from January 1993, tariffs on passenger motor vehicles and original equipment components will continue to be reduced at the current rate of 2.5 per cent per year, reaching 15 per cent by the year 2000. Tariffs on light commercial and four-wheel drive vehicles as well as on components for these vehicles will be reduced from 15 per cent in line with the general tariff reductions.

Tariffs on replacement components for passenger motor vehicles will be maintained at 15 per cent until 30 December 2000. In line with these objectives all quotas will be terminated on 1 March 1993, and out of quota duty rates currently programmed for 1 March 1992 will be halved.

Tariff rates will be reduced as follows: apparel and certain finished textiles to phase down by 25 per cent by 1 July 2000; footwear, cotton sheeting and fabrics to phase down to 15 per cent by 1 July 2000; footwear parts and existing non-quota textile, clothing and footwear goods to phase down by 10 per cent by 1 July 2000; and TCF goods already having rates of 15 per cent to phase down in line with general reductions for general manufacturing tariffs. The textile yarn bounty will be phased from 30 per cent value added on 1 July. (Quorum formed). Because my time has been shortened, I will have to reduce the time to go through all the complicated procedures of the two tariff Bills.

I would like now to get to the point raised by the honourable member for Barker, who demonstrated the difference between our side of the House and the other side. Anyone who thinks there is no difference need only look at these ridiculous amendments. Nothing has changed in 100 years. There is still on the other side of the House a philosophical hatred of organised labour; there is still a view that people should be held down, kept out, and should work for nothing. The squattocracy is still alive and well on the other side of the House. These amendments demonstrate that.

Also, of course, in the criticism that the honourable member for Barker made in regard to the Government not moving quickly enough, he forgot to mention that for 40 years we had the McEwen and Menzies tariff monkey around our neck and around the farmers' necks. While we have been the only Government that has had the courage to throw that off, he is sitting back saying, `Well, seeing you have climbed Mount Everest, why don't you climb to the moon?'. If we went to the moon those opposite would want us to go to Mars. Quite frankly, they have never had the courage in government to do anything, and they demonstrated today that they do not even have the courage in opposition to back up the claims they have made.

One of the most positive aspects to come out of these tariff reductions is a direct benefit to agriculture of between $350m and $400m in a reduction of import costs. I see on the speakers list the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss), an avid protectionist who has run around his whole electorate supporting the cargo cult mentality of his corrupt State colleagues in Queensland. I wonder whether he will have the courage here to support the free market propositions that those in the Liberal Party, his so-called coalition brothers, support and then have the courage to go back to Kingaroy and tell his paper and his editor-who is also a cargo cultist-the real facts and realities of life. We still have the Laurel and Hardy of Queensland politics, little Billy O'Chee and big Ronnie Boswell, running around Queensland, talking about the narrow, tunnel vision backwoods regulators--

TALK.START.PARA: —Abbott and Costello.

—Abbott and Costello, as the honourable member for Brisbane says-the same strategy with about as much intelligence. Of course, the sad thing is their approach when we come to the really tough issues, like reducing the tariff on sugar. As I have said before and will say again, as the only sugar producer in this House, that it gives an opportunity for end users of sugar to actually get on the front foot and become competitive. SPEECH.PARA: At the same time, I am very pleased to be able to read out what the Queensland cane growers have said about our decisions in the industry statement:
Cane growers may save close to $2 million each year in new sales tax exemptions for agriculture.

This was out of the industry statement and out of the decisions that this Government made. I wonder again whether the honourable member for Wide Bay, who knows a little about sugar-at least he knows that one puts sugar in one's tea-is prepared to go out and actually tell his constituents in Maryborough, the Maryborough sugar growers, that they will be better off because of this Government's decisions to broaden the exemptions on wholesale tax, part of this whole package that we are talking about tonight.

I would like to get back to some of the criticisms that the honourable member for Barker made about waterfront reform. Let us not forget that for 40 years, again, it was a sacred cow as far as the conservative parties were concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —They set it up.

—Not only did they set it up, as the honourable member for Parramatta said, but they sat on their hands and watched inefficiency grow. This Government has taken it on. It will take more than eight or nine years to change 40 years of sloth, but we are getting there.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to coastal shipping, what the honourable member for Barker forgets is that some of the ships we now have in commission have technology which cannot reduce manning levels overnight, unless we want to run them onto the Barrier Reef and crash them. The technology is such that certain manning levels are needed. Even with that, we are reducing manning levels as we can, post the Crawford report.

In regard to Telecom, of course, the honourable member was critical of telecommunications-`Let us not forget that if you are in America you can get a free local call'. The problem is that it is only a couple of miles. There is no free local call like the standard system across Australia-the best system in the world. Along with OTC, we are not only going to show that, but we will also earn a lot of export dollars for Australia.

Again, those opposite have this philosophical view that anything that is owned by Australia-like Telecom, which we are proud of-has to be got rid of. We have to sell the silver as far as the other side is concerned. We have sold the things we view as not conducive to being efficient. What those opposite want to do is sell the goodies, the real things that are of long term benefit to Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —To their mates.

—Exactly. We have seen that today. Who was going to get the biggest benefit out of the abolition of the capital gains tax? It was the former president of the Liberal Party. And they have the hide to come in here and talk about accountability!

SPEECH.PARA: When we get back to centralised wage fixing, it gets back to the old story of capital versus labour, greed versus manhood. That is what it is all about. As I said the other week, in May we will stand under an old tree in Barcaldine and remember the men and women who 100 years ago formed the Australian Labor Party, which actually gave working men and women an opportunity to have a bit of dignity and to get a decent wage.
