One could not get a job in the sugar industry in Queensland because it was worked by slave labour.

The Australian Labor Party and organised labour got rid of that. If centralised wage fixing was to go and voluntary agreements were to come in, there would be a return to exactly what existed 100 years ago. Let us not forget that the philosophy of those on the other side of this House is no different now from what it was 100 years or 200 years ago; whether it was in Mississippi in 1855 or in the Queensland sugar industry in 1906, nothing has changed. The members on the Opposition side represent greed; they are nothing more than butlers for the rich and they will never change. When we come to fighting on the issues, we only have to look at these amendments. That is why members opposite will stay on the other side of the House.

Not only do they want to abolish award conditions which have been fought for, but also they have the hide to say that workers do not need a third party. Members opposite should tell a worker on a council or in a sawmill how he can go into an industrial commission with no funds and argue about improving his conditions. Do members opposite have the audacity to tell me that someone out of the goodness of his heart will give that worker the safety conditions, the superannuation or the flow-on conditions which have been gained through the union movement? At the same time as we hear this nonsense about a blow-out in wages, let us not forget that we have had a reduction of 10 per cent in real terms of non-farm unit labour costs under the Federal Labor Government. Under the conservatives we saw the other side of the fence; we saw the big squatter, Malcolm Fraser, come in and blow out wages by 17 per cent in 12 months. That is how much members opposite know about industrial relations.

The other real beauty is amendment (1) (d), the introduction of a comprehensive goods and services tax; in other words, a tax on false teeth for the aged, a tax on glasses, a tax on bread and a tax on food for kids and for working families. Workers still have to eat the same as millionaires do, but a goods and services tax will not worry someone who has caviar or whisky, because that person can afford the little bit extra. But what about the working men and women of this country? What about the farmers who have to pay a flow-on right across the board, which will escalate?

On top of that the Opposition would abolish Medicare-a system that every working man and woman, every farmer and every pensioner need today. Members opposite have the hide to come in here to show that policy. Not only that, they also think that the people of Australia will actually accept this as a blueprint for the future. This is just a return to the Dark Ages. That is why members opposite will stay on the other side of the House and that is why I commend these Bills to the House, Bills that show a bit of courage and vision. All these amendments show is a regression to what existed prior to the formation of the Labor Party and the trade union movement. Over the next two years it will be very easy to take on the Opposition and beat it, because the Opposition has not changed and will never change. Opposition members might have better clothes and might be more eloquent than our members, but one thing that does not alter is the gulf between greed on the one hand and manhood and womanhood on the other. It is good to be able to stand on this side of the House and to represent manhood and womanhood and to oppose greed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a fighting speech from the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice), who accused members of the Opposition of having better clothes than members of the Australian Labor Party, which boasts the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and his Italian suits.

SPEECH.PARA: Actually the gist of the argument of the honourable member for Hinkler was that we on this side of the House are the parties of greed and that somehow the party on the other side of the House is not. One really hears this message a lot from the Australian Labor Party. The honourable member for Hinkler then went on to argue that during its term in office the Labor Party has reduced real wages to workers by 10 per cent, whereas under the Fraser Government wages had risen; I think he used the figure of 17 per cent. To accuse the Opposition of being anti-worker on the one hand and on the other to say that Labor, the party of the workers, has slashed workers' wages while the Liberals under Malcolm Fraser increased them, will be very hard for ordinary workers in this country to understand as they see their living standards plunge. Furthermore, the irony of the claim that other parties are the parties of greed when it is the Labor Party itself that has wooed the fast-money entrepreneurs of Western Australia-not the least being Laurie Connell and Alan Bond-will not be lost on the Australian people.

The debate this evening is not altogether about those issues; it is about the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill and the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill, which were both introduced by the Government. As the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) said earlier in the evening, these Bills in general continue the process of reducing levels of protection in Australia. One often hears from honourable members on the other side of the House the argument that the Labor Party reduced protection while our side of politics always favoured high levels of protection in years gone by. I take this opportunity to correct the record; that is not true. At the turn of the century the Labor Party campaigned on four basic policies; I will not go through all of them, although one of them was a White Australia policy, which honourable members opposite might be interested to note, while another was high protection. It was Charles Cameron Kingston, who-although not a member of the Labor Party, stood proudly by Labor-as the first Minister for Trade and Customs in this country, established the regime of high protection. That is what Labor gave Australia.

When the Fraser Government-and the Treasurer in particular never mentions this-progressively reduced the general rate of tariff protection in this country, the person who squealed the loudest was none other than the then President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and now Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). He squealed about the world of lower protection that the Fraser Government was imposing on Australia and now he boasts that Labor is the party which brings Australia lower protection.

I will not labour the point except to say that if we are to have a debate about history in this chamber, we need to get the facts right; we need to examine the record of the Labor Party on the issue of protection. If honourable members examine its record, they will find that Labor was the architect of protection in Australia-not Jack McEwen many years later. It was the old Labor regime so soon after its birth 100 years ago that created the whole edifice of protection in Australia. Members of the Labor Party should never forget that; if they are proud of the history of Labor, they ought to know something about that history and not just live in a fairyland world of myths, which seems to be so much of what dominates the Labor Party.

This legislation, which in general reduces protection, is warmly welcomed by members on this side of the House. Certainly I appreciate there is bipartisan support for the process of dismantling Australia's high levels of protection, liberalising our economy and, in the process, internationalising and helping to integrate it within the Asia-Pacific region. Members on this side of the House are very committed to that and to a continuation of that process and, after the next election, to reducing tariffs to negligible levels by the year 2000.

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1991, which is the first of these two Bills, reduces the general rate of manufacturing protection post-1992 to 5 per cent by July 1996. That is very welcome. It also phases out the developing country preferences for Hong Kong, Singapore, Taiwan and Korea. I could understand that there could be some consternation in those four countries about the decision to phase out the developing country preference; however, I visited two of those four countries in the past couple of months and I was heartened by their acceptance of the decision to phase out the developing country preference. The fact is that all four of those countries now have a relatively high standard of living and it is arguable whether they could seriously be described as developing countries. In any case the Government has done the right thing by phasing down that developing country preference while at the same time reducing general protection. I certainly welcome that. As a South Australian whose State contains a big part of Australia's automotive industry, I note that this legislation reduces protection for the car industry from 35 per cent in 1992 to 15 per cent by the year 2000.

These Bills raise a large number of issues, but I want to address four particular issues briefly. Firstly, the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) who claims-I think probably quite rightly-to be the only sugar grower in the House of Representatives, possibly even in the Parliament--
Government members-Hinkler!

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise for the mistake; even I can make mistakes. I think the claim by the honourable member for Hinkler is probably right. The legislation reduces the level of tariff on sugar to $55 per tonne by 1 July 1992. There is a legitimate criticism of this decision in the sense that the Government had made an earlier commitment, which it subsequently decided to change in this legislation. It has to be said that the tariff protection for the sugar industry, which replaced the old quota system, is a system based on dollars per tonne rather than a percentage value. If at a time such as this, when international sugar prices are falling, we were to convert the dollar per tonne level of tariff protection to a percentage rate, we would find that at $55 per tonne the sugar industry would be left with a level of protection of somewhere between 30 and 40 per cent. That still represents a very high level of protection for that industry, particularly as that industry argues-I think with complete justification-that it is the most efficient sugar industry in the world. If it is the most efficient sugar industry in the world, inevitably-I think that anyone could follow the logic of this-it does not need high levels of tariff protection to beat off foreign competition.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that there is some concern in the industry about dumping from other parts of the world. Sometimes the example of Thailand is used, as is the European Community, which is a sugar beet producer and not a sugar cane producer and so can only compete on the international marketplace with substantial subsidies. The point I make is that if the Europeans, the Thais, or whoever they may be, are selling sugar into the Australian market at dumped prices, then that is an occasion for us to use anti-dumping mechanisms to restrain that unfair trade. It is not an excuse for us to say that we should have higher levels of tariff protection, because even if we did have higher levels of tariff protection than we currently have, they could still be dumping into our market. They could be using more expensive export subsidies than they would need with a lower level of tariff protection, but they could still do it. My argument about using efficient anti-dumping mechanisms would still hold. I think it is important that the sugar industry and the sugar growers have that point properly explained to them.

I am critical of the Government for not doing enough to gain greater access for Australian sugar exports, in particular, into the European Community and the United States. I think I am right in saying that the level of protection for the United States sugar industry is around 40 per cent, which is similar to what our level of protection will be by 1 July 1992.
Mr Price interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —They have quotas and a tariff system; I think they have both. I am disappointed that the Government, in making this decision to reduce our level of tariff protection, has not also simultaneously made representations in the United States and with the European Community to grant us greater access to those markets. For example, even if access to the European Community were marginal, it would make a very significant impact on the livelihoods of our sugar producers.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth recalling that when Britain joined the European Community back in 1973 we had been major sugar suppliers to Britain. Its access to the European Community led almost overnight to our access to the European, and particularly the British, sugar market being cut off altogether. That had a very severe impact on our sugar producers. This is not an excuse for our sugar producers-they tell me, and I believe them, that they are the most efficient in the world-to have higher levels of protection. It is an example of how we must use the process of lowering our own rates of protection in Australia to gain greater market access in other parts of the world.

My second point is that these reductions in our levels of protection in general-I am not just referring to sugar-are consistent with the commitment that we as a country have made, and both sides of politics have made, to the Uruguay Round of multilateral trade negotiations. I have been critical in the past that the Government, on the one hand-and quite rightly-has been pounding away at the European Community for not doing enough to liberalise access to the European market for agriculture and to phase out export subsidies. On the other hand, on our side of the equation, it does not seem to me that in the past we have done enough to reduce our levels of tariff protection. The offer we made for reductions in tariff protection in the context of the Uruguay Round struck me as being rather similar to the offer the Europeans made in reducing aggregate support in general for agriculture. In that respect, our offer did not seem to be particularly convincing.

This legislation will make it easier for us to argue foursquare within the Uruguay Round for the Europeans to reduce support for agriculture and for other general measures of liberalisation. To many honourable members this is an esoteric point. I assure the House that this is not an esoteric point; this is a point that is absolutely fundamental to the livelihood of this country. Either we get a successful result from the Uruguay Round or the world will descend into trade wars, and we will be pathetic little victims in massive trade wars if that happens. So it is enormously important to the livelihood of all Australians that the Uruguay Round concludes successfully and, therefore, we should ensure that any contributions we make to the debate about reducing protection are consistent with our aspirations in the Uruguay Round.

My third point, regrettably, relates to the import credit scheme that the Government is introducing in this legislation for the textile, clothing and footwear (TCF) industry. I say `regrettably' because that particular measure, even though it is only a small scheme, actually contradicts all that I have said already, and all that the Government is apparently trying to achieve in the area of tariff protection. Let us face it, let us not beat about the bush: the import credit scheme constitutes an export subsidy. For Australia to be going to the Uruguay Round negotiations, to have gone to Brussels last December, and to be conducting subsequent discussions all around the world, in particular in Geneva, calling for countries to phase out their export subsidies, in particular the European Community, and then for us to be introducing an export subsidy to protect and assist an industry which, in a global sense, is a very sensitive industry-TCF is a sensitive industry not just in Australia but in every country of the world-is hypocrisy of the worst kind.
I remind the House of what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) continually says and said not that long ago:
There must be a general willingness to practise at home what we preach abroad.

During the period of the Fraser Government, I seem to remember that that was quite a common theme from the Labor Party in opposition. Whilst I will not particularly comment on going to a debate about that-and I have spoken earlier about the Fraser Government's real commitment to reducing protection, so some of that criticism was not justified-it is important to note that the Government is not living up to the Prime Minister's rhetoric.

This import credit scheme is an export subsidy. It is not quite clear, but it could be contrary to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) rules. That is the advice that the Government received from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade; indeed, it was argued by Senator Evans and by the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Dr Blewett) in the Cabinet discussions on this issue. The disappointing thing is that the Government decided that its GATT commitments-those foreign policy and international trade policy arguments-were apparently less important than trying to curry favour with a few people in the textile, clothing and footwear industry. I think that is very disappointing. As I said, it makes Australia's position in the Uruguay Round a little absurd.

Some people could say, `Well, this export subsidy is only small beer. It is not going to matter very much'. I remind the House that last year, when the Government introduced its luxury car tax legislation, it could have been argued that that was only small beer, it did not matter very much and, in any case, nobody likes people who drive luxury cars. The philosophy and attitude of the Labor Party is that they are all terrible people. But the interesting thing is that the Europeans, in particular, browbeat us about that luxury car tax throughout the life of the tax. I am glad to say that last week the legislation to repeal that tax passed through this House. We find exactly the same thing with this textile, clothing and footwear import credit scheme. We will be browbeaten on this scheme because we are introducing an export subsidy quite contrary to all we are arguing in the area, in particular, of agriculture.

Finally, I want to refer to the amendment moved by the honourable member for Barker about what we might generally describe as micro-economic reform. If we just reduce tariffs in this country but do not do anything to assist this country to become internationally competitive and if we say that we will internationalise our economy by reducing tariffs but not do anything to ensure that our shipping, our waterfront, our industrial relations and taxation system are internationalised as well, which means that they are relevant to the competitive pressures of the international marketplace, as a country we will simply not make it. That is a truism. That is not a politician's claim; it is not an Opposition's bleat; it is a truism.

One of the core problems of this Government, at least of its economic strategy-although I must say that some of the things I have heard and read in the last week make me think that it may have problems way beyond this-is that it finds it impossible to institute the reforms on the waterfront, in shipping, on the railways, in industrial relations and in taxation that this country simply has to make in order to be competitive.

The reason for this was actually outlined, implicitly but not explicitly, by the speech earlier of the honourable member for Hinkler. He made the point that the Australian Labor Party is so closely linked with the trade union movement that it is actually a virtue to do what the trade union movement wants. If a waterside worker is doing a handful of hours work a week and has a job for life-security of tenure-why would he want anything else? That is fine for him. But the fact is that 6,000 waterside workers in Australia are holding to ransom this country's trade, balance of payments and foreign debt. That is also a truism. The Government says that it would like to do something about it. It carries on with its sort of mealy-mouthed hand wringing about how it is going to introduce enterprise based agreements and all of that. But, of course, it will not do it in a way that in any respect would offend the glorious trade union movement, in particular the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia.

It is the same with shipping. When wheat can be shipped from the west coast of the United States of America to New Zealand more cheaply than from the east coast of Australia to New Zealand, would one not think that we had a bit of a problem, particularly when wheat prices are at a very low level and wheat growers are struggling to make ends meet?

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the railways?
—The honourable member for Wannon asks, `What about the railways?' All those arguments are the same.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, on taxation we ought to do something to make our taxation system internationally relevant. Twenty-two members of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) have a value added tax or goods and services tax and have no tax on exports. This Government has not got up to that, which means that our export prices are about 2 per cent higher than those of most other OECD members. We have a long way to go. It is good to reduce the tariffs. There are a few contradictory and quite hypocritical measures here--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Mr H.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was certainly a high point in the speech from the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer). It was something that I did not think I would ever hear him say. He actually admitted that he could make mistakes. We have come to regard him as `Mr Perfect'. It is good to know that he can make mistakes-and some of them were quite glaring.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill which is designed to phase down general ad valorem tariff rates to 5 per cent, to phase down tariffs for the textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF) industries to a maximum of 25 per cent by the year 2000, to phase down tariffs on passenger motor vehicles and original equipment components to 15 per cent by the year 2000 and to reduce the tariff rate on raw and refined sugar.

The Bill gives effect to those announcements of certain tariff changes in the Government's 12 March statement which was contained in the document Building a Competitive Australia. It really is about competition and making Australia competitive.

The Bounty Legislation Bill is designed to phase down bounty rates applying to various industries and to widen the scope of certain bounty schemes with the requirement for minimum annual production levels to be met in order to be eligible for certain bounties.

I suppose it would be appropriate in this debate to look at how we got into the position of requiring these Bills-of how Australia became dependent on high levels of tariff protection, subsidies and bounties. It happened over a long period. The honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) was right in saying that the debate has been going on for many years. The honourable member for Mayo was quite wrong in saying that the Australian Labor Party initially supported protectionism. One hundred years ago when the Labor Party was first formed in New South Wales, the Premier of New South Wales at that time was the 76-year-old Sir Henry Parkes. Thirty-five members of the Labor Party were elected to that first Government in New South Wales and they came down on the side of the free traders and supported Sir Henry Parkes.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Federal Labor Party, in the Federal Parliament.

—This was before Federation. In the initial stages the Labor Party supported the free traders. In 1975 Whitlam cut tariffs by 25 per cent. We are burying protectionism now. The position that we got into was the result largely of postwar policies of conservative governments; there is no denying that. They came about in the years of Jack McEwen, the former Deputy Prime Minister and the former Leader of the Country Party of Australia. The story goes that in those years if one presented oneself in Jack McEwen's office as a member or a leader of an industry and put forward certain arguments that showed that one needed protection for various reasons, assurances were probably given at those private meetings.

SPEECH.PARA: I noticed that the honourable member for Mayo made certain references to events in Western Australia. If the sorts of tariff protection, subsidies and bounties that were handed out in those years by Jack McEwen were around today, I wonder what sorts of accusations would be going around now. Those measures were not in the interests of country people. Let us remember that Jack McEwen was the Leader of the Country Party. The honourable member for Barker acknowledged that. He said that many years ago farmers realised that they were paying for that protection, so Jack McEwen could not have been unaware that the people he represented were paying the price. Why did he go along with those things? He had private meetings. That scenario was much more damning than are the sorts of things that the Opposition is bringing forward in relation to events in Western Australia.

What we are aiming for and what we have to look at is who is paying, or who has paid in the past, the price of those tariff barriers that have been produced. Two classes of people are affected. One is the primary producer; there is no doubt about that. The honourable member for Barker said that many years ago farmers realised that they had been paying the price. The other group is the low income earners. The levels of assistance to the TCF industries are the highest for Australian manufacturing. The Industry Commission estimates that the average effective rate of assistance to the textiles, clothing and footwear industries in 1988-89 was close to 150 per cent. The Industry Commission also estimated that the cost to consumers of protection in those industries in 1988-89 totalled about $1.7 billion or about $300 per family. So the costs were borne mainly by the low income families because it cost them the same to buy a pair of shoes as it did wealthy families.
An examination of the 1986 census information shows that the highest percentage of low income earners is found in seats held by the National Party of Australia-what used to be the Country Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your own?

—In 1986 it was a National Party electorate and it fits into that scenario of a high percentage of low income earners and a low percentage of high income earners. I am going back to 1986 figures when it was a National Party electorate. I am also going back and asking, `Why would a leader of the Country Party, which represented those sorts of electorates, put in policies that cost those constituents more than electorates with wealthy constituents?'. That is the question I am putting. The other question is this: with the acknowledgment that farmers realised many years ago that they were paying the price of these high tariff policies, why would a leader of the Country Party encourage those policies?
—To save manufacturing jobs, to save the workers' jobs.

—That was not in his interests. He was there, as the honourable member for Cowper and I are, to represent his constituents. Our constituents are in primary industry. Jack McEwen, the Leader of the Country Party and the Deputy Prime Minister at the time fell down on his job in doing that.

SPEECH.PARA: We are aiming for competitive industries in Australia. That will come about by these policies if they are able to be dynamic to change. There are all sorts of costs involved in running a business. I have been in business all my life. Business does not just depend on interest rates, tariff policies or tariff protection. If one has ever looked at a profit and loss account, one will be aware that it depends on a whole list of things. If one is not dynamic and not able to change weekly, daily or yearly to new conditions, one fails at business. Many of the business failures we see now are due to that. They are due to management inability to change.

As a bookmaker, I know that one's ability as a bookmaker reflects one's capacity to change to new circumstances from race to race. Bookmaking is a business and reflects that type of competition and free enterprise as one is competing not only against the punters but also against all the other bookmakers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that on-course, Harry?
—That is on-course.
—Still registered?

—No, I handed in my licence when I came here. There is no getting away from the transition period that these businesses go through. It is recognised that there will be a transition period where it will be difficult for some of them. It will be the businesses which get through that transition period, which are able to change their way of operating, which will come through that. The end result for those businesses will be the ability to compete on the open market, compete with overseas goods-not only in Australia-and bring forth goods that are not only competitive in price but also competitive in quality. For years Australians have had to put up with minus quantities on both those counts. They have paid too much and they have got less quality. We can blame the Opposition for that.
—Blame us!

—Yes. The Opposition comes in here and tries to jump on the band wagon by saying, `We did it'. But, by and large, the policies were put in in the post-war era by the Opposition. SPEECH.PARA: Currently there are a number of bounty arrangements in which individual recipients may qualify for very small annual payments. Such payments are inefficient and do nothing to enhance industry development. They institute minimum annual payment thresholds for bounty eligibility. Many of the arguments that apply to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill also apply to the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill. I support both those Bills. More efficient use of resources resulting from cuts in protection will lead to increased output--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you talk about sugar?

—The honourable member for Mayo just spoke about sugar and supported absolutely the provisions in the Bill regarding the cuts in sugar. The honourable member for Mayo is on the same side of Parliament as the honourable member for Cowper.
—Sometimes.

This is in addition to increases due to the program put in in May 1988.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to commend Fairfield City Council, the largest local government body within my electorate, for finally coming to the party and introducing recycled paper products into the Council's administration offices. I was pleased to see that $5,000 in extra funding has now been allocated to allow the Council to purchase recycled products such as paper, exercise books, note pads, envelopes and correction fluid. Fairfield Council, in announcing this decision, wrote to me seeking support for the increased use of recycled products in the workplace.

SPEECH.PARA: I feel that I must remind the Council that my office has been using recycled products since I was a member of the State Parliament. In fact, I condemned Fairfield Council in July 1989 for not taking an active part in recycling. It was then that I informed the Council that an increase in the recycling of paper would contribute significantly to conserving Australia's natural resources and could even help improve our balance of trade.

A mere 30 per cent of paper consumed by Australians is recovered for recycling-nowhere near enough, when we consider the advantages of recycling. The main benefits that would flow from increased levels of paper recycling in Australia would be a saving of our forest resources, avoidance of water pollution from the processing of wood for paper production and avoidance of the disposal costs of waste paper. Benefits to the balance of trade could also occur as a result of increased paper recycling, in that imports of pulp or paper could be lessened if more raw materials were supplied from Australia, and export earnings could be increased by selling collected waste overseas.

More and more councils are becoming actively involved in recycling and are also encouraging their communities to recycle products. The New South Wales Local Government Association (LGA) has recently given its support to a proposal for the establishment of a local government recycling cooperative to handle recyclable materials. The recycling centre would initially handle only paper, but eventually other recyclable materials could also be handled. According to the Local Government Association, the cooperative would be established on a non-profit basis and funds generated would be returned to participating councils or put back into improved facilities and operational efficiency.

Already, the recovery of waste paper from households is common in urban areas throughout Australia, as many councils have now recognised the overall benefits to the local community through waste paper collections. There is also scope for local councils to encourage the collection of all types of waste paper which are heavily represented in domestic waste, such as newsprint or printing paper in magazines. Surveys and experience indicate that a significant proportion of householders are willing to go to some trouble to cooperate with recycling collection schemes. If this is indeed the case, the LGA's recycling cooperative initiative should be very successful.

The Department of Administrative Services produced a recycled paper review in 1990 which identified a number of reasons why the recycling of paper is beneficial to the environment and to the economy. According to this review, the benefits of recycling paper include preserving forests and hence reducing the greenhouse effect; reducing paper imports combined with a possibility of increasing export earnings by selling recycled paper overseas; reducing costs of waste disposal; and other environmental benefits such as reducing energy use, air pollution, water pollution and water use.

Preserving our forests is perhaps one of the most vital benefits of recycling paper. To a great extent, our forests are being cut down because we consume large quantities of paper. It has been reported that the average Australian uses the equivalent of 50 large telephone books in paper each year. However, if individuals choose to buy only recycled paper and to recycle waste paper, fewer trees would need to be cut down, harmful bleaching chemicals need not be used, and waste disposal could be reduced proportionately.

There are two types of recycled paper available to consumers. One is made from 100 per cent recycled, consumer used office paper, unbleached and not de-inked, called `ReRight', which is made by Australian Paper Manufacturers. The second type, which is made from 100 per cent unused paper mill off-cuts, is called `Recycle 100' and is made by Associated Pulp and Paper Mills. Recycled paper is suitable for typing, printing, drafting, invoices, envelopes, et cetera. Offices could also conserve paper by using both sides of the paper, making no more copies than are really necessary and using waste paper for notes and scribbler pads.

I am very pleased to see that Fairfield Council is taking positive steps towards the conservation of paper and is now becoming actively involved in the paper recycling movement. Perhaps the last comment on this issue should lie with Fairfield Council, which concluded in its meeting about using recycled products in February:

Environmental necessity suggests that organisations such as Council should make an effort to introduce recycled products. Not only is this environmentally sound, it will also help raise demand for these products which will help to lower prices. Thus, in the long run, Council will benefit from lower prices as well as a better environment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, upon notice, on 17 September 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will he provide localised figures for the actual (a) percentages and (b) numbers of (i) males and (ii) females actively seeking employment who are registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) at the (A) Bendigo and (B) Maryborough, Vic. offices.

(2) Will he authorise officers at the Bendigo and Maryborough offices of the CES to release to my electorate office, from time to time upon request, defined figures, by location for males and females actively seeking employment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth Employment Service collects data on numbers of unemployed awaiting placement at local CES office level (local UAP) for internal management purposes only. The data is not released because it is neither an accurate measure of unemployment nor a reliable indicator of changes in unemployment. General release of UAP data would involve an undue use of Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) resources in preparation of material and responses to inquiries, yet it would provide no additional reliable information on the labour market.

The UAP data is based on records of registrations held in CES Offices. While the CES removes individuals from the register when it becomes aware that they are no longer seeking work (e.g., they have found work or they have left the labour force), registrants are not required to inform the CES when this is the case. (Unemployment beneficiaries are, of course, required to inform the Department of Social Security). To seek to ensure that all individuals are removed from the register as soon as they find a job would require an undue and unjustified diversion of CES resources to this task. Further not all people seeking employment register with the CES.

In short, the UAP data essentially provides a measure of the number of people who have registered with the CES and are still listed as possibly requiring assistance, but unavoidably it includes many who no longer require this assistance. It is certainly not a measure of the number of people ``actively seeking employment''.

Moreover, numbers on the CES register of job seekers vary over time not just as a result of changes in labour market conditions, but also because of variations in administrative procedures, and the effects of Government policy, particularly the impact of changes in labour market programs and changes in the use of these programs.
The inaccuracies and distortions in the data are especially significant at the local level.

The most accurate indicator of the number of people in Australia actually seeking employment is available from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) estimates, collected via the monthly Labour Force Survey, which are specifically and rigorously designed to measure unemployment in accordance with International Labour Organisation standards. These ABS figures, which are the official measure of unemployment in Australia, are available monthly for 60 regions in Australia.

DEET also prepares annually a document titled ``Developments in Regional Labour Markets-Australia''. This provides estimates, based in part on regional data from the ABS Labour Force Survey, of unemployment levels and unemployment rates in Local Government Areas. While I would stress that the figures in this publication are only estimates and not the actual situation, they do provide the best available estimates of unemployment at a local level. A number of Local Government Areas in the Bendigo and Maryborough areas are separately identified in that publication. The next update of the document covering the June quarter 1990 is currently in preparation. DEET is also taking steps to ensure greater timeliness in the production of these estimates in the future.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 14 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has Australia Post adopted the practice for security reasons of forwarding all overseas mail posted in letter receivers by surface mail, with the exception of standard letters and aerograms; if so, (a) when did this practice commence and (b) why has it not been made public knowledge by a proper advertising campaign.

(2) Does the acceptance by Australia Post of an item carrying the correct fee, in the form of stamps or other forms of franking, constitute a contract between Australia Post, who has accepted a fee, the sender and the person to whom the item is addressed.
(3) Will Australia Post be liable for damages or compensation should such claims arise from the unannounced changes of delivery methods.
(4) Does Australia Post have a responsibility to inform the public of changes in its contractual arrangements.
(5) Could Australia Post derive considerable profit by charging airmail rates for items it has no intention of delivering as airmail.
(6) Is a record of the return address of items so diverted being kept and have the persons concerned been notified the items are not being carried by air; if not, why not.
(7) Was he advised by Australia Post of its intentions before they were implemented.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. Items addressed to overseas destinations which carry postage sufficient for air transmission are conveyed from Australia to other countries by airline services. This applies to all airmail items irrespective of the point of lodgement.
(2) A contract does not exist in respect of articles delivered in the ordinary course of post except for receipted articles.

(3) There have not been any unannounced changes in delivery methods for overseas mail. If there were to be unannounced changes, any liability would depend on the circumstances necessitating such changes. Claims could arise in respect of receipted articles or articles not carried by the letter service if it could be shown that Australia Post was, in some way, at fault.

(4) Australia Post does not have a statutory obligation to inform the public of changes in its contractual or delivery arrangements. However, Australia Post informs the public of any such changes where it is reasonably possible to do so and as a matter of sound commercial practice.
(5) Australia Post does not provide services at levels below those for which the customer has paid.
(6) As items are not being diverted in the alleged manner the requirement to inform the sender does not apply.
(7) As items are not being diverted in the alleged manner the question of my being informed does not apply.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 21 February 1991:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 5 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do media reports from South Africa suggest that the white Government wants special provisions to protect their minority group rights built into any new constitution.
(2) Does his Government (a) support special rights for minority groups or (b) demand a pure one man, one vote system.
(3) Does he support protection of special rights in the constitution of South African sporting organisations for minority groups.

(4) Is the South African Cricket Union and South African Cricket Board to merge into one organisation whose constitution will contain special rights to protect minority groups; if so, will he support the organisation's right to play international cricket.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The Government supports a non-racial and democratic political system in South Africa, but it is for the people of South Africa to determine the shape of that political system.

(3) The Government does not have any blanket policy about the protection of special rights in the constitutions of foreign sporting organisations. The Government supports the efforts currently being made by South African sporting codes towards unification along non-racial lines. The constitutions of such sporting bodies are for their members themselves to determine.

(4) The South African Cricket Union and South African Cricket Board have undertaken to merge their organisations into a single non-racial body. The constitution of this new body is currently being negotiated, and whether it contains special rights to protect minority groups remains to be seen. The decision of the London meeting of the Commonwealth Committee of Foreign Ministers on Southern Africa was to recognise South African sports which unify, and to be guided by the views of representative non-racial sporting organisations in this regard. In accordance with that decision, irrespective of the presence or absence of special rights provisions in sporting bodies' constitutions, I will support the right of any unified non-racial body to recognition by the international community, including the right to play international sport.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 7 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is Australia one of only five Commonwealth countries which allow certain South African sportspersons to play in their respective countries.
(2) Is Australia one of only a few Commonwealth countries which have not stopped certain of their own sportspersons playing in South Africa.
(3) Did many Commonwealth countries impose government sanctions on sporting contact with South Africa many years before Australia imposed partial sporting sanctions with South Africa.
(4) Is it a fact that Australia did not lead the way in imposing sporting sanctions against South Africa, contrary to his statement to the House on 20 February 1991.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Since some countries do not have clear policies on sporting contacts with South Africa, it is not possible to put a precise figure on the number of Commonwealth countries which allow certain South African sportspersons to play on their territory. It is clear, nonetheless, that only a small number of countries allow South African sportspersons to play on their territory.
(3) No. Australia first introduced sporting sanctions in 1972. The majority of Commonwealth countries introduced sporting sanctions after that date.

(4) Australia made an early decision to impose sporting sanctions on South Africa. As the Hansard record of my answer to a question without notice in the House on 20 February 1991 clearly shows, I was speaking about Australia leading the way in the imposition of sanctions in general-as it did-and not sporting sanctions in particular.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 7 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he make comments which suggest that the South African Cricket Union led by Geoff Dakin is racially based.
(2) Are there any provisions in the constitution of the South African Cricket Union which restrict any person of any race from joining any club or from using any of the facilities of a club.

(3) Does the constitution of the South African Cricket Union contain an automatic expulsion clause which applies to any person or club which discriminates against any person on the basis of race, colour or ethnic origin.
(4) Is he able to state whether many blacks play club cricket in each province affiliated with the South African Cricket Union.
(5) Are there almost 100 000 black and coloured children participating in coaching programs organised by the South African Cricket Union.
(6) Has the South African Cricket Union established a scholarship system which enables black school teachers to finish their education.
(7) Is the South African Cricket Board basically an Indian and coloured organisation with few black or white members.
(8) Does he unequivocally support the South African Cricket Board; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) One of the legacies of South Africa's history of sports apartheid is the reality that neither the South African Cricket Union (SACU) nor the South African Cricket Board (SACB) can claim to be truly representative of South African cricket. It is because of this that the two bodies are currently engaged in a process of reconciliation and unification to form a single, non-racial cricket body which will represent all South African cricketers. The Government applauds this process and looks forward to the early normalisation of South African cricket.

(3) There is no clause in the SACU constitution which provides for automatic expulsion for discriminatory conduct. There are, however, provisions which would allow the suspension or expulsion of an affiliate of SACU for such conduct.

(4) The SACU does not keep specific figures on the racial composition of its members, nor does the Government hold statistics on the question. SACU claims that about 40% of players in SACU-organised competitions come from black, Indian and coloured communities, but the SACB doubts that the figure is as high as this.

(5) Coaching programs in South African cricket are now run under the joint SACU/SACB development trust formed in January this year. While it has no specific figures, the trust is confident that there would be more than 100,000 participants.
(6) There is such a scholarship system for black-and other-school teachers. Like the coaching program, it is also under the joint SACU/SACB development trust.

(7) No. The SACB contains members from all racial groups-including blacks and whites. While the Western Cape and Natal have higher proportions of coloureds and Indians (reflecting their greater overall presence in these provinces), there are still significant numbers from other population groups playing in these provinces. In the Eastern Cape and border regions, membership at both player and administrative level is almost completely black (again reflecting the overall population composition of these regions).

(8) The Government does not unequivocally support, as a matter of policy, any foreign sporting organisation. The Government supports the process of reconciliation and unification that the SACU and the SACB are engaged in, and trusts that this process will soon bring about a single, non-racial South African cricket body.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Special Assistance Program for South Africans

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, upon notice, on 12 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government provided funds for the Special Assistance Program for South Africans and Namibians; if so, (a) what are the (i) details of the funds and (ii) the criteria attached to the spending of the funds and (b) were some of the funds directed through the African National Congress (ANC).
(2) Has the ANC recently purchased the multistorey Shell Building in central Johannesburg for 20 million rand; if so, was Australian aid money used in the purchase of the building.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Government established the Special Assistance Program for South Africans and Namibians (SAPSAN) in 1986 with a view to assisting South Africans and Namibians disadvantaged by apartheid. The focus of SAPSAN was on education and training for people of South Africa and Namibia, whether in their own countries or as refugees elsewhere in Africa. Some humanitarian assistance has also been provided. A total of $11.9 million was spent under SAPSAN during the period 1986-1990 (The Program was renamed as the Special Assistance Program for South Africans (SAPSA) in recognition of Namibia's independence).
1. (a) (i) Details of programs funded under SAPSAN from 1986 to June 1990 are set out in the attached Appendix.

In May 1990, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade announced that assistance of up to $15 million would be provided over the period 1990/91 to 1992/93 for SAPSA. A further commitment of $2 million ($200,000 of which was spent in 1989/90) was made by the Minister to assist with the repatriation and resettlement of black South Africans living in exile. This total of $16.8 million available under SAPSA during the 1990/91-1992/93 triennium is additional to the $11.9 million spent under SAPSAN to June 1990.
1. (a) (ii) The basic criteria governing expenditure of funds under SAPSA are:

* the funds are for activities identified in consultation with the ANC. Funding of such activities is through Australian or international non-government organisations or relevant Australian High Commissions or Embassies.
* Activities funded must meet the objectives of the program which are:
- give substance to Australia's condemnation of apartheid;
- meet humanitarian needs caused by apartheid;
- help prepare disadvantaged South African inhabitants and refugees for the post-apartheid era;

- assist in the accelerated economic and social development of black South Africans in the movement to a free and democratic society, with particular emphasis on those sectors (i.e. education and training) and communities especially disadvantaged by apartheid;
- to increase Australian's awareness of the need for change in South Africa and what they can do to support it; and
- to give Australians a meaningful and positive role to play in helping disadvantaged South Africans prepare for the future of their country.
1. (b) Australia does not provide direct funding to the ANC under the SAPSA program.
2. We understand that a private business consortium has purchased a building in Johannesburg for the use of the ANC. No Australian or other aid money was used in the acquisition of the building.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 12 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that all civil marriage celebrants are required to advertise in the Telecom Yellow Pages or risk their continued authorisation.

(2) If so, will the Minister review the requirement so that celebrants in smaller communities may advertise in local newspapers rather than incur the unreasonable expense of advertising in Telecom directories.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Civil marriage celebrants in Australia are required to be listed in the Telecom Yellow Pages of their local telephone directory under the heading ``Marriage Celebrants-Civil.'' In addition, civil celebrants may of course advertise in local publications in accordance with established guidelines. Appointments as civil marriage celebrants are made to provide a service to the community and it is important that their services are made known to the general community.

A large number of celebrants throughout Australia have not listed their names in the Yellow Pages. In the 1991 Yellow Pages, only about 58% of civil marriage celebrants have their names listed. A celebrant's continued authorisation could be reconsidered if his/her name is not listed.

(2) A Yellow Pages listing is a prominent and convenient way of ensuring a celebrant's availability is made known to the general community on a continual rather than periodic basis, as is the case with newspaper advertisements. The additional charge for a Yellow Pages listing is not considered unreasonable and may be claimed as a taxation deduction under the provisions of subsection 51(1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. Regular advertising in a newspaper may well cost more and be less effective.
